If you are a writer or work in the publishing industry, THE PLOT is for you. As a matter of fact, the good reviews of this book that I‚Äôve seen have been written by people in the publishing industry.As far as I can tell, though, this book is not for anyone else. It bored me. I am sure it will bore most people, maybe even some writers and those who work in the publishing industry.Jake has written a highly successful novel that he based on a plot written by one of his students. The student is now dead, and Jake has rewritten the story. Jake did not really steal it from anyone, but he feels that he did. So does someone else who is badgering him online about it. Who is this? That‚Äôs what Jake sets out to learn.I read several good reviews of this book before I decided to read it. I feel cheated. Although most reviews warn that the book has a slow beginning, they also assure the reader that it gets suspenseful, thrilling. Believe me when I tell you that, yes, THE PLOT does have a slow beginning; BUT it continues to drag right up to page 300.If you can delay your gratification that long, go for it. I don‚Äôt know any people who can do that. No one should have to.Even after page 300, you‚Äôre bound to be disappointed. The whole mystery is solved in the end, and I could see it coming long before I got that far.

Jacob Finch Bonner has the story of his life. He knows it needs to be written. Too bad it's not his story to tell.As an unhappy teacher in an MFA program, Jacob is going through the motions. When classes begin, he meets a sullen student, Evan Parker. Evan is disrespectful towards Jacob. He also doesn't think Jacob can teach him anything and doesn't try to hide his feelings. During their only one-on-one meeting, Evan says he has the best plot for a novel. He's sure when he is done writing it, everyone will want to read it. Publishers will fight for it. He will be famous and Oprah will pick it as the "it" book. After Evan tells him what the plot is about, Jacob disgruntedly has to agree and he knows the book will be a success.A few years later, Jacob is in a new job. A job that leaves him time to work on a new novel but if he has to be honest with himself, he can't come up with anything good. Jacob's first novel was good but the two after have not been recognized at all.Over the years, Jacob has never forgotten about Evan's plot. A quick search about Evan's whereabouts on social media leaves Jacob in shock. Evan is dead and he never wrote the novel!Jacob makes a decision that will forever affect his future. He decides to bring to life the story he heard so long ago. Yet, someone is quite unhappy with his decision.Quite an interesting novel! I was engrossed reading about both plots, Jacob's and the novel he wrote.I had some issues about Jacob's guilty feelings. Yes, he used the plot of someone else's but the words were his. Yes, what he did was wrong but he didn't plagiarize a novel. What if Evan found out the hard way, that it can be quite difficult to write a book?The big twist was not impossible to guess. I was waiting to see which way the author was going to take it and I wasn't disappointed.Cliffhanger: No4/5 FangsA complimentary copy was provided by Celadon Books via Netgalley in exchange for an honest review.MrsLeif's Two Fangs About It | Facebook | Twitter | Instagram

The Plot is a slow burning and highly entertaining novel by Jean Hanff Korelitz. I loved it and I loved the narrator, Kirby Heyborne, whose voice I recognized immediately as the narrator who hypnotized me in Kubica‚Äôs Don‚Äôt You Cry. Jake Bonner is an author whose first novel was reviewed favorably in the NYTimes Book Review, where he was labeled, an author to keep your eye on. Several years (book rejections) later, he is on the Ripley College writer‚Äôs workshop circuit, a misanthrope charged with mentoring a ragtag group of wannabe authors. He drives an old car, still uses the same natty (rhymes with?) furniture from his college days and, in general, fits the description of an altogether, self-deprecating sourpuss.Enter younger narcissistic nemesis (NN), Evan Parker/Parker Evan, whose sole purpose, it seems, is to yank Jake‚Äôs chain. Puffed up NN, disparages all around him, including Jake, and boasts that he has come up with the ultimate plot that will catapult him into Stardom ‚Äì Best Seller, Agents & Publisher, a spot on Oprah Winfrey, lecture and interview circuits, Movie rights and let‚Äôs not forget a copy of his book on the table in the entrance of every book store. Tightlipped NN will not give away anything about his plot, yet at some point he can hold it in no longer and spills the beans to Jake, in the privacy of his office. Jake is gobsmacked, he knows that all the rewards NN claims he will reap from publishing his novel will come true for him‚Ä¶(circa) Four years later, Jake has dropped down to the lowest levels of the food chain, when he notices that NN‚Äôs book has never been published‚Ä¶he learns that NN actually died several months after attending the Ripley College Writer‚Äôs Workshop. Jake weaves NN‚Äôs plot into a book. The words are entirely his, as are character and plot development. As far as he knows, Jake is the only person who ever heard the plot from NN. Jake writes the Novel that catapults him into Stardom ‚Äì Best Seller, Agents & Publisher, a spot on Oprah Winfrey, lecture and interview circuits, Movie rights and let‚Äôs not forget a copy of his book on the table in the entrance of every book store (did I just plagiarize, er, repeat, myself?). Jake finally becomes a grown-up at the age of 30-something. He meets and marries the girl of his dreams, who changes his life (not to mention the furniture, dishes, and glassware). She feeds him lots of green soup and boy does he lap it up. His life is now meaningful and happy. Sourpuss is now the picture of contentment - hahahah, tell me you don‚Äôt see it coming‚Ä¶. Ooo eee, ooo ah ah ting tang, Walla walla, bing bang‚Ä¶. he wasn‚Äôt very smart (oops, there I go again, forgive me David Seville/Ross Bagdasarian).Everything comes crashing down around poor Jake as the first (of many) message(s) arrives from Tricky Tom. (Our author joins me in my newfound infatuation with Patricia Highsmith.) Did Jake or did Jake not plagiarize Evan Parker/Parker Evan‚Äôs book? Not every idea you throw out into the air can be claimed as your intellectual property‚Ä¶and you cannot plagiarize something that has never been published (published does not necessarily mean printed). Too bad Jake didn't have confidence in the merit and integrity of his work. To legally discredit Jake, "Tom" would have had come forward and expose the source of the claim, which would likely have been impossible since the manuscript was never published - if it existed at all. Possibly, there might have been a breach of confidence, but heck, the guy whose confidence may have been breached is too dead to sue. Let me set your minds at rest, plagiarism will make for a great debate in a book club, but it is not really the issue here, there are other issues at play. I mean, like what's with all that green soup wife keeps making and Jake keeps slurping? I looked up what green symbolizes in literature...are we talking guilt, greed, jealousy? Whose?I figured out who Tom was pretty early-on, but I confess, I should have expected (but did not) the PH-ish ending. WOW just WOW.Thank you NetGalley and Macmillan Audio for an ARC of this audio book. I LOVED IT. I loved the story/plot, I loved the writing, and I loved the narrator!

Jacob Finch Bonner had fallen on hard times. His first book was a moderate success, but book two was a flop and books three and four can‚Äôt even get published. He‚Äôs been reduced to teaching at a third rate MFA writing program. There, he encounters Evan Parker, the most obnoxious person anyone could have as a student. Evan is convinced he‚Äôs got the next best seller, on a par with Gone, Girl. When he dies later, never having published his supposed masterpiece, Jake steals the idea. And sure enough, the book is a colossal success. Then, the emails from Talented Tom start coming, accusing him of being a thief and a fraud. The theme of the book is who owns a story. This idea has been tackled before, even Mark Twain said there‚Äôs no such thing as an original idea. I liked that the book paints a very ambiguous story. This wasn‚Äôt a case of out and out plagiarism. Jake ties himself in knots explaining his own actions to himself. The book starts off slow and takes a while to really get going. The chapters interlace Jake‚Äôs life with chapters from his best seller. It would never be called fast paced. But there‚Äôs a nice underlying tension throughout and I was really curious to see how both stories would play out. I had a pretty good idea early on who Talented Tom but it didn‚Äôt dampen my enjoyment to be proven right. I was really impressed with Kirby Heyborne as the narrator. My thanks to NetGalley and Celadon Books/Macmillan Audio for advance copies of this book.

I won this in a giveaway from Celadon on Goodreads. I love getting books in the mail and especially free ones. Being a sucker for books about writers and their process and day to day problems, I really enjoyed this one. This is an in-depth look into plagiarism and how the theft of another writer's idea effects the thief. There are pages of text addressing how this person justifies what he has done and you almost start to believe it too. Jacob Finch Bonner is the writer. He is so pretentious that he adds "Finch" to his name from Atticus Finch in To Kill a Mockingbird. Ugh! Bonner has gotten to the bottom of the literary barrel and has no more ideas to write about. He discovers by chance that a student who had a great plot died without writing his sure thing and so Bonner decides to steal his dead student's great idea. I was ready to be wowed by the magnificent plot, but it turns out that wasn't the major twist of this book. The plot in question is only humdrum to my mind and has been done before. So, I don't know what all the hullaballoo was about in that instance, but the author of The Plot has a major twist that you don't see coming and I really was gobsmacked by it. All in all, a tasty little treat with a marvelous cherry on top ending.

"How many times, looking back at this night, the very last night of a time he would always afterward think of as "before" would he wish that he hadn't been so utterly, fatally wrong? How many times, in spite of the astonishing good fortune set in motion by one of those folders, would he wish he'd backed his way out of the sterile office, retraced his own muddy footprints down the corridor, returned to his car, and driven those many hours back to New York and his ordinary, personal failure? Too many, but no matter. It was already too late for that."Jacob Finch Bonner, a once promising debut author highlighted in "New & Noteworthy" (New York Times Book Review), had produced an underwhelmed second novel. Further manuscripts were rejected by numerous publishers. His three week writing seminar at Ripley College was billed as a workshop to shape future literary talent. "He was not looking forward to pretending that he himself was still a writer, let alone a great one.""(Evan Parker) entered the third rate MFA class with a swagger...clearly established as an alpha...judging from the hero's welcome....I'm happy to give my opinion on everyone's writing...don't expect me to change what I'm doing...I know what I've got here. I don't think there's a person on the planet...who could mess up a plot like mine...I'm not really looking to improve. I'm a very good writer, and my novel is well on track...". "Parker wrote with an eye for detail...the asshole appeared to be a natural writer...". Evan had submitted an excerpt of his story as a writing sample. He claimed the story, once written, would be a best seller, make millions, shake the literary world, and propel him to star status.Feeling defeated and unfulfilled, Jake accepted a job as a program coordinator nurturing beginning and struggling writers. "All he had ever wanted was to tell-in the best possible words, arranged in the best possible order-the stories inside him...Anybody could be a writer. anybody except, apparently, him." Evan Parker's book had not been written. A Google search. An obituary. "Later...Jake would go back to this moment...recognize it for the crossroads it was...the first of what would be many layers of rationalization." "Good writers borrow, great writers steal...He would hardly be the first to take some tale...and create something entirely new...".Crib by Jacob Finch Bonner was a bestselling tome. Readings, book signings, and a second novel in the works followed. Jake had arrived! Fame and fortune...then the email messages started. "You are a thief...we both know it...". The moniker-Talented Tom. Jake must hide the truth from his publisher and his readers. Having finally made it in the literary world, he needed to discover the person or persons hell bent on exposing him. If truth be stranger than fiction, is there an inner story behind the outer presentation in novel form? "The Plot" by Jean Hanff Korelitz is a thought provoking read that raises the moral issue of "a story too good not to steal" and its aftermath. The amazing twist was definitely a shocker. The trials and tribulations of a writer's life were brought to the forefront as well. A fascinating, unputdownable read I highly recommend.Thank you Celadon Books for the physical ARC in exchange for an honest review.

3.5 stars‚Äî- I just finished ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù by Jean Hanff Korelitz, and I can‚Äôt remember having a more mixed reaction to a novel. The book centers around a novelist, Jacob Bonner, who writes a book using the plot of another author‚Äôs novel, who died before he was able to have his book published. When the book becomes an immediate best seller, the author does an outstanding job conveying the dread and worry that Jacob lives with in fear that he will be discovered as a fraud and thief. The book hits some very rough patches as another mystery unfolds which could destroy Jacob‚Äôs professional life. Jacob‚Äôs luck running into random people in hugely populated towns that know exactly the information he needs to further his investigation is second to no other book I have ever read. Also, the author‚Äôs description of the plot of the book that Jacob wrote is supposed to be so amazing and original that the book becomes an instant bestseller; it definitely does not rise to that level in the book excerpts the author includes in ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù. However, even with these and other problems, the book kept me interested throughout and even finished with some very nice unexpected plot twists that made ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù an enjoyable read that I would definitely recommend.

I‚Äôm glad other reviewers warned this book gets off to a slow start. Had I not known that ahead of time I might have given up. After 50 pages or so the story really hits its stride and ended up being a fun read.After Jacob Finch Bonner published his first book it garnered some praise. His second book failed to draw any attention. To his utter dismay, he's stuck teaching in a MFA program in order to pay the bills. One of his students, Evan Parker, fits the definition of arrogant but surprisingly he came with an extraordinary plot for a novel. Jacob knows when the book is published it will set the world on fire and become a bestseller. Years later, Jacob wonders why Evan's surefire hit was never published and that's when he learns Evan died awhile back. Hmm... it'd be a shame for Evan's incredible story to go to waste...What I loved about this book, The Plot, is how the author created a tension filled thriller involving the publishing world of all things. It was an edge of your seat type read and given it revolves around writing, I just don't think it is a small feat to be able to pull that off. It was unconventional and creative and I was amazed I was able to maintain such a high interest level in the story once the ball got rolling.Now, the ending didn't exactly pack as strong of a punch for me because I had pieced together a few things ahead of time. I'm not going to give myself a pat on the back though because a lightbulb went off in my head for one thing literally a few pages before it was revealed in the story. And the ending does go in a direction that I did find surprising. Thank you Celadon Books for sending me an advance copy! All thoughts expressed are my honest opinion.

A Vegan MealI like Korelitz. She‚Äôs got style and skill and imagination. All of those are here. But I don‚Äôt like the meal. There‚Äôs no meat. ***HAPPY PUBLICATION DAY***Like the book talked about in this novel, I think this will be a well read and much talked about book this Spring. I found the writing to be very good in spite of the slow beginning. It took a while to set up the foundation for what was to unfold. I did not find it to be ‚Äúbreathtakingly suspenseful‚Äù as the blurb suggests, it‚Äôs much more of a slow buildup.Jacob Bonner is a 40 ish writer who had a one time promising career. He wrote a novel that did quite well but then his second novel didn‚Äôt take off and the third novel, well he couldn‚Äôt even find a publisher that would take it.Jacob finds himself teaching a creative writing class at a 3rd rate MFA program in Vermont. We join him as he is getting ready to greet the next class of prospective writers and he isn‚Äôt very enthused about it.Then he reads a few pages of Evan Parker‚Äôs submission. It is clever and the plot is really something he has never read before. He has some further discussion with Evan about what will unfold next in the story. Evan is narcissistic, doesn‚Äôt accept suggestions or criticisms. He knows that this novel will be a huge hit. But Evan never finishes the manuscript as far as Jacob knows. He actually disappears from campus and Jacob doesn‚Äôt know where he has gone or what he has done. Jacob kept waiting for this novel to surface but it never does. Jacob actually struggles with the thought of writing a novel with this plot. Who actually owns an idea? He justifies his use of the plot because he believes that ‚Äúif you did not do right by the great story that had chosen you, among all possible writers, to bring it to life, that great story didn‚Äôt just leave you to spin your stupid and ineffectual wheels. It actually WENT TO SOMEBODY ELSE. A great story wanted to be told . . . AND IF YOU WEREN‚ÄôT GOING TO DO THAT, it was OUT OF HERE, it was going to find SOMEBODY ELSE WHO WOULD!The less you know about what unfolds the more you will ENJOY the story. I use that word a bit loosely because THE PLOT itself portrays the story of a woman who is inherently EVIL, with no moral compass or thought of anything except what she wants!!I was thankful to read this novel with DeAnn and Jayme who helped me get past the first half!This novel is set to publish on May 11, 2021I received an ARC of this novel from the publisher through Edelweiss.

I entered several drawings, hoping to win the opportunity to review an ARC of this book. Alas I was never selected. Flash forward many months and it‚Äôs finally available at the library where I got my hands on it as soon as I possibly could‚Äî and boy am I glad I did! ‚ÄúThose who can, do. Those who can‚Äôt, teach‚Äú. Jacob Finch Bonner (Jake) is a professor of writing at a local university. Many years ago, Jake wrote his own fiction book, but it was a big flop! One of his students is boasting that he has the best plot ever ‚Äì no writer could mess up the retelling of this story! Years go by and Jake starts wondering about the student, Evan Parker, and if he ever published his book. During his detective work Jake finds out that Evan died before he could publish his book. So naturally Jake goes ahead and writes The Crib, which is based on Evans plot. And it‚Äôs a hit! But someone going by the username ‚Äòtalented Tom‚Äô knows the plot to Jake‚Äôs latest book was stolen. But can you copyright a plot? What does talented Tom know? This book has tons of twists and turns with surprises until the very last page. There are enough clues to figure out the ending ‚Äì if you‚Äôre carefully paying attention. All the characters are well written and there‚Äôs not a bunch of unnecessary fluff to it definitely one of the best summer reads of 2021.

"Life is about using the whole box of crayons." (RuPaul)You don't always have to stay within the lines. If the box has your name on it, do you own each one separately? Better yet, do you actually have the rights to all the various hues contained within? Well, does anyone?A perplexing thought in regard to what is ours in life. Do we have complete ownership of our thoughts or do we loosely leave them along the wayside in conversations and discussions where they can be snatched up and pocketed by others?Jacob "Jake" Finch Bonner is facing such a dilemma. Jake is teaching Creative Writing at the Ripley Symposia in northern Vermont. His claim to fame is a one-hit-wonder novel from some time back. As the years pass by, so do the accolades. Standing in his doorway is one of his students, Evan Parker. Evan is filled with himself and filled with an abrasive personality. He claims to have the all and end-all plot for a bestseller. Jake leans in, but he's met with "Anyone can write" by the rude Evan. And yet Evan's attempts at writing are limited, but oh, how Jake remembers the crusty elements of his idea. Evan never completes the assignment.Years later, Jake has presented a new bestseller entitled Crib. He's sought after for book tours and even Steven Spielberg has obtained the movie rights. Although every word is his....."ideas" may be counted on like low hanging fruit. Perhaps like Eve's tango with the ol' apple. And as of late, Jake begins to receive emails from a mysterious "Talented Tom" accusing him of thievery. Jake is hesitant, but he informs his publisher and agent. Jean Hanff Korelitz provides us with an interesting dialogue in regard to literary property. Both legal and the publisher seem to scoff at the assertions. Jake is not so sure.....The Plot will take us on a road trip initiated by Jake in the hope of revealing the accuser. Prepare yourself for a bit of dryness in the opening chapters which convey a bit of stiffness surrounding the publishing world and novels in progress. It's this road trip that will reveal Jake's inner turmoil over his good name and reputation as a writer. "Talented Tom" will be sucking all the oxygen out of the room from here on out. We'll be brainstorming along with Jake. Jean Hanff Korelitz does a fine job of showcasing her main character of Jake and all the backstories involved. The storyline is a clever one and the tension heightens all the way to the finale. Even if you see it coming, you'll just sit back and absorb all the craziness of it. Seriously, it wouldn't be too far-fetched if the real Steven Spielberg would pick this one up. I'm smelling popcorn already.I received a copy of The Plot through NetGalley for an honest review. My thanks to Celadon Books and to Jean Hanff Korelitz for the opportunity.

I think it was Twain who said ‚Äòwrite what you know‚Äô, and quite a few writers appear to take that advice literally and write about, well, writing. And I don‚Äôt mind that, I like the idea that I‚Äôm somehow getting a glimpse inside a writer‚Äôs head, that I‚Äôve been granted an opportunity to unpick the craft in some minor way. In this story, the author introduces us to Jacob Finch Bonner, a man who‚Äôs wanted nothing else than to be a successful writer for as long as he can remember. He‚Äôs had some success too, with his first book receiving quite a bit of critical acclaim even though sales were only modest. But his follow-up books failed miserably and as a result he‚Äôs now he‚Äôs taken up a job teaching an MFA course at third-rate school, just to make ends meet for a while. But then he gets lucky.The luck involves his coming across a brilliant, can‚Äôt fail plot for a book, courtesy of one of his students. But it‚Äôs not his plot, is it possible that he can steal this idea and run with it himself? There‚Äôs a lot more to this conundrum, of course, but I‚Äôm not looking to share any of that here. Suffice to say that Bonner wrestles with this dilemma and the choice he makes shapes how his future is to play out. It‚Äôs a well-crafted and suspenseful thriller that definitely had me hooked from early on. I liked the way that Bonner was brought to life, even though I‚Äôm not sure that I actually liked the man very much: most of the time he comes across as a self-obsessed loner who really has little time for anyone else.My main issue with the book is that I worked out the key twists to come about two thirds of the way in, something I rarely do. I didn‚Äôt know exactly how it was going to play out but I had the bones of in my head from that point. This somewhat took the edge off the remainder for me as I started to spot what I saw to be confirmations of my predicted route. However, despite this there was still enough mystery left in the detail to hold my interest and, in truth, there was at least one significant element I that hadn‚Äôt foreseen that definitely startled me. When I try to analyse whether this could play out in real life I conclude that there are just too many elements that I believe would have derailed the whole thing along the way - but as a piece of entertainment it did have a lot to offer. I enjoyed it and I think a lot of other readers will too.My thanks to Faber & Faber and NetGalley for providing a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

Review also published on blog: https://books-are-a-girls-best-friend...What happens When You Borrow or Rather-A-Hem Steal Something You So Desperately Want? In the case of Jacob Finch Bonner, his decision to steal ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù becomes quite dangerous.If only he looked before he leaped! Then again, no one ever does.Jacob Finch Bonner is an instructor at an MFA program. Once a somewhat successful novelist, now he‚Äôs kind of a has-been. To make matters worse, one of the students in his class is an arrogant jerk who claims to be writing what will become a bestseller. Though he‚Äôs only been given a few of the details, Jacob waits with bated breath for its release. Years go by and it never materializes. Then one day Jacob researches Evan Parker, his former student, and discovers that and realizes that the book won‚Äôt be published after all, and he decides to write the book himself. Upon doing so, Jacob and his new book ‚ÄúCrib‚Äù are a huge success and all seems swell until he receives threats from someone who knows the truth. Someone who threatens to destroy everything Jacob has worked for. Something Jacob has no intention of letting happen.Though the first half of this novel starts off extremely slow and therefore took a lot for me to get into, the pace and the storyline picks up around the halfway point. Though I guessed the culprit fairly early on and knew what was going to happen, I still enjoyed the ending and think everyone else will too.3.35 StarsI received a free Galley of The Plot from Celadon Books and a free ARC of THE PLOT from Macmillan in exchange for an honest review.Published on Goodreads, Twitter, and Insta.

For Jacob Finch Bonner, life was good. He was an acclaimed first-time novelist, basking in its glory for a while and eager to follow it up with another winner. However, his second attempt doesn't go well and he finds himself in the land of floundering, looking for that theme that magical something that will take his newest novel into Olympian heights. Jake is teaching a joy he initially likes but after some years finds himself bored and stumbling. His writing life seemed to have hit that old brick wall and every day is just like the one preceding it.Into his creative writing class, comes Evan Parker, an arrogant imperious man, so convinced the plot of his book is one that will zoom him up to number one in the writing world. He allows Jake to read a few pages of his story and Jake acknowledges this impudent man cocky and pompous has a sure to be winner on his hands. Jealousy sets in as he waits for this book to be published and his novel to be eclipsed. However, that evet never happens and Jake is perplexed and beyond curious. He finally learns that Even Parker has died presumable from a drug overdoses and since there no family well the temptation to "borrow" the deceased plot idea takes root.As Jake's new book storms onto the best seller lists of many publications, he meets a woman who eventually becomes his wife, but then an email arrives accusing him of plagiarizing the book and Jake's trip into the nightmare zone starts. The email missives keep coming and eventually they go to his publisher and are posted on social media. Jake is terrified and decides its time to delve into Evan Parker's background and the surprises keep coming.Although this book has quite a slow start, it builds momentum as we journey along to puzzle out the details of deception and lies. At times, it is a bit of a puzzlement why Jake takes this so seriously as he just seems to have taken the plot but written the story himself, and yet he does. As he delves deeper into the actual Evan Parker, he finds that as the old adage goes, life imitates art this time with dire consequences.Thank you to Jean Hanff Korelita, Celadon Books, and NetGalley for copy of this interesting story. Jan and I enjoyed this story that did seems to pull us in after a slow beginning. We were intrigued by Jake and his seemingly unsure about his own innate ability. He was definitely the polar opposite of Evan Parker, his future student. We also talked about in this time of so much controversy, who exactly is "permitted" to tell a story? As the author aptly points out if only those who experience a story can write about it, our book shelves would be bereft of books.

I‚Äôve read one book per week over the last four years, and I can safely say that this is one of the worst books I‚Äôve ever read. Before I get into specific complaints (and spoilers), I first just want to beg you not to waste any time, energy, or money on this book. Trust me, it‚Äôs not worth it. It‚Äôs not even interesting in how bad it is. It‚Äôs a thoroughly bland and underwhelming book.***SPOILERS AHEAD***1) To start with the most obvious point, the story hinges on believing that the titular plot idea is in some way revolutionary and inherently engrossing, when in fact, it is actually completely uninteresting and unoriginal. Here is the totality of the plot idea: A jealous mother kills her daughter and assumes her identity. As if that hasn‚Äôt been the basis of a dozen expendable, interchangeable thriller novels.2) The book occasionally has opportunities to actually cultivate thematic depth, but it basically ignores all of those chances. For example, Jacob‚Äôs sudden success as an author provides fertile ground for exploring the nature of fame and the hollowness of desires for notoriety, money, etc. However, the novel mostly evades all interesting or meaningful questions, instead focusing on hollow, formulaic plot points. I‚Äôm not saying that mystery books and thrillers can‚Äôt be thematically rich. On the contrary, some of the best novels ever written are in those genres. But this novel is not interested in actually attempting to say anything.3) The twist of Anna‚Äôs true identity is thuddingly obvious. Anna‚Äôs entrance into the story is extremely ham-handed, and pretty much all of her words and actions might as well be big neon signs that say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the bad guy!‚Äù Unfortunately, it‚Äôs clear that her identity is meant to remain a surprise until the final chapters, but it most definitely is not. This twist has also been done so many times before, and in much better ways. The book even references another book (Gone Girl) that has a similar twist, and which employs the twist in a much more effective and original way.4) The slow revelation of the titular plot serves only to hide information from the reader and to cover up plot holes in the novel itself. For example, as soon as Jacob realizes that Evan based his plot on real life, Jacob should have logically concluded that Dianna killed Rose and took her place.5) The characters in the novel are all very one-dimensional. Additionally, Jacob‚Äôs characterization sometimes changes dramatically, simply to fit various plot conveniences. For example, Jacob is generally portrayed as a bland, bumbling, everyman-type character, but in one scene, he instantly becomes a master at manipulating other people. (It‚Äôs the scene with the Georgia lawyer. To make matters worse, this scene is pretty much completely unnecessary.)6) If given any thought whatsoever, the success of Anna‚Äôs evil plan after the publication of Crib is incredibly improbable, far beyond suspension of disbelief. For example, it hinges on her successfully seducing Jacob and manipulating him into marrying her very quickly, without ever raising his suspicions. Her plan only works because the plot requires it to, and because Jacob is not a character, but rather just an engine for the plot (like every other character in the book.)7) Here‚Äôs something that‚Äôs admittedly a nitpick, but it‚Äôs representative of some of the carelessness that‚Äôs evident in the book‚Äôs overall construction. There‚Äôs a character introduced near the beginning who seems like she might be important, but she never reappears after the scene in which she‚Äôs introduced. I‚Äôm not sure she even has a name. She‚Äôs a new faculty member at Ripley, and she even seems to flirt with Jacob a little. She has no evident purpose in terms of plot, theme, characterization, or anything else. And then she just disappears from the story as quickly as she appeared.8) The last third of the book is mostly comprised of a boring slog of generally empty and uninteresting conversations between flat characters. These scenes add nothing to the book other than to stand in for Jacob‚Äôs ‚Äúinvestigation‚Äù of the mystery. The story dispenses clues at random to occasionally advance the plot.There‚Äôs more, but the above points cover most of it. I lastly just want to reiterate my point that the experience of reading this book is in no way interesting or satisfying. Not even in a so-bad-it‚Äôs-good kind of way. The relative popularity of this book is frankly kind of distressing. I‚Äôm genuinely sad that this is apparently what people want to read. I can only hope that people are reading this book because they were suckered in by good marketing, and that they‚Äôll soon realize they were sold a false bill of goods. Moreover, when/if this book is adapted into a movie (as the author and publisher so clearly hope) then the wider public will have a chance to step in and say, ‚ÄúHey, this is terrible.‚Äù (See also: The Girl on the Train.) At the very least, this book gave me an opportunity to exercise my critique muscles. And surely whatever book I read next will seem like a masterpiece by comparison.

‚ÄòAnyone can be a writer‚Äô, so says a supremely arrogant and abrasive student of Jacob Finch Bonner, a once promising author now struggling to maintain that early potential with his career in free fall. He‚Äôs now teaching writers courses at Ripley Campus in Vermont where the obnoxious young man reluctantly shares his plot with him and Jacob knows, he just knows it in his bones, that it is amazing. This is a book about a book ..... and I imagine we can all work out where this is heading!! Yes indeed, plagiarism. This is an extremely well written and cohesive novel which starts slowly but picks up momentum and you find yourself totally immersed. Jacob is clearly a clever individual and although he‚Äôs likeable, he doesn‚Äôt have a huge personality but this may very well be the entire point the author intends. His feelings of guilt and the terror of discovery with the fear of being unmasked are well conveyed and oddly, you root for him! As threats come from an unknown source he is dogged in his research and pursuit of the truth which is beyond his wildest imagination. Whilst I do figure out who the masterful manipulator is fairly early on, this in no way detracts from the enjoyment of this skilfully written plot. What plays out becomes a really deadly game and Jake is most certainly being toyed with like the proverbial cat with a mouse. I love the chapter headings which are clever and excerpts from Jacob‚Äôs book, ‚ÄòCrib‚Äô. The ending is excellent and very entertaining and you read with baited breath. Overall, this is well worth sticking as after the slow start it becomes a rewarding reading experience. It‚Äôs a clever psychological thriller from a talented writer. Recommended to fans of the genre. With thanks to NetGalley and especially to Faber and Faber for the much appreciated arc in return for an honest review.

3.5 starsI liked this book, but it did take me a very long time to get into it. I kept putting it down and doing other things and then reluctantly picking it back up. About halfway through it definitely gets better and picks up steam and so I read the second half much more quickly.There really aren't any likable characters in this book, but that was honestly all right in the context of this novel. And how many details could Evan really have told him to make them so similar?) and how he goes off on an armchair detective pursuit of the person who is making the accusations. I did figure out a couple of the twists ahead of time, but overall the plot of The Plot (ha) is pretty intriguing and entertaining.As an aside, I didn't find Jake's book and the storyline (can't keep saying plot over and over again) to be that "shocking" and "stunning". Jake's enjoying wealth, fame, and worldwide success. It's all due to his release of Crib, his latest book. His author dreams have finally come true ... he'll soon regret it.His latest book is based on the plot of someone else's story. Lucky for Jake, that author died before publishing his story. Jake has nothing to worry about since no one knows his secret, right? Sure, until he starts receiving messages from TalentedTom, letting him know he's not the only keeper of that secret.This is an interesting story, but I didn't find it to be much a thriller. The reader can figure out who TalentedTom is early on, but Jake doesn't. The point of the story, then, is to follow Jake's ordeal as he tries to figure out who TalentedTom is. All while the threatening messages continue and escalate.Was this an unputdownable story? Not exactly. At first I wasn't even sure I'd like it. The story starts out very slow, but fortunately picks up momentum. Overall, it's an engaging story and the book-within-a-book aspect is clever.

ATTENTION PLEASEBy the end of this review I will tell you my unique idea for the best review ever, a review that will get ONE MILLION likes at least, that will get picked up by the news, be read by every. single. goodreads member. Stay tuned. Now onto the scheduled review. The Plot is about a failed writer turned sadsack tutor. One day, one of his students reveals the plot of the novel he's currently working on to him. This plot, being withheld from the reader at this time, is made out to be so incredible, so genius, never having been told before, that the student as well as the protagonist are convinced that it is a "sure thing", sure to be a bestseller, the one book everyone and their illiterate uncle will read. The protagonist goes as far as to proclaim that anyone could write that book and be successful, no matter how bad of a writer they are. Surprising to no one, the student dies and our protagonist steals The Plot. Everything turns out as predicted; the book is a mega-hit, the protagonist gets propelled into superstardom. Bit by bit we get to read passages of the best plot to ever have plotted. Spoiler-town below, enter at your own risk And the incredibly amazing guaranteed bestseller plot isdrumroll pleaseA mother kills her daughter and assumes her identity.That's it. Yup. That's the never-done-before twist of the century. Something no one has even remotely thought of. I shouldn't have been disappointed. I mean, had Korelitz actually thought of a super duper amazing story, she would've just written that instead. Do you see how this book doesn't work in and of itself?And then there was the so-called twist I had seen coming from the time a certain character was introduced. The whole book was like a box of chocolates: building unrealistic expectations and then leaving me disappointed and slightly disgusted once I had finished it. Anyway, back to my great review idea: get this, I'll write a review that imitates the style of the book. Genius, right? So original, right? ... right?

4 book world starsWe meet Jacob Finch Bonner languishing as a teacher in a struggling writing program. He had a breakout successful book years ago and can‚Äôt seem to capture the magic with anything else new that he‚Äôs written.In this particular class, there‚Äôs an arrogant student who doesn‚Äôt think he can learn anything from the program and he‚Äôs already got the perfect plot for a blockbuster book. During a private session, he shares his plot with Jacob. It does sound like a great plot and years later Jacob decides to track down the student to see if the book was published. It never was and Jacob‚Äôs own writing is still suffering, so he decides he will write this blockbuster book!I always enjoy a book about writing and the publishing world and this one gives us an insider‚Äôs view to just that! It‚Äôs always interesting to read author interviews and have them share where ideas came from. It might be an overheard conversation on the train or at a restaurant or maybe you hear an idea from someone. Is it stealing if that person never writes about it? Make no mistake, if you take something someone else has written and try to pass it off as your own, that is plagiarism. But, can you steal a plot? Are there original ideas left in the world?The first half of this book was a bit slow going, but once Jacob starts getting messages claiming he is a thief, the pace and intensity pick up. We get to read a few sections from the blockbuster book itself and that was a fun element of the book. There were definitely some great twists in this one, a few I guessed, and a few that were surprises. The ending boosted my overall enjoyment of the book!I received a free ARC from Macmillan in an exchange for an honest review.

What a fun and fantastic book!If you write a book called ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù about a story so stellar everyone wants to steal it ‚Äî well, that‚Äôs a pretty good plot, too. I was captivated from the very first page of this book, which is not shy about its homage to the Talented Mr. Ripley. But, there‚Äôs a difference between homage and stealing, right? At least, that‚Äôs what Jacob ‚ÄúFinch‚Äù Bonner, a novelist with only one obscure book under his belt, tells himself when he stumbles upon the plot of a lifetime. But it‚Äôs not his. It‚Äôs a story told to him by one of his writing students, who dies before he can write the book.So, if Jacob just steals the plot, but writes the whole book himself, it‚Äôs not really theft, is it?Fast forward a few years and Jacob is the toast of the town, having written the book with the plot that captured the world‚Äôs attention. But of course, someone knows and is sending threatening missives to expose him. Will Jacob get away with it?I gobbled this book up in 24 hours. Like the plot of the book at its center, it is delicious and shocking and fun. One problem I sometimes have about authors who write about writing ‚Äî they will characterize their characters work as spectacular, and then they‚Äôll present the thing the character supposedly wrote, and it‚Äôs not spectacular. So all along I was worried this magical ‚Äúplot‚Äù that captivated the world would end up being a disappointment. It wasn‚Äôt! It was great, and it was also tempered by Korelitz‚Äôs sense of humor and some fun wordplay. No spoilers - but let‚Äôs just say the title of Jacob‚Äôs fictional book and the book you are reading have something in common! You get to read chapters of Jacob‚Äôs book parallel with the plot of this book, and that is extremely fun and deftly done.For lovers of a good plot (me, please!) - this book delivers. And the writing is good too. I didn‚Äôt realize initially that Korelitz had written the also-great You Should Have Known, but if you know that going into this book, it makes reading about this fictional author even more fun.Big thanks to Celadon Books, Jean Korelitz abd NetGalley. I had nonstop fun with this one! 4.5 stars rounded up for ... two great plots.

4.5/5 STARS!Happy publication day to The Plot! THE PLOT is a beautifully written mystery/thriller that had me guessing almost all the way. Jean Hanff Korelitz is going on my "must read" authors list! Jacob Finch Bonner is struggling as a writer. His first book was a modest success, but in some ways, that makes writing the second more difficult. He's now written a second and a third, but neither one was accepted for publication, so now Jake is teaching at a small college in Vermont. One of his students, Evan Parker, stands out because of his arrogance and attitude. One day in what amounts to a student-teacher conference, Parker tells Jake the plot of the book he wants to write, and Jake finally understands where Parker's arrogance comes from. The plot is AMAZING and will most certainly be a best-seller. Jake moves on, waiting to hear news regarding the publication of Parker's novel, but he never does. A few years later, having heard nothing, Jake searches for Evan Parker and found that he died, never having published a word. What do you think Jake did then? What any writer would do, of course! What happened after that? You'll have to read this to find out! I listened to THE PLOT on audio and at first, I didn't think I'd be able to finish it. Seriously, this book has a very slow start. I didn't care for the narrator at that point either. A few Goodreads friends warned me of the slow start and advised me to try and hang in there because the payoff was *chef's kiss*. I'm glad they warned me and I'm happy to report that they were right. The narrator ended up growing on me quite a bit as more characters and voices were introduced. What I did like, right from the beginning was the author's writing style. The first part of this book is a lot of "telling" and even though I didn't much care for that, I can still respect how well it was written. Once the story gets moving though, the writing really shines and here's the kicker: not only is she telling Jake's story, she's telling the story that Jake wrote, based on Parker's idea. So, there are actually two stories here, with chapters of Jake's book CRIB, intermittently sprinkled throughout. Somehow, Ms. Korelitz manages to do this so that the storylines between the two are correlated and it makes for very fast paced and intriguing chapters.The plot for...well, THE PLOT, is an intricate wonder and I found myself guessing almost to the very, very end. I'd say I guessed correctly around the 70% mark, but I did doubt myself. Around the 90% mark is when I knew I had guessed correctly. I did not see all the twists related to my theory, so even though I did guess the perpetrator, the denouement still held a few surprises. I was not familiar with this author prior to this book, (I thought.) Then I discovered that the HBO series I watched called THE UNDOING was written by her, and that show was a trip! THE PLOT would have been a perfect 5 star read for me, but I deducted half a star for the slow beginning and because I did guess who the bad guy was beforehand. Still, I rounded it up to 5 stars here at Goodreads and I'm pretty sure this book will make my top ten of the year! Highly recommended! *Thanks to MacMillan Audio and NetGalley for the audio download of this book in exchange for my honest feedback. This is it!*

A writer fails to live up to the expectations after his first novel is published, wallows in self-pity and lands a gig to teach writing at an inferior MFA program. Sure, but I‚Äôm a reader not a writer so what do I know. Oh! I know that this is a sure-fire bestseller.

This blurb had everything I wanted in a thriller- I don‚Äôt know what it is but I love the academic or literary setting and a thriller. So to discover a novel about a down-on-his-luck, once-successful author stealing another‚Äôs plot and the consequences that come with this, had me requesting this book immediately. Also the beginning of this book seemed to have lots of exclamation marks for some reason. They were used at points that I didn‚Äôt think were necessary- but I think that‚Äôs just me üòÇüôà I am not a writer but the over-use of exclamation marks at the beginning did keep throwing me off.

Jacob Finch Bonner has published 2 books but no one wanted to publish his later works (and apparently he never heard of self-publishing). ***NO SPOILERS***What‚Äôs considered plagiarism in the literary world? Where does one draw the line? In The Plot, Jean Hanff Korelitz wants to get readers thinking about this, and she does it in the character of Jacob Finch Bonner, a novelist who wrote a hit book in the past only to follow that with a few misses. To make ends meet, Jake is unhappily teaching creative writing, which he doesn‚Äôt believe can actually be taught. When he‚Äôs not teaching, he‚Äôs trying to write a new hit book but is frustratingly stymied by writer‚Äôs block. With a voice that‚Äôs honest and wry, Jake is authentically human. In the opening pages, readers learn that he nurtures bitterness over his circumstances but puts up a serene, satisfied facade. This changes, however, when the story soon fast forwards a few years to show how he‚Äôs finally published that elusive hit and has transformed into someone humbly confident and grateful. But he‚Äôs not allowed to bask in the glow for long thanks to a vengeful someone out there: the sinister ‚ÄúTalentedTom.‚Äù I loved The Plot for its intelligent story told in casual prose and for the character of Jake. As someone who likes dialogue-heavy stories, I appreciated Korelitz‚Äôs fine-tuned ear for dialogue and Jake‚Äôs point of view. I liked the story-within-a-story structure, particularly Korelitz‚Äôs skill in ordering the two stories so they unfold in tandem to reveal important information. I even liked how the title has multiple meanings. However, the book is a little simplistic despite its stand-out complex traits. The cast of major characters is small, making the mystery feel basic. For a mystery, it‚Äôs also just too...taut: It doesn‚Äôt go in exciting winding directions or get itself in a bind. In the course of Jake‚Äôs investigation, helpful clues fall right into his lap, and pieces of the puzzle lock into place too neatly as the story marches toward a twist that becomes predictable several chapters before its reveal. Pacing is very steady and the plotting singularly focused on the mystery, but this book isn't high adrenaline so may feel slow in comparison to numerous other mysteries. The drawbacks aren‚Äôt exasperating, dumb drawbacks, though; they aren‚Äôt deal-breaker drawbacks. The journey to get from beginning to end is still really fun. Even predicting the twist doesn‚Äôt dampen enjoyment because, although significant, the twist isn‚Äôt the be-all, end-all of The Plot. Interest simply shifts to watching Jake himself discover it and then seeing what comes next. This is a page-turning read with its own identity. It isn‚Äôt unique‚Äìvarious iterations of the premise have been done before‚Äìbut it doesn‚Äôt devolve into clich√©, and it‚Äôs different enough to feel fresh. I probably won‚Äôt remember every single detail of the intertwined stories, but I will remember how nice it was to read a mystery with many more strengths than weaknesses.

3.5 stars: ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù by Jean Hanff Korelitz has an interesting premise: is an ‚Äúidea‚Äù for a novel personal property? Can one author appropriate a ‚Äúplot‚Äù idea legally? Korelitz does a great job providing input for both sides. In America, we‚Äôve seen music artists taken to court for stealing another musician‚Äôs music. Some authors have been taken to court for stealing book ideas, but generally the original plot books have been published previously to little fanfare while the alleged ‚Äústealing‚Äù author makes a best-selling novel. In this story, however, there is an idea that is never written by the person with the concept.Jacob Bonner is a struggling author who is a has-been. He wrote one novel that received much press. His following two works were published and were disasters. Jacob is now a professor at a third-rate college working with student writers who want to publish novels. It is there that he meets an unlikable and obnoxious man who claims he has a plot idea that is so fantastic that even a bad writer will make it into a best-selling book, which will eventually become a film. I, as a reader, beg to differ. I don‚Äôt care what the plot is, bad writing will be the death of the novel. But I digress. Years later, Jacob is still teaching and another obnoxious student piques his memory of his previous student. He googles the guy‚Äôs name and discovers the guy died shortly after he was a student. It‚Äôs been years, and no book was written. Jacob uses the plot idea and writes a novel that is loosely similar to the original plot.Of course, the book is a best seller, and Jacob has sold the film rights. He gets trolled by someone claiming he stole the novel, causing Jacob to emotionally unravel.Pieces of Jacob‚Äôs novel which is entitled ‚ÄúCrib‚Äù are included in the novel, dispersed between chapters of Jacob dealing with the stress of writing another novel and the person trolling him. I found the idea of examining what is an author‚Äôs personal property interesting. If an idea is never written, who can claim that the idea was stolen? What if the idea was telling someone else‚Äôs story without their permission? Aren‚Äôt some of the best novels ones that we can relate to because we have seen the situations/characters/plots in true life, making it realistic fiction? Now the part of this story in which Jacob unravels is where it fell apart for me. I easily guessed who the troll was, so I was not surprised. I‚Äôm assuming many felt the same way. Also, Jacob was realistically written until the troll started hounding him. I didn‚Äôt understand or could empathize with his behavior of trying to find out who the troll was. But then, reality can be stranger than fiction.I‚Äôll remember this novel for its exploration of what an author owns, whether ideas are written down or not. This was not a case of plagiarism, as the novel was written by Jacob. Plus, he loosely based it on the idea of someone else, someone who died and never wrote the story. My disappointment was in how easy it was to figure out who was trying to blackmail him.That said, I do recommend it as a fast and interesting read. Plus, this is well written.

SPOILER ZONE!!!Because it's almost impossible to write a review of this book without spoilers, I'm marking this review as completely SPLOILERY. ***STOP READING IF YOU DON'T WANT TO KNOW STUFF!***Now, here's the point: If your entire novel is predicated on a twist that you can't have "spoiled", as this one most definitely is, then you better be damn sure your "twist" is not super duper obvious from, oh, say page 50 on. Because heaven forbid a reader know exactly what you're doing from, oh, say page 50 on, if the ENTIRETY of the remaining book only exists to have this one big twisty moment in the last 10 pages. Because IF that's the case, then said reader will be wondering why they read 300 pages of 'who gives a shit' to get to the last 10 pages in which, yes, there it is, the big twist that we saw coming from 250 pages back.Look, I'm not saying "twist" books don't have merit if you know what's coming. The journey, often, is more important or as important as the ending. BUT, if your journey does nothing but tease the big twist at the end, and in itself has no interest or entertainment value or merit, than you need to understand it's going to annoy a LOT of readers who see the unbelievably obvious twist you are setting up for 250 pages.I'm sorry if this review is more of a rant, but please understand I spent three days flipping pages, annoyed and bored out of my mind, saying: "please don't do what I know you're going to do, please don't do what I know you're going to do, please don't... GOD DAMN IT."Because THAT means the book was a waste of time.Okay, here's the reality. The first 50 pages are excellent. Tight, intriguing, and actually unexpected. But the rest of the book is supposedly some sly wink of a setup that thinks it's being insanely clever when in fact you and anybody with half a brain will know is leading to only one possibly ending.Spoiler? Yeah, not really.The only thing remotely shocking about this book is that she ended it with a much darker note than even I had anticipated. So maybe that's the twist?Thriller writers, take note: Don't write around the twist. Write a great book. If it has a twist, great. If the twist doesn't work, who cares, because you wrote a great book. But if your ENTIRE book only exists to feed up one small moment that is supposed to blow the reader away and absolutely does not, then please rethink writing the book.Does any of this make sense? Probably not, because I'm annoyed and drunk. But good lord, you guys, find another book to read.This marks a big fat Strike Two on my latest thriller reads (The Maidens was also a waste of time). Which means don't trust the big publicity machines. Go read Laird Barron or S.A. Cosby or Joe Lansdale, somebody who can tell a story that doesn't make your entire experience hinge on one page of GOTCHA that you saw coming from the start. Because there's no point, is there?Not recommended. Ignore the Stephen King blurb on the cover.

This book, to sum it up, was a fantastic read even though the first few chapters were a bit of a slow paced. I liked how informative this book was. The pace picked up when samples of stories were introduced, especially the story titled Crib. The horror of someone knowing the author's secret was a nice push, made me want to turn the pages. This book definitely answered many of my asked and unasked questions about writers, publishers, and readers including reviewers. I'm glad to be informed as an early reviewer.‚Ä©This book followed Jacob aka Jake, a once well-known author, told in the third person point of view as he arrived at his office looking hopeless. His new job was a teaching position, a writer teaching students to become a writer, except he's not motivated to do the job because his own writing career has been receiving rejections after rejections since his first book was published years ago. One student, Evan Parker, had an idea for a story that was self-proclaimed mind blowing and after much persuasion, Evan finally told Jake about it. Jake thought that it will be the best story even though he hated to admit it. Two years later, Jake found himself yet again with a new job, but this time at a small town. There, he met a fellow writer that acted like Evan and the memories about Evan and the book idea returned. He decided to look up Evan and the book but found out Evan died and couldn't find the book had been published. Three years later, Jake published a book with the idea he stole from his student, Evan. He became wildly successful as he always imagined but also terrified that someone will find out that the idea wasn't his. The inevitable happened when Jake received an email from an unknown person accusing him of being a thief. This book was divided into four parts where there's a title for each chapter summarizing what's to come.‚Ä©The Plot was well written with a unique idea I have not encountered before. I rarely able to guess who the killer was in thrillers but in this story, I was able to. I enjoyed both stories very much: the book and the story within this book. I was sad for the ending though because I do liked Jake and would prefer him to have a happy ending. The big reveal was great but I was hoping Jake would realize something was amiss sooner. The epilogue was okay only because the character was not my favorite. Overall, this mystery thriller was definitely an interesting read and I do recommend everyone to read it.‚Ä©xoxo, Jasmine at www.howusefulitis.wordpress.com for more details Many thanks to Celadon Books for sending me a copy of The Plot in exchange for an honest review. Please be assured that my opinions are honest.

I really don‚Äôt understand why this book is getting so much attention.Breathtakingly suspenseful? No - the first 1/3 of the book drags with the protagonist first feeling sorry for himself for not having the career he had wanted, then feeling sorry for himself for not knowing how to deal with so much success.Such an annoying protagonist. I just wanted to feel him ‚Äúoh shut up‚Äù or ‚ÄúI know, I know, you told me that a million times already‚Äù. I wish I hadn‚Äôt bought this one.

I finished last night and when I woke up this morning thinking about it, I realized I need some time to consider what to say in my review and not spoil it. I think the problem is that I read many mysteries and I figured this out too soon also, there was one thing I just didn't buy (okay, I'll spoil this one: a plot so perfect poor writing can't ruin it), one situation that is never explained and some of the ending that the more hours after I've read it elapses, the more I'm like "I know you said it's like that... but is it though?". Jake Finch Bonner had a mildly successful book, but after that his career stalled and he ended up teaching writing seminars at a small unknown university. This is where he meets Evan, a pompous writer who claims to have a once in a lifetime plot that is sure to be a hit. When Jake realizes the reason Evan never published the novel, he does and it becomes a best seller. Someone knows that Jake stole the plot and threatens to expose him. Perhaps my expectations were a bit lofty for this one. I was drawn to the book within a book premise, and overall I thought it was well done. It started off good for me, but then unraveled a bit. In my opinion, the plot was not all that original and definitely didn‚Äôt live up to Evan‚Äôs claims. Secondly, I am probably one of the worst detectives ever despite all of the mysteries and thrillers I read and yet I was easily able to figure out where this was going and even guessed the mystery person. Lastly, the manner in which everything came out in the end is one of my least favorites and felt very abrupt. Overall, 3.5 stars because I did mostly enjoy it and it kept me entertained.

This author it masterful at writing around voids. Internal voids and plot voids both. Her style pulls the narrative to intensity pitch after a slow and wordy/erudite start which is highly deceiving both in category (mystery/whodunit) and pace. Yet the carved and nervous tenseness arrives much earlier full strength than in other novels or works of this sort. Here she nails attitude, IQ brilliance of overlook, and essential parts of their emotional cognition to a 5 star degree in at least 4 characters. This is a supremely dark book. Let me warn first. Much darker than the first 60 pages would lead you to warrant.There is a skill here with character plummeting that translates to visuals too here- this novel will most probably be made a movie. Or even a short limited series. I would not be at all surprised.I read this over a period of about a week (that is much slower than usual) as it was busy planting time. But it gave my little grey cells time to posit about it while doing physical work. Regardless, I had a HUGE inkling by page 122-126 how this was. The who for sure and the where and how less sure. But I was right about 2 out of 3 of those prior and "missing" aspects. So the last parts of this book were not as loaded with shock value to me as it seems they were to others. Being old, and reading too much? Well, when an author spends so much (too much) time on certain descriptions of ambiance or nuance or physical appearance to make sense? It's a red flag (nearly a red herring in reverse) for me. What is that trying to obscure?This could easily be given a 5 star rating. The writing prose forms and switch features to another "book novel copy" are not too frequent or confusing of pronouns either. Like a talented illusionist performing for the staring audience, the eye or mind or emotion are diverted here repeatedly. It's done well.The author also put in a few cheap shots that were beneath her and this body of work. Not just to the politico but to the "writing about writing" teach and do skills. It also rather detracted from Jake's personality analysis / background/ mindset, IMHO. But that's the times we live in. They are tawdry.Only read this book if you can tolerate Godless, insipid, faithless to mankind on the whole souls. Jacob (Jake) Finch Bonner is a writer and published novelist whose first book reached critical acclaim but not the commercial success he‚Äôd dreamed about. His second book didn‚Äôt reach the level of the first and so he began teaching in an MFA program at Vermont‚Äôs Ripley College that even he knew wasn‚Äôt highly regarded. Jake was also struggling the past few years to find inspiration for his next book when one of his students, an arrogant and narcissistic young man named Evan Parker, declares he doesn‚Äôt need his or anyone‚Äôs help because the plot of his book is so compelling, it will become an immediate bestseller on its own. Evan won‚Äôt share more than a couple of pages with Jake but it‚Äôs enough that he becomes highly intrigued with the beginnings of the plot. A few years later, another student with Evan‚Äôs personality traits triggers Jake‚Äôs memory and he searches to see if that much touted story ever got published. When he discovers that Evan died a few weeks after he left Ripley, Jake ultimately convinces himself that he can pursue writing the story himself. It does become that predicted commercial and financial success and Jake's name is right up there with the well known authors of the day. But as he‚Äôs enjoying all that comes with fame and critical acclaim, he receives the first of many messages to come from an anonymous sender called ‚ÄúTalented Tom‚Äù who simply states, ‚Äúyou are a thief.‚Äù Jake‚Äôs private search sends him on a journey into Evan Parker‚Äôs past that produces astonishing results. Let me first warn you that this story requires your patience as it takes some time to develop but there is a payoff for your efforts. When it finally takes a turn to the point where it‚Äôs hard to stop reading (or in my case, listening), the foundation that was created provides that insight into the characters you‚Äôll need to keep up. To make matters more interesting, the story transitions between Jake‚Äôs present day movements and excerpts of his book. Those transitions were well crafted as they become more meaningful as Jake delves deeper into Evan‚Äôs life. But the most compelling aspect of the story is the question it raises about the ownership of an idea. Jake had only a fragment of Evan‚Äôs story premise but was it enough to be considered a theft of someone else‚Äôs story? You‚Äôll be left to decide that for yourself. I listened to the story and it took me a moment to adjust to the narrator because he was so low key. But, after a bit I realized he was just being Jake who consumes most of the beginning of the book and he did that very well. When other characters emerged, there was quite a distinction. I‚Äôm really glad I chose to listen versus read because he helped build the excitement and intrigue, especially that twisty ending. I also have to admit to having guessed the surprise revelation but not the ending. I enjoyed this slow burn novel with the provocative proposition about what constitutes theft in the writing arena. You‚Äôll have to consider decide for yourself. And, the journey to get there was delicious.Posted on Blue Mood Caf√©(Thanks to NetGalley and Macmillan Audio for my complimentary copy. All opinions are my own.)

** Happy Pub Day **This book has got to be the best one I've read that deals with the process of writing, authors and the publishing industry. Although I'm not an aspiring writer, I do free-lance work for a company and have been told too many times to count that I should write a book. As if! Although the main character often says anybody can be a writer, I have read or attempted to read too many books that prove the opposite. Jacob "Jake" Finch Bonner is a writer who met with success by making the "New and Noteworthy" column of the New York Times with his first novel. Unfortunately, his second and third attempts were not as successful so he turned to teaching at a third-rate MFA program. One of his students, Evan Parker, an arrogant jerk, has a self-proclaimed "sure thing" whose plot he shares with Jake. Jake agrees it's a certain hit. As time passes but the book fails to be published, a curious Jake finds out that Evan has died and has left the door open for Jake to appropriate the plot. Life for Jake changes on a dime. His book is everything he thought it would be: number one on the NYT best seller list and movie rights optioned with an A-list director. Life couldn't be better. That is until he receives an e-mail saying he is a thief. The attacks continue to be more specific and more public and set Jake on the path of discovering who is behind these attacks.This is a great suspense thriller. The pacing is good, the story original and the insights into writers and writing are enlightening. I did figure out early on who was behind the attacks, but how the story unfolded kept me reading. Thank you NetGalley and Celadon Books for an Advance Reader's Copy. The publication date is May 11, 2021.

Failed novelist steals a brilliant plot from his now-dead creative writing student. It becomes a huge hit. But then he starts getting threatening messages from someone who's found out. This is well written and absolutely conveyed the nightmarish sense of being stuck in your wrongdoing with no way out. But I couldn't get past two aspects of this. 1) He was always going to get found out. If the student was prepared to tell a creative writing tutor he didn't respect or like his entire plot, you would have to assume he told it to other people. I mean, the hard part is getting unpublished authors *not* to tell you their entire plot. Stealing it was dumb as a box of rocks. (Especially given the premise that it was going to be an Oprah-level mega hit). Of course someone out there would know. I don't know how it works out, I DNFd, so maybe nobody knew and it's actually a crazy person accusing him and his sense of guilt will ironically be what betrays him? But even if that's the case, you would *have* to assume someone else knew.2) The guy *stole someone else's book*. Not an idea, not a title: he stole the whole damn book. He stole a book. I hope his hair catches fire. As such I couldn't feel any sympathy at all for the MC, which pretty much torpedoed my engagement with the story since it's very firmly located in his head, so bailing about 30%. Possibly I'm being extremely grumpy about this. Certainly if you like thrillers with unlikeable protagonists--The Talented Mr Ripley being the obvious parallel--you'll probably love this, but I'm not in that sort of mood.

3.5 stars rounded down.With every book there has to be an outlier review and in this case it my unfortunate duty to be that person. Jacob Finch Bonner is a mediocre writer who had some moderate success with his first book. His second sank into obscurity with barely a ripple and he now finds himself teaching creative writing to a new generation of hopefuls. One of his students, Evan Parker, an obnoxious young man is unwilling to share much of his writing but claims to have an idea for a sure fire plot that cannot fail. Begrudgingly Jake agrees with him when he finally wheedles the plot out of Evan.Jake think nothing more of this but, a couple of years later, is surprised not to find Evan‚Äôs book on the bestseller lists. He does some basic sleuthing and learns that Evan died shortly after attending his (Jake‚Äôs) course. He also learns that there are, apparently, no living relatives. So Jake does the unthinkable and takes Evan‚Äôs plot and crafts it into a book that, yes, makes it onto the bestseller lists. Ok it‚Äôs not his plot but all the words are his. He did write the story. He is still riding the wave of success when he gets the first message from someone calling themselves TalentedTom claiming he is a thief! Jake brushes it off. How can you steal an idea? Aren‚Äôt most plots derivative of something? Didn‚Äôt he write all of the words in the actual book? But as the messages continue and get more threatening he decides to try and track down this TalentedTom and set them to rights. He travels around following the leads and clues. What he finds though is rather disturbing. It‚Äôs not just a plot he has taken - it seems to be someone‚Äôs actual life story. And that someone is not very happy about it!I do agree the story was very well written although in a very flippant style. That‚Äôs fine, I do flippancy myself. It was, however, I thought, quite slow and not particularly riveting. Yes it got a lot more interesting towards the end but by then I had already guessed the twist so again any suspense was lost on me. The way the story was told - a book within a book was well done and Jake‚Äôs character was really well portrayed. He wasn‚Äôt exactly likeable but neither was he unlikeable, I suppose he was like most of us, a mixture of characteristics and just trying to make a living. I could totally imagine him sitting at his keyboard typing away at this amazing story. But that‚Äôs my other problem - I don‚Äôt actually agree that ‚Äòthe plot‚Äô was that exceptional! The idea for the book was very good and I know a lot of people enjoyed it more than I did. I didn‚Äôt NOT enjoy it - I just didn‚Äôt love it but I think the author has a lot of talent and I would totally read another book by her. Thanks to Netgalley and Faber and Faber Ltd. for providing a free copy which I reviewed voluntarily and honestly.

3.5**I will admit right up front‚Äî I never like this kind of trope. The kind where the main character (anti-hero‚Äî maybe) spends all of the book ‚Äúlooking over their shoulder,‚Äù physically or in the case of this mildly suspenseful story, emotionally.Our character is weak and that is no spoiler.
