I almost gave up after the first 50 or so pages - I thought the start of this one was beyond slow, but luckily I had read several reviews warning of the slow start so I knew to keep on, and ultimately I'm glad I did. I'm not sure that this is quite the mind-shattering, jaw-dropping read that is being touted, but it is a clever, twisty, tale of comeuppance that I found very unique and for that alone, it is worth 4 stars. Jacob Finch Bonner, a down-and-out novelist, is teaching in a third-rate MFA program and hasn‚Äôt written anything decent in years. When an arrogant student, Evan Parker/Parker Evan, announces he doesn‚Äôt need Jake‚Äôs help because the plot of his book in progress is a sure thing, Jake is skeptical ... until he hears the plot, and he knows it will be an instant hit. He waits for the publication of Parker‚Äôs book, but it never comes. After doing some digging, he discovers that his former student died, presumably without ever completing his book, Jake does what any self-respecting writer would do with a plot like that‚Äîhe publishes it. In a few short years, Jake has it all - he is wealthy, famous, praised and read all over the world, thanks to Parker's plot idea. But at the height of his fame, an e-mail arrives that says only, "You are a thief." And thus begins the downward spiral of Jake Bonner.This is one that you are best going into rather blind, so I am not going to say too much about the storyline. I'll be honest, I didn't like Jake's character at all - he is pretentious, cold, and rather calculating - but I think that is how Korelitz intended for the reader to feel about him. I can't say as any character really gripped me, but it didn't bother me in the least, as that fits the plot. I loved the glimpse into the writing and academia world that Korelitz offered, and I really liked the chapters that gave snippets into the book Jake stole from Parker. My only real disappointment was that I figured out most of the plot pretty early on ‚Äì one or two things did somewhat surprise me, but I was right about most of it. Still though, it was a crazy ride getting to the very cleverly-done ending. As an aside ‚Äì I always find it interesting when authors reference Goodreads in their plots (talking about poor reviews and checking on how many stars their book has, etc.). I thought Korelitz may have been being a bit patronizing, but overall, it gave me a good laugh! This really is different from your average thriller, and for that I applaud Korelitz. I just wish it had a wee bit more of a ‚Äúwow‚Äù moment, but still a 4-star read all the way!

Sadly I figured out "who did it" about 40% of the way in, but kept reading in desperate hope of being shocked by a surprise twist I wasn't clever enough to see coming. None came.Spoiler: it's exactly who you think it is.

"THE PLOT" was 'NOT" for me.I prefer "insanely readable" and "breathtakingly suspenseful" reads (as promised on the "THE PLOT's book jacket) and THE PLOT was just too slow-burn and laborious for my discerning palate.I felt that the author's premise was compelling: a "has-been" novelist is currently teaching in a third-rate MFA program. The novelist steals an over-the-top story idea from one of his fourth-rate students. The stolen story gets published and the novelist's fame and wealth soar. The novelist's "perfect world" starts to fall apart, however, when he receives an anonymous "I know what you did" email accusing him of stealing the story.It's important to note the novelist wrote his best-selling "stolen story" book in its entirety by himself. I have read many books with very, very, very similar plots and even though I agree that stealing an author's idea for a book does not comply with "best practices" and is WRONG, it happens all of the time.I listened to the audiobook and perhaps the reason why I was unable to connect with the book's protagonist (and had trouble staying awake when listening!) can be blamed on the book's bland narration by narrator Kirby Heyborne. The book only had one narrator and almost 11 hours of straight book narration did not bode well for this narrator or this listener. I was waiting for a jolt from both the author and/or the narrator, and was left disappointed. (I was actually hoping for several jolts!) I checked Kirby Heyborne's credits and he did a great job with the narration of "GONE GIRL" and 'THE WIFE UPSTAIRS" but in those books, he only narrated portions of those audiobooks and not the entire audio.Author Jean Hanff Korelitz has had great luck with film and television adaptations of her novels and if the author secures a screen deal for THE PLOT, I will definitely be watching!Special thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for providing me with an ARC in exchange for an honest review of the book.
I finished the audiobook in one day. That's how good it is!

Who is the true owner of a story? How much of a story can be used before it becomes someone else‚Äôs?Without question The Plot is one of the best books I‚Äôve read this year. It‚Äôs the perfect sort of character-driven mystery where one decision leads to a snowball effect that soon twists and turns towards a stunningly composed ending. I can‚Äôt say enough wonderful things about this book!As anyone who is deeply invested in the literary world knows, even the mention of scandal surrounding the plot of a book or what inspired it can cause an uproar that can make it hard for a book to recover from. I don‚Äôt want to rehash something that got way too much attention in the media as is, but I can remember just such a scenario happening last year. Two books came out close in time that were on a somewhat obscure historical period and profession, rendering a discussion in the book world that spiraled quickly out of hand over whether one author had essentially taken the other author‚Äôs idea and run with it.Jean Hanff Korelitz‚Äôs novel The Plot is based around a premise that, while different, reminded me of this exact discussion. Because truly, even if someone did hear about something from someone else, who is the owner of an idea?Jacob Finch Bonner is such an interesting character‚Äîneither fully rootable nor fully despisable. This is the hardest sort of character balance to strike, I think, and shows the skill of the author in crafting him. I often wanted things to work out for him, but at the same time I found him to often work against his own best interests and at many points in the book I didn‚Äôt agree with his decisions. And yet‚Ä¶I liked him. I understood him. I even could see myself making some of the same bad decisions in another life and time.Jacob had achieved some acclaim with his first book, though it was more in the niche literary worlds than in the bestseller‚Äôs sense. But his second book and subsequent attempts at a third failed to live up to the momentum his career had with his first. By the time our story begins, Jacob is teaching writing at a third-rate MFA program, at a school that (unlike his own) has neither the reputation nor quality to matter much to most of the staff and students.In the slog of yet another cohort beginning, Jacob meets a rather obnoxious student who declines to share his writing with his class, claiming he has a plot for a book in his head that is so outstanding, it doesn‚Äôt matter if he is a good writer. The book will be a bestseller regardless. Jacob dismisses this bravado until he meets with the student to review his chapter, and the student tells him the plot. And suddenly Jacob realizes he is right. This is the sort of plot that will make this one of the most popular books of its time. The sort of plot that will have movies made off of it, that will have people talking, that will be the pick of every famous book club out there.And how demoralizing to know that it is the idea of someone so distasteful!Several years go by, the program shuts down and Jacob is laid off. He‚Äôs taken a job at a retreat to make ends meet while he tries yet another attempt at his third book. He has almost forgotten about his former student, until by chance he learns that his student passed away not long after the program, without ever having written his book.And suddenly Jacob finds himself in an interesting position. He is now in possession of a brilliant plot, and no one has to know where he got it from. And so he begins writing and sure enough, it is every bit the bestseller he thought it would be‚Ä¶Jacob finds himself living the life he always dreamed of. He is doing interviews, book tours, readings, and getting the acclaim every author aspires for. He meets a woman who he soon falls in love with. He begins working on the international releases of his book. He‚Äôs happy.Until one day an email comes through his author‚Äôs site: You are a thief.And then eventually another comes. And another. Someone knows Jacob stole the plot of his book and is threatening to expose him. If only Jacob can find out who it is first‚Ä¶I loved that chapters from the book were interspersed with Jacob‚Äôs life and the mystery of who is stalking him. I found the way this book was crafted to be so incredibly delicate and elegant, each moment playing into the next. Brilliant!Thank you to Celadon Books for my copy. Opinions are my own.

Writer Jacob Finch Bonner knows the feeling of being a promising author. His first book was cited in the New York Times Book Review‚Äôs ‚ÄúNew & Noteworthy‚Äù section. While it wasn‚Äôt a big seller, he was on his way. And then he wasn‚Äôt. The next book that would finally give him the career he craved never happened. So he teaches a writing course at a small college. He‚Äôs simply passing the time until he meets a student whose confidence intrigues him. Student Evan Parker doesn‚Äôt want his literary help although he‚Äôd like assistance in getting an agent. Evan expresses that the plot of his book is a guaranteed hit. Once Jacob learns more about the plot, he has to agree.Jacob waits and waits for this sure-fire hit to be published but it never comes out. He finds out Evan has died. Jacob decides to take the plot and write the book himself. Plagiarism? Stealing? No way. Jacob convinces himself that there is nothing wrong with writing ‚Äúhis‚Äù book as he is simply taking the idea of the plot and making the book his own. It‚Äôs done all the time, right? Jacob‚Äôs book is a huge success and life is great until he receives an email. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a thief.‚Äù Let the cat and mouse game begin.This enjoyable thriller takes its time at the beginning. We learn more about Jacob and we also get to read excerpts from his bestselling book ‚ÄúCrib‚Äù. We wait to find out what that incredible plot twist is that has made it a must-read book. We learn more about Evan and how he developed his story and his book‚Äôs ‚Äúshocking‚Äù plot, which is now in Jacob‚Äôs book. Will you figure it all out before the end? You might. I did, but it didn‚Äôt ruin it for me. This is my first book from author Jean Hanff Korelitz. I was glued to the HBO series "The Undoing" with Nicole Kidman and Hugh Grant, based on her novel ‚ÄúYou Should Have Known‚Äù and had to read The Plot because of it. I was not disappointed. Many thanks to Celadon Books, NetGalley and the author for the opportunity to read The Plot in advance of its May 11, 2021 publication. I also would like to note that the publisher encouraged those with early copies to donate them to one of the many ‚ÄúLittle Free Libraries‚Äù across the U.S. to pass them forward. Great effort.Rated 4.5 stars.Review posted on MicheleReader.com.

This was a fun thriller/mystery set in the world of writers and publishing. Which was the story itself.""In his experience, poets often read fiction, but fiction writers who said they read poetry with any regularity were liars...""One thing we do know is that writers have always helped other writers, whether or not they're in a formal program together. 4.5 starsTwo years ago, I had read Jean Hanff Korelitz‚Äôs previous novel 
You Should Have Known
 (which is now famously known as the book that the HBO series ‚ÄúThe Undoing‚Äù was adapted from) and while I liked the story overall, I remember how tedious of a read it was for me, mostly because the story meandered quite a bit and went off on various different tangents that didn‚Äôt seem to have a whole lot to do with the plot. And the book was long (400+ pages) ‚Äî which normally wouldn‚Äôt matter, except that the story was written in such a convoluted way that, by the time I got to the end, I was just glad it was over.Given the above experience, it shouldn‚Äôt come as a surprise that I went into Korelitz‚Äôs newest book 
The Plot
 with a bit of trepidation, despite the fact that, as soon as I had read the book‚Äôs premise, I had immediately wanted to read it. My concerns didn‚Äôt go away even after starting the book, as the story progressed really slowly for the first 50 pages or so ‚Äî not only that, I also started noticing some of the long, meandering, overly-descriptive passages that had irked me in her previous book. But I stuck with it and am so glad I did, as this ended up being such a wonderful read! The story centers around a writer named Jacob Finch Bonner, a once successful author of a bestseller who hit a snag with his second book and is now struggling to move his career forward. While teaching at a low residency MFA program, Jake encounters a student, Evan Parker, who shares with him the plot of a story he plans on writing that he believes will be ‚Äúa sure thing.‚Äù Several years later, as Jake still struggles with his writing and has just about given up all hopes of reviving his career, he inadvertently finds out that Evan Parker has died, supposedly without having finished the ‚Äúsure thing‚Äù novel he had bragged about during the MFA session. At this point, Jake does what he feels any self-respecting writer would do ‚Äî he takes the plot that Evan had told him about and turns it into a widely-read, bestselling novel. Jake instantly becomes famous and also wealthy beyond measure. One day, as he is riding the highs of success in both his personal and professional lives, he receives a mysterious message that contains four terrifying words: ‚ÄúYou are a thief.‚Äù But it doesn‚Äôt stop there ‚Äî as Jake receives more and more threatening messages, to the point that he can‚Äôt ignore them anymore, he sets off on a race against time to find out who his harasser is in the hopes of confronting them before they expose him.As I mentioned earlier, I initially didn‚Äôt have very high expectations going into this book (despite all the hype it has gotten so far) because I thought it would be a convoluted, drawn-out story that would take me longer than preferred to read. But this book turned out to be opposite of what I was expecting ‚Äî not only was it a quick read for me (I finished it in 2 sittings, with majority of the book completed in the second sitting because I just couldn‚Äôt bring myself to put it down), the story was also tightly-plotted and absolutely brilliantly written. Of course, there were still moments throughout the story where certain passages veered into the ‚Äúoverly-descriptive‚Äù category, but not to the extent as her previous book, in my opinion. Having said this, in researching the author and her other works, I‚Äôve come to realize that this is actually her distinctive writing style, which is good to know. In addition to a cleverly-crafted story however, one of the things that makes this book stand out is the way the characters are rendered, especially the main character Jake. As a character, Jake is entirely fictional, however the way his struggles as a writer and the angst he goes through both come across so realistically, it really made the character come alive for me ‚Äî to the point that I found it difficult to figure out where I stood in terms of what he did. Here, Korelitz did a masterful job weaving in recent ‚Äúdiscussions‚Äù about certain aspects of the publishing industry and literary community that have been concerns over the years: issues such as appropriation versus inspiration, who should get to tell what story, the writing process and the trials and tribulations of being a writer, and most interesting of all, an inside glimpse into the publishing world and the role of the writer in that world. Another unique aspect of this book is the way Korelitz utilizes the ‚Äústory within a story‚Äù method to tell Jake‚Äôs story by incorporating excerpts from his book (the one with the ‚Äústolen‚Äù plot) interspersed throughout the story, culminating in a fantastic coming together of the plot to create a ‚Äúfiction vs reality‚Äù twist in the end. I don‚Äôt want to say too much so as not to give away the ending, but I will say that this was one of the most propulsive, surprising endings that I‚Äôve read in awhile.Lastly, I just wanted to comment on why I ended up rating this one 4.5 stars rather than the full 5 stars. The main reason for this is because I actually was able to figure out aspects of the ending early on, which made the ‚Äúbig reveal‚Äù (specifically as it pertained to the person sending the messages to Jake) less impactful ‚Äî though with that said, the last couple scenes were definitely unexpected and very well-done.This literary thriller is definitely a ‚Äúmust-read‚Äù in my book! It‚Äôs clever and creative and even though I did figure out parts of it early on, I still found much of the plot to be unpredictable in terms of the direction things ended up going. Already, this book is getting a lot of buzz, and deservedly so, in my opinion! And I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if this one also gets optioned for a movie or TV series at some point ‚Äî I would definitely be interested in watching if that were to be the case!Received ARC from Celadon Books via NetGalley

This blurb had everything I wanted in a thriller- I don‚Äôt know what it is but I love the academic or literary setting and a thriller. So to discover a novel about a down-on-his-luck, once-successful author stealing another‚Äôs plot and the consequences that come with this, had me requesting this book immediately. Jacob ‚ÄúFinch‚Äù Bonner, a once successful author, is now working at a literary programme on a small college campus. Here he has to read other student-writer hopefuls work (which he hates doing) and giving them tips. When a student arrives called Evan Parker, a self-confident, sort-of-an-asshole, tells Jake about his plot, Jake (and Evan already) knows that this is unique and will become an instant best-seller and success.Switching to a few years later Jake is still in a rut with his writing and life when he remembers this student- what ever happened to him? What happened to his novel? And from there he steals the plot and publishes his own.Bathing in his success, Jake starts getting anonymous emails- someone who knows his secret- and from this point, Jakes mental anguish and trying to discover who this person is consumes his life.It was fascinating to see the investigation Jake does to find the truth of who is threatening him and finding more about his ex-student. As things unravel, Jake learns where the plot originally came from and this investigation I really enjoyed. The author here does well to plot the narcissism of Jake to begin with and the self-frustration at not being able to write a new book and lack of ideas. I would say that this was a slow burning novel (which isn‚Äôt for me) but the novel does pick up around 60% when move things are uncovered and then I wanted to read more.I did unfortunately guess the ending quite early on in the book so there was no sudden ‚Äútwist‚Äù that I usually love from thrillers. Also the beginning of this book seemed to have lots of exclamation marks for some reason. They were used at points that I didn‚Äôt think were necessary- but I think that‚Äôs just me üòÇüôà I am not a writer but the over-use of exclamation marks at the beginning did keep throwing me off. Thank you to NetGalley for sending me this E-ARC.

5 fabulous stars üåüüåüüåüüåüüåüJake is a writer and published author, a one hit wonder of sorts, but maybe more half a hit. He is struggling to come up with a best seller to really make it as an author. While teaching, he meets Evan, a cocky student who exudes confidence and thinks he is a brilliant writer. Evan also has a brilliant idea for a story which he shares with Jake. A real game changer. Years alter and the story still isn't published. Jake finds out the reason, Evan died before he could tell his historyJake sees this as an opportunity to truly make it as an author and turns Evan's idea into his own boom. Except Jake isn't the only one who knew about Evan's story. There is so much to love about this book. The writing was superb. You really get into Jake's head and get to know him, all the good and bad. The story is fantastic. I loved the idea of a book within a book, such a unique way to tell the story. Thank you Celadon Books, MacMillan Audio and NetGalley for both the digital and audio ARC

I loved this book.I got Covid back in January, and have been struggling with daily migraines since then, so my reading time is really limited (and precious!) The Plot was absolutely worthy.It took me a little bit to adjust to the author's writing style, but the story, and the story within the story, were fantastic. Can I get a copy of Crib, please?5 very happy stars

I've seen a lot of hype for this book and whilst I didn't quite love it as some, it was still a fun read.I also think it's quite a difficult one to rate?I liked the whole premise of failed writer Jake completing one of his students (Evan) novels after learning that he had died.The anxiety of 'stealing' a story is an interesting one as Jake is continually concerned of being caught whilst now having that bestseller hit that he's so craved, convincing himself that the story is now in the public just quite justify riding the success!I'm a sucker for books within a book and eagerly enjoyed the excepts from 'Crib' that Jake published.The fact that characters in the book kept referring to it having the most biggest shocking twist did seem to overpromise and felt a little let down by that reveal.The story really picks up once Jake starts to receive claims online by an account named 'Tom Talent' citing him as a thief.This overarching mystery is slightly predictable but does help drive the pace towards a quite satisfying conclusion.I think all the little nods and in jokes to other books and authors was enough to just tip my rating a little higher.

3.5 starsFirst, for such a book that heavily involved publishing houses, I have no idea how such a dreadful cover was chosen. I spent months thinking that's the cover of the arc and not the book itself. The designer could've done a much better job especially since it's a book about a book! A lot of room for creativity but no, let's go with the most direct and ugly way.Next. I honestly liked this book much better than I expected. It was more fun and interesting than I originally thought and that ending was strong!! I have the mental capacity of a goldfish when listening to mystery audiobooks so I don't bother to guess the final twist and it did not even occur to me, not even remotely, how the author will close his story.I also assumed when I read the description that I would hate Jake, he sounds obnoxious. I didn't. Far from it. I was able to understand his PoV and see why he acted the way he did. It's very human. Sure, at the beginning, I didn't appreciate his character at all given the way he treats his teaching job. I wouldn't go as far as saying he's a bad person but the beauty of books is that we can appreaciate those and it's always a plus when their PoV makes sense, not complete BS.The only thing that prevented me from rating this book higher was that the story was slow and it lost me several times before Jake took off on his own personal "quest". I wouldn't go as far as saying it's a thriller because a huge part of it is purely fiction, discussing the characters' inner thoughts, his turmoil, his response to his problems... I did get me bored a bit but overall, it is a good book. Would I recommend it? Well, check GR's summary and if it sounds like something you'd like then sure give it a shot. It's different from the usual mysteries given the time the author delves into the author's inner thoughts and at many points it was mostly character driven rather than plot drive until that explosive ending. The audiobook was also well narrated and I rarely lost focus while listening. Even if I did, I was still able to keep track of the story.

I had a hard time getting into this book from beginning to end. Initially, I thought the book had a good idea but about 30 percent of the way in, I started to lose interest. Maybe that's the time it picked up for many, but I couldn't commit to the plot with "The Plot". Jacob Finch Bonner started off as a pretty great first time author, but he hasn't been able to write a second novel, and can't even think of a slightly interesting plot. To keep himself relevant, Bonner is teaching an MFA course. One of his students, Evan Parker, who is obscenely arrogant feels like he doesn't need Bonner's help and has an amazing plot. When Parker suddenly dies, Bonner takes on his plot and enjoys all the notoriety that comes with it. What happens next consumes Bonner. Someone is on to his stolen novel and want to expose Bonner for stealing Parker's story. I had a hard time dealing with the main character's whinny, annoying, and tiresome failed attempt at becoming someone important again. What ensues after felt too predictable and simplified. This was a laborious read for my semi-important desire for good mystery. I know many others enjoyed it, and I just couldn't commit. I gave it a solid 2.5 stars.

I love the "obsessed artist" archetype, and in The Plot's context: the obsessed author. Jake, his anonymous hunter, and even Evan Parker are all very compelling and complex characters. The writing of the Plot felt very literary when compared to other popular thrillers being released this year. Jake's narrative of his life before "fame" is slow-paced but a great introduction to set the building blocks of an amazing twist. And yes, like the many others in the reviews section, I will also continue to gush over the hugely anticipated twist at the end of the novel. You also get a book inside a book format, sort of similar to Moonflower Murders. The Plot is truly just a bunch of pretty crazy ideas all mashed into one, and it works for me! Korelitz, being an author herself, kept the commentary interesting about some of the highs and lows of being a writer. This is a great book to pull an all-nighter for, the ending was worth the read!

Honestly, I really have nothing to say about this "novel"- partly because I really don't want to waste anymore of my time and energy on poor excuse of a novel. It was boring, drab, stupid, dumb, wordy, pointless, trying too much and ending up achieving nothing, the main character was a clueless moron, so much so that he couldn't find his own arse with a map and a head start, the "twist" was predictable and could be figured out after a few pages, really,there was no suspense as the plot is not only lazy but extremely straight forward and relies on the stupidity of its main character... And my word: THAT FUCKING BULLSHIT ENDING! Seriously?! I'd be glad if there was a way to erase this novel from my mind or get back the hours I wasted on this piece of crap.Can't, and won't recommend this to anyone.

I really enjoyed this one! I subtracted a star because it was a little slow in the beginning. It did, however, speed up towards the end and become unputdownable. This book is easy to figure out early on but it still was an interesting book. It has an intriguing storyline and keeps you engrossed.

This book was so compelling! Jacob Finch Bonner was an author with a great first book, but then his subsequent books didn't do well. He's struggling to write anything good! He is now teaching an MFA writing program. He then meets one of his students Evan Parker, who is bragging about a plot that he has written for a book saying this it's going to be a bestseller, and could even be picked up to be made into a movie.When Jake reads the PLOT, he does agree with how great it is. Well years later Jake thinks about Evan and how he has never heard anything about him or his book. He does some digging and finds out that Evan died a few years ago. So then he has the idea that HE could write the book. So he uses Evans PLOT and becomes a successful author again, and things are looking good in his life. Then one day he gets a message on his site threatening him, and saying he stole "THE PLOT". Who else could possibly know the truth? I don't want to say anything more and ruin it for you, but I loved the mystery behind this one. The book picks up pace the more you get into it, and I really loved the twisted ending. You'll want to add this one to your list!Thank you to the publisher for the gifted copy! All opinions are my own!

The premise of this book is that our hero, Jake, (I picture him as the actor who plays Nate on Succession) is a failed novelist who once had promise. He now teaches at a small writer's program and one of his unruly students tells him the plot of the book he plans to write. Jake is struck with envy and a certainty that this plot is SOOO GOOOD that it'll make literary tsunamis once released. But years later, no book. Evan has passed away. Out of a sense of writerly duty to a good idea, he can't let the story languish, so he writes the book Evan never did. As predicted, it becomes a huge, mega-selling, blockbuster, Oprah Book Club, Spielberg attached to direct, NYT bestselling novel. After it blows up, Jake begins receiving threatening anonymous messages to the tune of "You're a thief" and "I know what you did." Our novel then becomes a mystery to find out who else knew Evan's story and is tormenting Jake about it. Sounds pretty exciting, which is why I picked it up in the first place. Plus, books about books, writers, and author-y stuff are my jam. I loved the inclusion of insider tidbits, writer angst, and name-drops of some of my faves, like Donna Tartt and Stephen King. I was ready for a five star read. But the thing is, Jake is not a plagiarist. He didn't steal a word of Evan‚Äôs writing. He used an unused idea. An idea that wasn't going anywhere or being written by anyone else. This is not thievery. He is not a criminal. If I post online a plot idea for a book and then fail to write the book, someone else just might. And so long as they use none of my actual words, they'd have every right to. You can't copyright ideas. But the threats grow stronger and Jake's publishers make legal noises against the culprit while Jake's freaking out about discovery (as he has been this entire time.) And that's the narrative tension that drives the first 2/3 of the book. I almost fell for it, too. Jake's paranoid about social media outing him, but here's thing: he didn't do anything wrong. If there's one thing we know about Twitter it's that it demands receipts. Without actual screenshots of plagiarism, these accusations are baseless noise. Jake makes a few comments about the duty of a writer to salvage a good story, and that's valid but also completely deflates the entire conflict. The original author is dead and has been dead for years (not a spoiler, that's in the blurb). So there isn't going to be any book. So there's nothing to "steal" here. As a reader, that detracted from the enjoyment. As a writer, the bigger issue was that the plot to the mega bestseller in question here is not only excerpted throughout the book, it's also called every manner of superlatives imaginable. At one point, this plot is even deemed "legendary."For the author to hype it with that kind of language, the plot twist has to be absolutely mind-blowing. Keanu-Reeves-like-whoa. I guessed it pretty easily and while it's a cool idea, it's just that: a pretty cool idea. And that's okay. It can be a cool idea. And while it‚Äôs all good to have confidence in one's work--god knows writers need all the mental boost they can get‚Äîconfidence in the work isn't the same as telling your readers that your plot twist is literally the stuff of legend. I don't like giving negative reviews but my biggest pet peeve in any book I read (or write) is when stuff just plain doesn't make sense. I don't try to pull crap on my readers and I don't like it being pulled on me. As if I will just accept what is tossed my way without much thought. I give much thought. ;) So three stars for an unconventional ending and the writerly goodness at the beginning. I don't deter anyone else from reading it either--many, many others have enjoyed it, and maybe I'm just too darn picky for my own good. I can't just go with the flow. I wish I could; this one might've been a lot more fun.

Jake‚Ä¶oh Jake‚Ä¶what made you think stealing a story was a good idea? What made you think you would never get caught? What made you think you could ever really fully enjoy your success?Jake is a struggling author who has 1 good and 2 not so good books under his belt as this book opens. He has had to pick up odd jobs to afford to continue to live in New York. One of his side hustles is as an advisor at a summer college writing program which touts itself as the program that can turn anyone into an author. While there, Jake meets an unlikely and unlikable author to-be named Evan Parker (or Parker Evan). He is convinced that his idea for a book, his plot is 100% success guaranteed and so he hold his plot close to his chest. In a rare turn of events, he shares his plot with Jake during one of their one-on-one sessions. Jake agrees that the plot is a guaranteed blockbuster, and is pretty miffed that such a jerky kid is the one that holds the idea. Years later, Jake is still struggling as an author, and becoming quite desperate for some measure of success. As he thinks back upon his job as a summer advisor, he remembers his interactions with Evan and wonders what happened with that great idea for a book. Eventually Jake talks himself out of the guilt of stealing a story, and into believing that it is his responsibility to bring this book to life. Jake‚Ä¶ oh Jake.The book follows the trajectory of his life as he finishes the book, finds momentous success, finds love, finds fame, finds fear, finds doubt, finds regret and eventually finds that secrets do indeed bite you in the butt. I am choosing not to give any more information out ‚Äì because this read is better going in mostly blind. For me, the first half of the book drug on a little, but I had been warned of the same. Keep on reading and then bang ‚Äì the second half takes off running and doesn‚Äôt stop until it dives off a cliff. Even though I had a pretty good idea who was behind the anonymous voice about halfway through, it did not detract from my enjoyment in reading this book in the least.THE ENDING IS WORTH THIS READ. Easily recommend.Thank you to NetGalley and Celadon books for the gifted advance copy to read and review.

It looks like I'm in the minority, but I really wasn't a fan of this one. It started out okay, but quickly began to drag. It felt like it took a really long time for Jake to decide to write the book. Then, once he did, the book spent way, way too long with him feeling guilty about writing it. Finally, it starts to pick up about the halfway point. The second half is pretty good, but then the ending pretty much ruined it for me. In another review, I complained about twists coming out of nowhere without any kind of build up or hinting. This book falls at the other end of the spectrum where it gave out too many hints. I knew what every twist was going to be long before it was actually revealed. The only real surprise was the very ending. The author had two ways to end it, and in my opinion, they picked the worst option. Surprise!Probably my biggest complaint, other than the ending, was some of Jake's decision making. He spends way too much time lying when there really wasn't any need to. His argument for why he "stole" the book were enough to convince me that it was okay. Like the book said repeatedly, plots and basic outlines get used over and over, so I didn't see any real issue with it. Evan wasn't alive to write the book anymore. Jake wrote the entire book on his own and just borrowed the plot, so there was no plaigarism. As far as I'm concerned, it passes the sniff test. He could have also done a better job planning. At some point in the second half of the book, he should have realized what he was dealing with and begun to take some precautions. Ulitmately, I think I'd have rather read the novel within the novel, than The Plot. It felt like a more interesting story than the one we ultimately got. I was disappointed that we only got one or two pages at a time. At the least, I'd have liked to see alternating chapters between the Plot and Crib. Might have helped to build the suspense a bit more.

In this addictive psychological thriller‚ÄîI read it quickly without coming up much for air‚ÄîJean Hanff Korelitz sets a high bar for herself.Imagine, she postulates, if an ambitious novelist is struggling to write a follow-up to a reasonably promising debut. And then his narcissistic student at a low-residency MFA program arrogantly shares his own plot, which is a surefire best seller. And then circumstances change and the novelist‚ÄîJake Finch Bonner‚Äîis able to take the framework of the plot and turn it into a success beyond his wildest imagination. And then something happens, and his veracity is about to be exposed.To write a novel like that, you have to deliver the goods. What would this surefire plot be about? For what feels like the longest time, the author withholds it. But when the story comes into focus, it all starts to make sense. And there‚Äôs that a plot twist that I never saw coming (and I think I‚Äôm pretty good at ferreting those plot twists out).But behind the mechanisms of the storyline, Jean Hanff Korelitz‚Äôs theme is appropriation. Who gets to tell a story? Is any plot just an idea until an enterprising novelist grabs hold of it and gives it wings? Are there indeed original plots and if so, doesn‚Äôt it fall upon the writer‚Äôs talent to bring it into the spotlight? Can anyone simply lay claim to an idea?It‚Äôs fun reading‚Äîthe character of Jake, as well as the author, share Macmillan as a publisher and the reader is treated to some behind-the-scenes looks at the writer‚Äôs world and interactions. I‚Äôm giving this a 5-star, not in comparison to all books (that‚Äôs impossible to do) but in comparison to other books of this genre. It really had me going. I received a free ARC of The Plot by Jean Hanff Korelitz from Macmilllan an exchange for an honest review.

The Plot is a fast-paced and highly entertaining mystery/thriller.It centers on Jacob Finch Bonner, a once-promising novelist who suffers from writer's block. Bonner is supplementing his income by teaching in a Vermont-based low residency MFA in creative writing, and here he meets a student who shares his plot idea for a sure-fire hit novel. Three years after the meeting, Bonner learns that the student has died of a drug overdose, and he decides to use his plotline for his next novel. The novel is a huge success. It makes the New York Times bestseller list, is selected by Ophray Winfrey's book club, and is under contract for a film adaptation by Steven Speilberg. Then Bonner begins to receive e-mails that accuse him of stealing his plotline. So he takes the role of amateur detective to track down his accuser.The novel is well-written and cleverly satirizes the literary world and low residency creative writing programs. I enjoyed the characters, the pacing, and the humor. However, I figured out the mystery early on and kept waiting for the protagonist to get past his anxiety and guilt and do the same. However, I enjoyed the book despite its predictability. I listened to it on audio, and it was great fun.

"The Plot is about a story too good not to steal, and the writer who steals it."I found the story to be unique but predictable. It did hold my interest throughout as I wanted to see where the author would take us. The ending with the "Big Twist" was played out well even if I had already figured out the "Big Twist".I really wanted to enjoy this book more than I did especially since it was loved by so many readers.

Holy WOW did I enjoy this book! With a little more than half to go, I literally could not flip the pages fast enough and stayed up way past my bedtime to finish!Jake is a struggling author trying to reclaim the small amount of fame he felt from his first book. Problem is, he can't seem to write anything and his lackluster ideas take years to get down on paper and fizzle out before they even start. Teaching a three-week, immersive creative writing course for Ripley College, Jake feels burnt out and underwhelmed with his life.When he meets student Evan Parker, Jake is less than impressed with Parker's arrogance and overconfidence. Parker claims he has the next big American novel on his hands and isn't shy about letting people know. However, he keeps the plot close to his chest. In a constructive session, Jake is able to get Parker to open up a bit about the plot and he's dismayed when he actually agrees that there's no way the book won't be a hit.Years later, stuck in another dead end job and working on a novel going nowhere, Jake thinks back to his old student Evan Parker, wondering why he never saw the great American novel hit shelves. Turns out, Evan Parker died shortly after the creative writing class. Is it really stealing if Jake writes the whole book on his own and just uses the basic plot line designed by Parker? Can Jake live with himself if he does?This was such an interesting novel about morality and right versus wrong, how to live with guilt, and the impact of our decisions on ourselves and others. Additionally, it discussed some very relevant topics such as cultural appropriation and the impact of social media, bloggers and early reviewers on authors and literature. Being an early reviewer, blogger, and Goodreads user, I loved the references to those platforms and the viewpoints from the publishers and authors. I couldn't give this one the full five stars because admittedly I found the first chapter to be a slog (it was all dramatically uphill from there) and I figured out the basic twist less than halfway through (this did not in any way slow my reading down and actually probably sped it up because I HAD to know if I was right!). I really loved the format of this book with the novel within a novel. I was totally enthralled with Crib and loved the snippets we got. I felt like Jake's ethical dilemma was fairly authentic and it was hard to watch him unraveling as he let his guilt eat away at him.I really loved this book and it's definitely one I will recommend. It's my first by Hanff Korelitz but certainly won't be my last!Thank you to Celadon and NetGalley for a copy of this novel.

I bought this book blind on the recommendation of my local bookstore (hi Bookhampton!). I was obsessed from the first page, ignoring everything and everyone else until I was done. Beautifully written and very sly.

It's bestseller-like with a whiff of the artsy thanks to the subject matter -- namely writing and writers and the games they play. Clearly the author, Korelitz, knows the terrain well. You see lines like so:"I've learned so much about writers. You're a strange kind of beast, aren't you, with your petty feuds and your fifty shades of narcissism? You act like words don't belong to everyone."And this:"... the world -- the world of writers in particular -- was full of bitter people who believed they were owed something or other, by someone or other. The logic of this being something like:"If you could write a sentence you deserved to consider yourself a writer."If you had an 'idea' for a 'novel' you deserved to consider yourself a novelist."If you actually completed a manuscript you deserved to have someone publish it."If someone published it you deserved to be sent on a twenty-city book tour and have your book featured full-page ads in The New York Times Book Review."And, if, at any point on this ladder of entitlement, one of the aforementioned things you deserved failed to materialize, the blame for that must rest at whatever point you'd been unfairly obstructed:"Your daily life -- for not giving you an opportunity to write."The 'professional' or already 'established' writers -- who'd gotten there quicker because of unspecified advantages."The agents and publishers -- who could only protect and burnish the reputations of their existing authors by keeping new authors out."The entire book industrial complex -- which (following some equal algorithm of profit) doubled down on a few name-brand authors and effectively silenced everyone else."In the Acknowledgments at the end, Korelitz apologizes for being so rough on writers, but says it's only because she loves her brethren so much. (Editor's Comment: "Tough love," anyone?)As for the book, it doesn't feature a cover blurb by Uber-reader Stephen King for nothing! This novel could have been written by King. In fact, he no doubt wishes he had written the thing. But, because he didn't, he generously and correctly assured us that it is "insanely readable," which is a great way of saying, "Plot, baby. Great plot."Good characterization, too. Reads like a mystery, too. A plagiarism case in need of a whodunnit in need of a warning about SPOILERS. O. Henry would sympathize. By the end, you may too. Me, I insanely turned pages. I followed the long and winding road to (pardon my French) denouement. I wondered a bit if the long step-by-step solution was one too many steps.Maybe. Or maybe me being impatient, which I seldom am with a book. On a bestseller rating, I give this a 5. On an "all the world's a stage (of every book written in 2021), I give it a 4. If you feel like some fun or like mysteries or, like me, have had a taste (however small) of writing and publishers and fellow writers and egos and much ado about that something we call nothing -- even in that Outback we call "Poetry World" -- you'll relish this book. Pass the hot dog.

A suspenseful read about the ownership of storiesJacob Finch Bonner, the once promising author of the debut novel The Invention of Wonder, is now a struggling writer teaching at Ripley College in Vermont. At Ripley, basically anyone can attend to receive a MFA. This includes Evan Parker, a pompous jerk who declares he doesn't need Jake--or anyone's--help to make his novel a success. But when Evan actually deigns to share his plot with Jake, Jake can't help but agree. He waits for Evan's inevitable success, but it never comes. When he learns that Evan has died--without having published his book--Jake feels that his story must be told. So Jake writes it, and he is soon basking in the success he was so sure Evan would have. He's rich, famous, and touring the country on a book tour. But then he receives the first email: "You are a thief." Jake feels everything he has about to slip away. As the threats increase, Jake begins to dig into Evan's past. What he finds is horrifying--he may not be the only one who stole this story--and the consequences could be deadly. 
"All Jacob Finch Bonnner had ever wanted to be was a writer." 
THE PLOT starts off slowly, but then takes off, becoming a compulsively readable thriller. It's incredibly ominous and creepy and peppered with reading and writer references. If you love to read, or write, there's a whole meta layer to this book. (Not to mention, we get pieces of Jake's "stolen" novel within our novel as well.) Slowly everything untangles: Jacob's plot, Evan's life, and more. 
"Evan Parker had been entirely correct: the worst writer on the planet could not mess up a plot like this." 
The book builds on, year by year, as Jacob moves from his struggling writer days to a successful and famous novelist. I had an inkling of some of what happened, but enjoyed reading to see if I was right. Jake isn't exactly a sympathetic character, but he's fascinating, and the book certainly makes you think. It's best to go into THE PLOT blind, so I don't want to reveal too much. But I stayed up late to finish it, because it's quite captivating--and different. I certainly recommend it. 4 stars. I received a copy of this book from Celadon Books and Netgalley in return for an unbiased review. Look for it on 5/11/2021!Blog ~ Twitter ~ Facebook ~ Instagram ~  PaperBackSwap ~ Smashbomb
I didn't end up liking this, but I do respect what it was trying to do, so for that I give it an extra star

Suspenseful and impossible to stop listening to! Once I started, I couldn‚Äôt stop. I kept seeing such great reviews, I had to read (or listen to, in this case) this one. The audiobook had incredible narration that made it easy to stay engaged.I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever read a book with this original premise, but it just so happened that I read two at the same time, without knowing they were so closely related. I haven‚Äôt quite finished the other book yet, so I can‚Äôt say which is better, but I think it will be a close finish!Several years after Jake had Evan Parker as a student in one of his classes, he finds out that Evan died suddently, just a few months after finishing the class. The only thing Jake remembers about Evan is that he was very arrogant, and he had an amazing plot for a book. Since Evan died before he was able to publish his book, what can Jake do? He writes his own book, stealing Evan‚Äôs plot. But is it really stealing since he‚Äôs only using the plot and the book is written in his own words? Someone thinks it is.After the novel‚Äîtitled ‚ÄùCrib‚Äù‚Äîbecomes an instant bestseller, Jake starts receiving cryptic messages, from someone who calls themselves ‚ÄúTalented Tom‚Äù, who is accusing Jake of being a theif. ‚ÄúTT‚Äù threatens to publically expose Jake. Rating 3.5As an avid reader I enjoy stories about authors, so choosing this one was a no brainer. As both novelist and writing program instructor, the reader is given a clue about the direction when Jake Bonner, the protagonist, cites a book quote early in the story. From there, the plot reveals elements that if paid attention to, signal the finale. While I'm no Sherlock Holmes, I had it figured out when a 'chance' encounter on a book tour blossoms. It's well written, paced and engaging, though I felt Jake's character was shallow. Regardless, its easy to see how its popularity grew, though its far from what I'd call unique. A fan of unusual characters, unique plots and evocative writing, this one fails in all three. That said, if mystery is your preferred genre, you'll probably enjoy it.

I don‚Äôt do well with slow burn books that take more than 50 pages to get to the meat of the story. In 'The Plot' I learned more than I ever knew about the writing process and the ups and downs of being (and becoming) an established, respected author. This is the best psychological thriller I've read in years - and the most disturbing. There are a ton of lauded reviews here, so I'll be brief. After a creative writing teacher helps himself to the plot of a dead student's story and it becomes a huge best-seller, the teacher starts receiving emails, "You are a thief," and other tormenting messages. Alas, the teacher knew nothing about the student or his personal life. Author Korelitz interweaves pages from the best-seller and, yes, it's a gripping (shocking) story. Some GRs say "The Plot" starts slowly: nonsense! These infantiles want a dead body by Chapter 2 !This is a novel about writers, writing, the whole creative process and the morality of using someone else's ideas. "We're not all hung up about the sales and the rankings and the Amazon number," the teacher-writer Jake tells his soon to be wife. "But we're just so glad that people are reading our work." He reminds himself: On creating narrative tension..."Understanding what made a story track and grab and hold....can just anyone do that?""In my world," the tormented Jake explains, "the migration of a story is something we recognize, and respect. Works of art can overlap. Narratives get told and retold. It's how stories survive through the ages." Yes, he feels, this is powerful, exciting, and - hell - it has a kind of beauty.Here's a fiercely intelligent "thriller" from an original mind. About 2/3rds of the way author Korelitz deliberately suggests who the email blackmailer is, and you, dear reader, can participate in the chilling plot within "The Plot."

4 starsElegantly crafted and filled with smart details, The Plot is an engaging puzzle that fully fulfilled its wild goose chase premise. It is worth mentioning this is definitely more of a slow-burn mystery with a literary bent, than a twist-galore commercial thriller; but the deliberate pacing is justified for the well-realized cast of characters, and the planted hints throughout that actually lead towards its grim reveal (rather than the blindsided, but illogical 'twist for the sake of it' maneuver that often disrupt stories of this genre). Also, how subtly clever is the book title and cover design (hardcover edition)? I 'get' it now.Overall, The Plot feels extremely classy and substantial; not only does it dive deep into the process and psyche of authorship (inspiration vs. plagiarism), but also sustain a constant echoing of fiction vs. reality (love the meta detail, such as the fictional 'novel' in the story being published by the actual publisher in real life).This might be an odd comparison, but the taut atmosphere of The Game with Michael Douglas came to mind numerous times‚ÄîI would love to see David Fincher adapting this!***This ARC was provided by the publisher via NetGalley in exchange for an honest review. Much appreciated!***

Jacob Finch Bonner has one successful novel in his repertoire, and although he has been unable to write anything near its calibre, he does not quite want to give up on his dream. Soon, he‚Äôs teaching creative writing at a third-rate college, helping aspiring writers, including Evan Parker. Jake takes an immediate dislike to Evan, who claims he has the next ‚Äúhit‚Äù novel, and insists he does not need Jake‚Äôs help or guidance in order to be a huge success. What‚Äôs worse is that when Jake reads Evan‚Äôs work he realizes that Evan may actually be right. Months later, Jacob is working an ‚Äúartists retreat‚Äù, dealing almost exclusively with struggling writers, when he finds out that his former student Evan passed away, leaving his book idea unpublished. Jacob decides to take the idea and write a book of his own and it instantly hits superstar status, until he starts to receive messages calling him a ‚Äúthief‚Äù, that threaten his entire future. Jean Hanff Korelitz newest novel, ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù takes a deep look into the world of creative writing, book publishing, and the general birth of a novel from the mind of writer and beyond. Although Korelitz is a well-known and much-published author, I have not read her before and figured a book about books and the writing process was a good place to start  (also, anything Stephen King calls ‚Äúcompulsively readable‚Äù is on my immediate TBR list). ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù is creative and well-written, with substantial vocabulary. This novel has all the nitty gritty details of the publishing world, from the consumerism to the backhanded support and competition between authors. It was an engaging look at the ‚Äúbackstage‚Äù world of books and their creation, and I was intrigued from page one. Each chapter is relatively short, which contributes to its ‚Äúcompulsive readability‚Äù and is told from Jacob‚Äôs viewpoint, allowing a reader to bond with Jacob as he struggles with his moral and creative challenges. One can‚Äôt read this book and not wonder what they would do in this instance, and begin their own internal debate as to whether Jacob‚Äôs choice was moral or not. Above all, it is the ending of this novel that blew me away. As soon as I got to it, I let out an audible gasp. It was completely unexpected while still managing to be realistic and believable‚ÄîI definitely didn‚Äôt see it coming! I picked up this novel completely based on reading nothing but positive reviews, opinions and accolades and I can see they were well deserved- Hanff Korelitz has a winner on her hands!

Have you ever really thought about the plot of a book? What it‚Äôs composed of‚Ä¶ how it hooks you? 3.5 stars and reluctantly rounding up. Reasons for the round up- LOVE the ending. Even though I predicted the culprit (I'm notoriously bad at this too), the ending was deviously satisfying.- No pun intended, but the plot is truly genius. The Plot is an entertaining psychological thriller exploring the competitive world of aspiring authors and the publishing industry.The first part of the book is set on a Vermont college campus, as published author Jacob Finch Bonner teaches a short course for aspiring writers. It's not a job he's passionate about - having experienced fleeting success and recognition after the publication of his first book several years ago, he's struggled to live up to his early promise and has to take on teaching jobs to support himself financially. Among the predictably uninspiring cohort of wannabe writers Jacob is assigned is one standout, a rather obnoxious young man called Evan Parker. Evan confidently asserts that his has a unique plot idea that cannot fail but launch him into the publishing stratosphere - but he won't share it with the group. Over the course of their private meetings, Jacob gains access to the opening pages of Evan's manuscript and gradually draws out of him the great plot twist, and he's stunned: Evan is right - his plot is a virtually guaranteed bestseller.Returning to his dispirited life, searching but failing to find inspiration for another novel, Jacob waits for Evan's novel to hit the shelves, but it never does. It transpires that the young author died tragically shortly after the conclusion of the writing course, and never got a chance to finish his book. Readers will guess what happens next - Jacob develops the plot idea himself, quickly finds a publisher and the book becomes a runaway bestseller.All is rosy for Jacob for a while - he has the life he's always aspired to - but then the creepy emails start arriving: "You are a thief.".Jacob becomes quite paranoid, terrified that he'll be publicly exposed - but for what? It's not as if he plagiarised Evan's work, and there's no property in ideas, is there? As Jacob digs deeper into the story of Evan's life and death, he comes to the shocking realisation that Evan's imaginative plot premise may actually be based on real life events. And someone out there is furious that Jacob has appropriated their personal tragedy for his own gain - can Jacob hunt down the truth and identify his online stalker before his career is blown out of the water, or worse?The Plot takes a meta-fiction format, with excerpts from both Evan's manuscript and Jacob's published novel woven into the main narrative. Jean Hanff Korelitz cleverly drip-feeds details to readers as the story unfolds. While the plot twist alluded to throughout is surprising and unusual, I didn't find it quite as earth-shatteringly original as it had been portrayed. Perhaps this is the author playing games with her audience - there are so many layers of reality and perspective here, it's hard to be sure.As a qualified lawyer and aspiring fiction writer myself, what I enjoyed the most about The Plot was the exploration of intellectual property concepts against a narrative background. Where is the line between taking artistic inspiration, which all authors do, and plagiarism / stealing? Who owns a true story, and to what extent can it be legitimately incorporated into a work of fiction? Is it okay for an author to enjoy professional acclaim and huge profits off the back of someone else's trauma? I had sympathy with both "sides" of these conundra, as played out by the story and characters of The Plot. While Jacob wasn't a particularly likeable character in many respects, my own feeling was that he had the letter of the law on his side, if perhaps not the spirit. Jacob's battle of conscience over Evan and constant self-justification reinforced this impression.The Plot is a thought-provoking and entertaining read, which I'd recommend highly to any reader who enjoys twisty thrillers, especially those with a literary setting.My thanks to the author, Jean Hanff Korelitz, publisher Faber & Faber Ltd., NetGalley and NetGalleyUK, for the opportunity to read and review this intriguing title.

Jacob Finch Bonner is a washed up, one hit wonder of a writer that has been relegated to teaching in a third rate MFA program. Dismayed at this predicament and with his inadequacies, Jacob desperately looks for that ‚Äúbig break‚Äù that will propel him back into the limelight of the literary world.Enter Evan Parker. Evan is a blistering, arrogant snob that claims he has a blockbuster of a novel. That his novel will be an instant bestseller. Not easily persuaded, Jacob regards Evan‚Äôs boastful remarks as showboating until he hears the plot. It is then that Jacob waits with bated breath for news of Evan‚Äôs book release. Nothing happens. Then, Jacob learns of Evan‚Äôs untimely death. Of course, knowing that the plot would be a bestseller and that the story needs to be told, Evan does what any other author of his time would do. That is to write a novel worthy of A-list producers and directors.The Plot is a slow and deliberate read. The reader needs to be prepared to ride the tide and be well invested in order to fully appreciate and enjoy the novel. It took me past the 50% point before I actually thought, ‚Äúwow, this is an interesting novel.‚ÄùThe characters are somewhat boring in an of themselves, but the plot is what makes them shine together. And the enigmatic book cover just adds to the mystery that will eventually be solved once the reader completes reading The Plot. Four mysterious stars.I received a physical ARC from Celadon Books through Bookish First. The review herein is completely my own and contains my honest thoughts and opinions.

I thought this was an awful book, and only gave it 2 stars because of the admittedly very sneaky couple of twists at the end.What it is, basically, is what I call a 'babysitter plot'. You know the movies your 13 year old likes, about babysitters who hear a noise in the basement and though they are frightened they decide to investigate? Those movies that give the kids a chance to shout in unison "Don't do it!"?Because there is nothing else at all to move the plot along if someone isn't doing stupid things against even their own better judgement?That's this book. The main character is a self-centred, navel-gazing dweeb, who constantly does things he knows he shouldn't, then moans about the consequences. I shouldn't even call him the main character because he has no character. The protagonist then.He consistently trashes other people - everybody really - his students, other writers, and envy rules his life and his world since he sees himself as having been denied the success that should rightfully be his.It's nasty, and he gets really boring.But that said, the twists at the end are really very good. I just wish that inventiveness had been saved for a book worthy of them.
This is a book I find difficult to say anything about because I fear spoiling it for others!

The Plot by Jean Hanff Korelitz is a slow burn mystery/thriller that centers around a struggling writer named Jacob Finch Bonner who ends up stealing the plot of another writer's book. This one definitely took me a decent amount of time to get into, but after I did I found it to be quite enjoyable. I thought of it more as a mystery than as a thriller and had no idea who the mysterious person calling Bonner a thief could possibly be. I found myself cringing quite a bit at the choices Bonner makes, and as he searches for the person calling him out online, the story is quite suspenseful. So if you think it starts slow, just wait because the end will make it worth it! I did listen to the audio via NetGalley and unfortunately, their app is not good, and it made the narrator sound a lot like a robot. However, from what I could tell of Kirby Heyborne's narration, he did a really good job, and I was really impressed with all of his inflections. I would definitely listen to him again (not on the NetGalley Shelf app) to see what he sounds like normally. I think going the audio route really helped me with the slow pacing of the novel at first, and once I got to about the halfway point I didn't want to put it down. I am still coming to terms with the end (WHAT), but it was not at all what I was expecting, and I am shook. The Plot has been called clever by a lot of readers and I am definitely inclined to agree. I received a complimentary copy of this book. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

This book has got to be the best one I've read that deals with the process of writing, authors and the publishing industry. Although I'm not an aspiring writer, I do free-lance work for a company and have been told too many times to count that I should write a book. As if! Although the main character often says anybody can be a writer, I have read or attempted to read too many books that prove the opposite. Jacob "Jake" Finch Bonner is a writer who met with success by making the "New and Noteworthy" column of the New York Times with his first novel. Unfortunately, his second and third attempts were not as successful so he turned to teaching at a third-rate MFA program. One of his students, Evan Parker, an arrogant jerk, has a self-proclaimed "sure thing" whose plot he shares with Jake. Jake agrees it's a certain hit. As time passes but the book fails to be published, a curious Jake finds out that Evan has died and has left the door open for Jake to appropriate the plot. Life for Jake changes on a dime. His book is everything he thought it would be: number one on the NYT best seller list and movie rights optioned with an A-list director. Life couldn't be better. That is until he receives an e-mail saying he is a thief. The attacks continue to be more specific and more public and set Jake on the path of discovering who is behind these attacks.This is a great suspense thriller. The pacing is good, the story original and the insights into writers and writing are enlightening. I did figure out early on who was behind the attacks, but how the story unfolded kept me reading. Thank you NetGalley and Celadon Books for an Advance Reader's Copy. The publication date is May 11, 2021.

Jacob Finch Bonner is teaching at an MFA program mentoring aspiring novelists in Vermont when he meets Evan Parker(or shall I say Parker Evan?). Anybody can be a writer, right? All you need is a really great plot. And if you can't come up with one of your own, maybe you can...er...borrow one? Jacob Finch Bonner, once considered a promising young author, has done just that and hit the jackpot--#1 best seller, book tours, movie deal with Stephen Spielberg, beautiful young wife. But he's not completely happy with this fame and glory because he fears the truth will be revealed and it will all come crashing down around him.This is a slow burner of a story with a terrific twist ending. Along the way, the book delves into the moral issues that come up in writing and publishing--mainly, who owns an original idea, a storyline? The title and the choice of cover art are perfect for this novel with all the different permutations of that word. I have now read two of Korelitz's novels and have signed copies of two others on my bookshelf to be read, obtained at St Mary's College's National Literary Festival, October, 2019, where she was one of several authors who were interviewed. If anyone can come up with an original plot line, it's Jean Hanff Korelitz!I received an arc of this new thriller from the publisher via NetGalley in exchange for an honest review. Many thanks for the opportunity.

4.5 mostly for readability, enjoyment and storytellingI'm certain that listening to this immediately after the audio of Who is Maud Dixon was a mistake since a year from now I most likely will get the two confused. But writing and writers are a subject on my mind.Both books are mysteries that concern writers and writing. Both are at the heart about women who feel they deserve more in life. In Dixon there are many unexpected twists and turns where as in The Plot I felt pretty sure where the story was going but like an accident unfolding I could not look away or in this case stop listening and in truth felt unable to listen fast enough (without turning up the intended speed) to get to see if I was right and exactly how it would unfold. If I could have gotten the print at the library I likely would have stayed up most the night reading.This story about a writer and his use of another's plot poses many great questions about writing. This even more than Dixon was its strongest recommendation for me. Dixon really did not talk much about writing where as the Plot wove in some interesting writer knowledge and questions. The obvious: Can the idea for a book, its plot, be used by another. Are a plot and a trop the same?Does each person have a unique story to be told? Does that story belong to that person or can it be appropriated by another? and in what degree? Is it possible that there are story ideas out there, that if you don't grab and use them when they are presented/gifted to you (in a dream, idea, thought), that the story will eventually find someone who will write it? (I think I read something similar in Elizabeth Gilbert's novel, Big Magic). I wanted to think more about these ideas, considerations yet I was so engaged in the story, the plotting of it, the telling of it, that I found I put aside all questions/thoughts posed and was just anxious just to see where this particular story was going, where the author would take this story. Excellent story telling, a mystery I will be recommending for sure and one with ideas that will linger long after the plot has been forgotten. Well done Jean Korelitz 4.5 stars rounded up.

Jacob Finch Bonner is looking to write his next big novel. When arrogant Evan Parker walks into his MFA program‚Äôs writing class claiming that he doesn‚Äôt need help because he has the perfect plot, Jacob easily dismisses him. However, when he eventually hears the plot of Evan‚Äôs novel, he agrees that its a winning book. He tamps down his jealousy and moves on with his teaching career and own writing. When he eventually hears that Evan died without ever publishing his book, he steals the premise and writes the book himself. The book turns out to be an overnight success, giving Jacob the wealth and fame he desires. When he starts receiving threatening messages from someone who knows he is a thief, he decides to investigate Evan Parker and where he found the idea for his ultimate plot. I‚Äôm definitely in the minority with my opinion on this book, so please check out other reviews as well. This could be due to the fact that I listened to the audiobook, whose narrator spoke in a robotic monotone voice. For this reason, I highly suggest reading the written book instead of the audiobook. I actually debated quitting many times, but ultimately stuck with it and finished the book. Overall, I found The Plot to be a very slow-paced thriller with very little thrills. It took almost three hours of listening before anything happened. I also found that the third person narration took away from the authenticity of Jacob‚Äôs voice. I predicted most of twists early on and was underwhelmed by the actual ‚Äúplot‚Äù of Crib, as it was not as shocking as promised. This book just didn‚Äôt deliver for me. 3/5 stars

If you enjoy a very slow burn, an extremely complex plot and strong character development ... pick up The Plot by Jean Hanff Korelitz! This novel is a story within a story, a book within a book, and a plot within a plot that you will definitely have to pay very close attention to. The problem for me was that it moved so slowly that I had a hard time keeping that close attention. The plot (pun intended) definitely thickens with every chapter and every detail uncovered! It's a really interesting story but you cannot expect it to grip you. If it had been executed more like a thriller with a fasted paced edge and quickening to it, I would have enjoyed it so much more. But that's just me. Some readers LOVE slow burns and if that's you -- ENJOY! Thank you, Celadon Books, Macmillan Audio, and NetGalley, for a copy of this book for review!

Liked:1) I loved the book within the book, aka Crib. I wish the author just wrote this book and let us all enjoy twists, turns, and drama.2) The end. It made me happy.

It‚Äôs wonderful when the right person comes into your life at the right time.Jacob Finch Bonner is a failed writer but even he would know a good plot when he sees one. And that is exactly what happens when his arrogant student boasts about his own manuscript and the ingenious plot therein. Bonner is tempted. How hard could it be to steal someone else's story? After all, a great story needs to be told, doesn't it?Years pass, Bonner writes and publishes the book and becomes an overnight success and all is well until he receives a much less than praising email accusing him of plagiarism. You know what you did. I know what you did. Are you ready for everyone to know what you did? I hope so, because I‚Äôm getting ready to tell the world. Have fun with your career after that.You would think the person behind the condemning messages is the rightful owner of the plot; but the thing is, he is long dead and buried.So, who is Bonner's accuser and what do they want from him?The reasons for my 2 star rating:-The superfluous and unnecessary use of parentheses in almost every sentence rendering the sentence long and painful to understand. Reading the dialogues was less excruciating than the rest of the writing.-The main character who is named Bonner by the author for reasons best known to herself, is a despicable, condescending and self-centered person filling half of the book whining and explaining the reasons for his failure. The book could have been much shorter.-The transparency of the plot and the lack of any major twist is disappointing to say the least.-What's the deal with the bottle-opener that it's mentioned a million times? Did i miss something?Naturally, the Evan in question would only require his first name, at least to anyone and everyone who‚Äôd known him. Evan, the triumphant rescuer of the kidnapped bottle opener. Evan, the guy who sat at the seminar table with his arms tightly folded across his chest. Everyone would know an asshole like that.

Here we have the second novel published this year that takes aim at the publishing industry with an arrow of suspense. Whereas Zakiya Dalila Harris's The Other Black Girl happens inside a publishing house, Jean Hanff Korelitz's The Plot happens in the writer's mind. Both novels hit their targets dead to rights, skewering the top hits-driven publishing industrial complex in its fickle heart. But The Plot's twisty moral ambiguity caught my imagination and not a few times, I had to catch my breath. Like many readers before me, I figured out the whodunit aspect long before the end. And yet, this did not dull the figurative sheen of sweat that broke out on my forehead as I felt Jake Bonner's fear of being found out as a writer who purloined a plot. What if I published a bestselling novel, knowing the story wasn't mine? Could I live with the guilt, and then worse ‚Äî when it's clear someone out there knows what I did and they are really, really pissed about it ‚Äî the fear?But here's the thing. This question is what I love about this novel ‚Äî the nested mystery inside the mystery: was Jake really in the wrong? After all, every word he wrote in his Oprah-approved, film-optioned blockbuster was his. Whatever the answer is, I had to keep reminding myself this was fiction, and I was not this writer. Korelitz's prose is elegant, the story-within-a-story plot device propulsive. This is an irresistible read that falters in the blandness of its protagonist, Jake, and his too-sublime girlfriend, Anna, and the odd oversell of the world's most ingenious plot. The real mystery is that there really are so few storylines to go around, and yet terrific, original and satisfying novels keep being written. The Plot is one of them.

I've enjoyed this author's previous books so I was excited to get an ARC of The Plot and it didn't disappoint. While the beginning is a bit slow, the second half clipped along at a rapid pace and it kept my interest throughout. I especially enjoyed the glimpse into the writing and publishing world. There were some brave choices by the author. The cat and mouse game between the writer and his internet troll/stalker felt, at times, a little like the game the author was playing with the reader. Aside from the fun and devious "plot" of the book, I found the ponderings of the protagonist interesting as he debates the ethics of appropriation to justify his actions. As society increasingly looks for stories told by authors with lived experience of the subject matter, in their own voices, this book asks who really owns a story? Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for an advance copy!
