4.5 Be Careful What You Wish For Stars* * * * 1/2 Spoiler FreeWhen I saw this blurb, I clicked immediately. As a reader/reviewer, the art of writing is near and dear to me. I started it, dug in, and was captivated by the two major points of this book. Yes, it is a mystery/thriller and I loved that...but it also put out there this bare, raw, and vulnerable reveal of what it is like to have that need, that desire to write, to appreciate the wonder of what words can do.Our main fella isn't really a hugely likable character. The main thing about him is his early understanding of words and stories. He was advanced in his observations and decided to read books way more advanced for his age. He grew to realize writing was something that needed nurturing, devotion, and a focus to the point of sacrifice. He worked harder, applied to all the necessary programs, awards, scholarships, anything that would advance him in the writing field.And then it happened, after all the years of schooling, programs, and dedication, he was published and recognized as a promising new voice. He experienced that feeling...it was a high like no other. His book had made a little mark for him and then he needed to do his second book to hold onto his place among those who were considered worthy. It was that second book curse, he experienced it and never really recovered from it. He was published after many submissions, it never being anything to be proud of. He was on that ugly spiral, the downward journey that had him becoming what many shift to...a teacher. It is as this teacher for a program for those who wish to write and come to for guidance. It was almost a joke to have him teaching this as he had no real concern anymore for these minds. He did when he first was hired for the program but now he was just marking time and cashing the small check.This story starts to move forward when we get to the major set-up for this book, an arrogant, entitled guy is part of this session, and his attitude in how he behaves has us immediately disliking him. The joke, of course, is he won't talk about his project when the group first meets and it seems the only reason he is here is to try to get an agent and put a program on his resume. Full of himself would be the perfect description.This guy has a scheduled time to meet with our teacher and before the meeting, our teacher searches for the required submission needed for the course. It is read, then re-read because it isn't the usual drivel he gets. No, this is different. It is descriptive but with few words. You feel the place and who the people are...the conflict and pain just under the surface. Prepared to deal with this ass, the meeting starts. It is during this meeting, our author is juggling, dancing back and forth with this guy. It finally comes down to the challenge from the guy daring him to ask about this "Sure Thing" plot for his book. After a back and forth of mental gymnastics for the power play, the guy tells the teacher what is his plot. It is devastating...It is something that defies all the rules of plotting, of how there are only so many that can happen. It is perfect and everything the jerk had said that would happen when he writes this, will come true. This is the first part of the book. Heady, right. The book is done in parts and the next one is three years later and our writer has continued down his spiral of non-writing becoming a manager for a writers retreat. It is while he is there when his life will be presented his writing crossroads.I could not stop reading this, even when I needed to do other things. It presented an interesting theory about the responsibility of words and how the gift of something given needs to be taken seriously, how there is this purpose that must get them out, to not turn your back on them. To revere them, nurture them, and take on their responsibility. Yes, there is so much more than the concepts of writing, there is a terrific mystery/thriller story too. Our fella took on so much more than he ever could have thought when he decided to go on his path with his new book.

It's almost impossible to review this book without giving a thing away. I do feel like the one thing that might be interesting to talk about, is whether a book idea can be truly stolen. When the publishers were met with the question, it was clear to them. An idea can not be stolen. And just because one has an idea, doesn't mean they can write it, or get it published. Many themes and tropes are used all the time, and many ideas blend into one another. In her book Big Magic, Elizabeth Gilbert tells the story of having had a particular idea. She had some of it flushed out. She went to lunch with a novelist friend, and they never once spoke of it. Not even a word or reference to it. She got busy and distracted with other projects and never got the book written, despite it having been flushed out. One year later, the novelist friend published her well known novel. It was the same exact idea, flushed out in the same exact way, in the exact setting and plot. Coincidence? I remember a few years ago, where there were three Mata Hari books out at once. Someone in my main group (CW I believe) suggested that it was because the 75th anniversary. Perhaps, but that was indeed strange. I have also noticed more than once that a flush of books emerge on a particular topic that isn't even current or prominent, but rather obscure - I ask again, can an idea or plot be truly stolen? Now of course in the book, the Plot, there is more to it than that. For one, our central character feels an immense guilt that is hard to understand, but that drives the story plot. The question becomes deeper, what if the plot were based on a real story? Whether you know it or not, is any plot that has a remote resemblance, stealing? Or are our stories so similar enough that it wouldn't have mattered. To whom might it truly matter? We get our imagination from our own lives, so is it stealing if it is adequately disguised? If it mirrors too close to the truth, even without knowing, is there a blame aspect required? Now the book is a fun thriller, but what does it say about writers and writing, and whose story is it to tell?An interesting phenomena happened while reading the book. And the book within the book, which promised a twist that no one saw coming. I wanted to comment on reviewers and twists. We seem many of us to get abject pleasure in "having seen the twist a mile away" or having been blown away by "I didn't see that coming." People in their reviews seem to love to announce that they predicted the twist. Why is this I ask? And yet I had that thought with this book. I felt I knew exactly what was coming, and often I don't quite..... But the need to announce that to everyone? That I knew it early? (If indeed I did....) Well who does that serve? Why as a book reading culture are we caught up in announcing whether or not we saw it in advance? Even I found the desire to do so, and caught myself and say, "well who cares, and what on earth is that about?" I don't think we should be congratulated personally, for outsmarting the author. It's about the joy in reading the tale. And enjoying the twists, whether you are right or you aren't. The book was fun, and layered. And worth a read. Four stars from me!

3.5 starsJacob Finch Bonner saw moderate success with the publication of his debut novel. Unfortunately, his second release failed to garner any attention and he fears he‚Äôs fallen into obscurity. He finds himself teaching creative writing to others and knows all too well the starry eyed dreams of the hopefuls who fill his class. One student stands out: Evan Parker, tight lipped about an idea he has for a novel yet arrogant enough to brag to anyone who will listen that he‚Äôs come up with the perfect plot for a runaway bestseller.Jake is ready to brush off Evan‚Äôs arrogance but then he hears the plot ‚Ä¶and he has to agree that it is going to be a complete and total success.A few years later Jake discovers Evan died soon after the creative writing course ‚Äî presumably before he could finish his novel or even reveal his idea to anyone else. Jake can‚Äôt forget that incredible plot, in fact, it‚Äôs too brilliant not to share with the world. So Jake writes the novel based on Evan‚Äôs idea and finally has the fame and success he's longed for as an author; he even finds love on his never-ending book tour. He‚Äôs enjoying every moment of his success until he receives the first of many brief and menacing emails: ‚ÄúYou are a thief.‚ÄùJake‚Äôs life could come crashing down at any time. In order to find out who knows the truth, he has to learn more about his late student and what he uncovers is that his bestselling novel may not be fiction after all‚Ä¶The Plot is a story within a story. Readers follow Jake‚Äôs story and as it progresses we get excerpts from his novel. When the plot of his novel is eventually revealed, it was a letdown because it is a pretty formulaic thriller twist. That choice seems to be tongue-in-cheek commentary on the author‚Äôs part; Korelitz delivers some amusing insight into the publishing world and a writer‚Äôs life. The story is at times clever with the way it appears to poke fun at - while paying homage to - the ‚Äúpsychological thriller‚Äù genre trends of the past decade, and I was hoping Korelitz would deliver a truly surprising twist ending. Unfortunately, the twist was glaringly obvious to me and I was left thinking this is just your average middle of the road thriller which means a highly entertaining beach read but nothing shocking or new.I recommend The Plot to readers who enjoy psychological thrillers, suspense, and books about books. 4.5 STARS"THE TWIST" as an alternative titleNo SpoilersThis is my first Jean Hanff Korelitz novel but assuredly not my last. She is a highly skilled author and delivers her story with aplomb. The reader is highly engaged from the beginning and is led through the story by the narrator thoughts and reactions as the observant fly on the wall.Jacob Finch Bonner is an author of limited success. His first book was a modest success but the following three stories were mediocre and though he knows he is talented that doesn't seem to correlate with fame or name recognition or even money for him. He relies on teaching to pay his bills living a life of near poverty and focused on a gangbusters idea to success. One day, a mediocre student delivers the hit of the decade for plot and Jacob is tied in knots at not conceiving it. He awaits its publication but years pass and not a squeak is heard, leading to his discovery that the student died without publishing the story. So, Jacob writes the story and becomes a big hit. However, that isn't the end of this tale, no it is really the beginning.We suffer Jake's angst at being non-productive and then the high of being "that famous author" and then later to his anxiety prone life which is always over shadowed by the secret he carries and the threats of being unmasked. Someone knows how he learned of this plot and they want him to admit that he stole it. However, there is a bigger matter that is never quite obvious. Though I did figure the twist before the reveal it was just a few pages before it was revealed, that wasn't a problem. I was delighted how Korelitz wrote the story and the pieces tied together. The characters make this story and they are well drawn and memorable. One never completely empathizes with any of them completely, as they are drawn with flaws, however, the reader is always highly engaged. ALWAYS. What I liked most is that I even wondered if Jean was male because she seemed to capture the way I believe a man thinks. I'm not sure what male readers perceived but she seemed to capture his slight arrogance as a professional writer having to interact with less superior persons attempting to write (students). His interaction with the females in the story reflected a male persona as well (I'm not inferring anything here).I will be back to read some of this author's prior and future works. If you like character driven stories this is one to put on your reading list.

When writing a book about a plot that is so unique, so fantastic, that it will simultaneously become a commercial hit and an instant classic, divulging the details of that plot is a risk. This is because the author must actually be able to deliver such a story. However, once the plot is actually revealed, it is no where near the caliber described in the book. It could be argued that the visibility of the twist is a comment on the protagonist‚Äôs character, but that doesn‚Äôt make this a novel worth reading. Some of the most squandered potential I‚Äôve encountered in a long time.

Writer Jacob Finch Bonner is a one semi-hit book author. Years ago he wrote a fairly well received first book, with a not terrific selling second book. As years have gone by and he is still struggling to write a third book, with no luck, he now works as a writing teacher at a Master‚Äôs Program coaching who he feels are inadequate and undeserving self-centered wanna-be writers.At the beginning of the current semester, he come across a student who not only is egotistical, but insists that he will become the number one best-selling author of all time because he has thought of a plot which not only has never been conceived, but a story that will blow people‚Äôs minds. Jake has heard and seen this type of enthusiasm before, but from this student, Evan Parker, he sees something else. An absolute surety in his story.Jake of course does not believe Evan Parker, and tells him. He asks for proof that Parker really has written this great American novel. Parker refuses to let him see any of his writing because he says he does not believe another writer would not hesitate to steal his plot. But Jake being the teacher finally convinces Parker to let him read a few pages of this novel. And Jake begrudgingly sees that Parker is correct. He will have a blockbuster on his hands.As time goes by and Jake continues to attempt another novel, and moves on to a different school, he continually awaits the publication of Parker‚Äôs novel because he knows for sure it will be sold. But the book never comes out. Jake decides to do a little digging and discovers Evan Parker had died. Jake realizes this could be the opportunity of his lifetime knowing Parker did not discuss the plot with anyone. He decides to write the book with the plot which Parker took to his grave.And just as Parker assured him, it became not only a best-seller, but he appeared on The Oprah Winfrey Show and Steven Spielberg is making the movie. His life went from writing an ok book to being a famous author. And he was enjoying every second of his fame!Until he receives an email out of the blue which changes his life forever. Someone knows his secret. They have made it perfectly clear they will expose him for the plot stealing plagiarist he became. Clearly, Jake has no where to turn. He is in too deep. He cannot tell his editor or publisher what he has done, his career will be ruined. He decides to ignore the email. But whoever the person is persists and takes their case to social media.Jake embarks on a journey to try and find out who this mysterious person could possibly be and figure out how THEY knew about the plot and somehow try and make them stop before his life is ruined. He begins to investigate Evan Parker‚Äôs life to see if there is possibly someone from his past (all his family is dead) who knew about Parker‚Äôs story.And what he begins to discover will shock, amaze and horrify Jake as well as the reader. And where the plot inevitably leads Jake will have the reader stunned.Jean Hanff Korelitz, author of You Should Have Known, which was turned into the HBO mini-series The Undoing, has written a terrifying mystery in The Plot which the reader knows only what Jake knows and we are all kept in the dark until the last page. Incredible!Thank you #Goodreads #CeladonBooks #JeanHanffKorelitz #ThePlot for the advanced copy.

Jacob Finch Bonner was once an up-and-coming novelist with a bestselling book. Too bad his second book was such a flop. Now he's a down-and-out professor with a fourth book he'll probably never finish and students he despises. There is one student that has particularly incensed him: Evan Parker. Evan is arrogant enough to think he doesn't need Jacob's help or his lackadaisical teaching. When Jacob hears the plot of Evan's novel, he realizes that Evan is completely right. That plot is a winner, which sends Jacob into an even further downward spiral of self loathing. Only, the book never gets published and Evan ends up dead. As Jacob sees it, there's no sense letting a perfect plot go to waste. So he steals it for himself and is catapulted to fame. The only problem is: Someone knows he stole the plot and is hellbent on making him pay. This book was a chore to read. The main character was dull as dirt, as was much of the story.As others have mentioned, this is a slow burn. A very slow burn. And not the good kind of slow burn that builds tension and suspense. The "Good lord will something happen already?" kind of slow burn. Because nothing of note happens until Part Three. Even then, I didn't find it to be a fast-paced read. That being said, I did like the twist at the end. It was very well done and unexpected. It was just the getting there part that I found quite tedious. And, honestly, that could be in part due to me rather than the writer. I simply didn't enjoy Jean Hanff Korelitz's writing style and didn't find it engaging. Other people may love it, so I do recommend trying this book out for yourself. I do recommend this book to anyone who enjoys academia literature, stories of writers and slow burn thrillers. Thank you to NetGalley for the ARC in exchange for an honest review.

Jake Finch Bonner is a published author who has received some critical acclaim for a past novel, but has never achieved the kind of success and financial reward that he craves. After teaching at a ‚Äúlow-residency‚Äù writer‚Äôs workshop, he makes a decision that will alter the course of his life and career. It also prompts a moral question about his integrity, especially when a Twitter comment threatens to expose what he did.Korelitz made some style and structure choices that hooked me in immediately‚Äîthe novel within a novel format, although with a carefully navigated twist. It‚Äôs not the first novel to concentrate on stealing another writer‚Äôs work, but this one focuses on hijacking the plot. The prose and story conflicts are the work of the writer and protagonist, Jake, who ‚Äúborrowed‚Äù the plot from his former student, Evan Parker. Familiar tropes are used, although Korelitz made this her own story. However, for me, it had mixed results.Jake‚Äôs successful novel, CRIB, centers around a mother and daughter that dislike each other so entirely that their interactions are merely transactional. Jake is a competent writer with a talent for producing a suspenseful narrative, but lacked the imagination to create a brilliant plot. When Parker reveals his own story line, Jake is jealous and aware that Parker could produce a winner, and later finds an opportunity to make it his own. Korelitz adds intensity by not revealing Parker‚Äôs prized plot to the reader until close to the end, but I figured it out pretty quickly, anyway.In the meantime, Jake has been consumed with his success, his new girlfriend, and a movie version of his book, directed by Spielberg. He struggles with doubt elicited by the anonymous tweeter, and attempts to convince himself that he was scrupulous. What is the outcome, and what are the implications, when a writer covertly lifts a plot from another writer? What are the boundaries and ethics of a writer, especially when he cherry-picks the meaning of T.S. Eliot‚Äôs, ‚ÄúGood writers borrow, great writers steal.‚ÄùI‚Äôve read several Korelitz novels, and noted her talent for insights and characters. Perhaps it is my familiarity with her arcs, but I was able to figure out 90% of the late revelation before I finished the first third of the novel. Parker‚Äôs winning plot did not win me over, as I surmised the bombshell ‚Äústeal.‚Äù If that was the only idea that Jake ‚Äústole,‚Äù it lacked the gravitas he made of it, or that Korelitz presented. Even though it was part of Korelitz‚Äôs aim for us to question whether Jake‚Äôs actions were libelous, dubious, a transgression of his craft, it felt a bit feeble as the breathless disclosure. The actual ‚Äúplot‚Äù idea is available from the vapor, the place where writers‚Äô ideas collect and swirl; it‚Äôs not the kind of plot that calls out ownership. There was also an expository info dump at the finale, which was unnecessary, since most of the facts had formerly and slowly been signaled or revealed. And Korelitz regularly overexplained how Jake‚Äôs thoughts turned, such as writing that ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt really believe that‚Äù or ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt really think that,‚Äù not giving enough credit to the reader for tacitly understanding it without requiring her parentheticals.THE PLOT, despite its flaws, is still a dark, engaging book. It will appeal to escapist readers who want something deeper than Dan Brown and more literary than Liane Moriarty. If they make a series, I hope they do a better job than they did with YOU SHOULD HAVE KNOWN, which was made into the HBO prestige domestic thriller, THE UNDOING, which was a complete mess. But I can‚Äôt blame the plot changes on Korelitz. :)Thank you to Macmillan First Reads and NetGalley for an advanced reading copy.

All he had ever wanted was to tell‚Äî in the best possible words, arranged in the best possible order‚Äî the stories inside him. The Plot is about Jake Bonner, a stalled novelist who is teaching at a mediocre MFA program. His book dreams of grandeur are unmet and he's having some trouble making rent. He grumbles about his lackluster years teaching students until he hears the plot of Evan Parker‚Äôs story. Evan‚Äôs narcissistic about his future acclaimed book, but even Jake silently acknowledges ‚Äúa good plot when he saw one.‚Äù Two years later, Jake‚Äôs a glorified receptionist at a writer‚Äôs retreat, and he has still failed to churn out a book. He recalls that unusual plot his student spoke about. In a moment of desperation, a quick search reveals the acclaimed plot has not been published because Evan‚Äôs dead. Jake takes this windfall and runs with it ‚Äì straight to wealth, fame, respect ‚Äì just as he‚Äôd always dreamed. Life would be perfect now if he were not being harassed and threated to be exposed for plagiarism. As Jake tries to figure out who‚Äôs behind the attack; he finds a connection that he can‚Äôt overlook. The Plot is told in two narratives with different writing styles. It starts off with Jake‚Äôs narrative when he meets Evan and continues in a present timeline. The other narrative contains brief excerpts from the novel Jake wrote. So, you get a story within a story. I struggled through the first 30% at a crawl. Besides not introducing anything more than I had learned in the book‚Äôs description, Jake‚Äôs narrative drove me batty. It was all mile-long paragraphs, infinite serial lists, and the most excessive parenthesis usage I‚Äôve encountered. I soon realized this writing style was a ploy to show how shallow and annoying was Jake‚Äôs character. And, yes, I found Jake terribly annoying. However, it was a chore to get through this part. Interestingly, each time the narrative would flip to the novel excerpt, I was engaged and couldn‚Äôt wait to find out more. But like I said earlier, you only get a few pages of this every so often. This alone proved the quality of the author‚Äôs writing to me. This and the positive reviews for the book kept me reading. It was unfortunate that I spotted the twist early in the book. And I do mean early. This wasn't a complete let down though, I was still curious about how the details would play out.  It wasn‚Äôt until the last 30% did I feel the story had begun in earnest. From this point on I was fully engaged in both narratives. But I found the suspense only marginal. Perhaps, since I didn‚Äôt engage with Jake‚Äôs character, I felt less urgency‚Ä¶maybe. Or if Jake hadn‚Äôt been so inept here‚Ä¶The way the ending came together made reading the book worthwhile. I especially liked the narrative in the final reveal, even if I found it somewhat predictable. This psychological drama was my favorite part. I would recommend this book to readers who enjoy fiction with a less violent narrative.

I immediately felt this story would have worked better in the first person. I don‚Äôt get that feeling often when I read something. I wonder if the author ever considered this.I was really digging this book at the beginning to the point that I was talking it up to all of my friends. I just reached a point where the story got too stupid to tolerate.The book was way too long. It would have been a terrific short story. The author goes into so much unnecessary description of places and people that mean nothing to the story, she was just filling up pages. Long descriptions of not-shit characters who disappear after a few paragraphs are a sure sign that the writer is looking for something to flesh out a novel from a short story.Jake couldn‚Äôt possibly be charged with plagiarism for what he did. You can‚Äôt copyright a story idea someone pitches to you. If that were the case, people from publishing houses would be writing endless synopses of stories and nailing down the rights to them. He wrote the book from start to finish, the guy who told him the story died without leaving behind a paper trail, and Jake would have proof that he wrote the entire novel. There is no legal issue here at all. Perhaps a bit of a moral dilemma, but nothing to worry about in a court case.I was confused early on when Jake finds out that the Parker kid is dead and decides to steal his book. How he ‚Äústole‚Äù it wasn‚Äôt explained, and as it turned out, he didn‚Äôt steal the book, at least not a manuscript. He simply wrote the story that the kid relayed to him. P.S. It wasn‚Äôt such a shit-hot story.I‚Äôm sure that I‚Äôm not alone when I say that for the last one hundred pages, I knew what was going on and had to put up with a slow wrap of the story. It‚Äôs not like it was some big, secret twist because I figured it out early and I usually never do that, I never really care. I hate mysteries, for the most part.Really dumb Things that Annoyed Me:1 - How did Jake not know that his wife had a baby?2 - That was some coincidence that Anna just happened to be working at a radio station where she could arrange the meet with Jake. It‚Äôs almost like her whole life up until then was preparing for a stranger to steal her life story and turn it into a novel.3 - Why would Anna go after Jake in the first place? She murdered her own daughter and prodding the author could bring out the true story.4 ‚Äì How could Anne go from psychopath who killed her entire family to dream girl who Jake‚Äôs parents loved?5 - How could she steal her daughter's scholarship?

Review published in: https://diagnosisbookaholic.blogspot....- A writer as main character. ‚òëÔ∏è- A little peek into the publishing world and the writing process. ‚òëÔ∏è- A book within a book PLOT. ‚òëÔ∏èWith those three ingredients I can only say ‚Äútake my money and give me that book to read NOW!‚Äù, or listen to in this case, cause I went with the audiobook and that might have been a good choice. I‚Äôve read some people complaining about the writing style, really long sentences or the overuse of parenthesis, but that wasn‚Äôt an issue to me with the audio version.I found the dilemma the story presented really interesting. Is it plagiarism when you actually wrote every single word yourself? Do ideas have an owner? If the one who thought of a plot is dead, is it really dishonest to take it and write the book yourself? After all, everyones will want to read that story, so original and shocking it is (I lost count how many times this was said).My allegiances and sympathies for Jacob came and went all throughout the story and I really don‚Äôt know what I would have done in his situation (in case I had the knack to write a book, which I don‚Äôt).The first few chapters were a bit slow, but once Jacob publishes his novel and starts ‚Äúinvestigating‚Äù everything became much more interesting.I was not that surprised with the ending cause I called it (or some variation of it) almost from the 50% mark. I loved how the word ‚Äúplot‚Äù took more than one meaning at the end.A small issue I had with the story was that we‚Äôre told countless times that ‚Äúthe plot‚Äù was something spectacular, never been done, that every publisher would want to publish it and every person in the world would want to read it, so when it was finally revealed I could not help but think that we‚Äôve all read ‚Äúplots‚Äù like that hundreds of times, so I could not completely understand Jacob‚Äôs huge success.Good writing and an original plot made of The Plot a fun listen, with every piece of the puzzle fitting together at the end in a clever way.It was my first approach to the author‚Äôs work but I‚Äôll be definitely checking out some of her previous books. I can see how this will be one of the books of 2021.

I listened to the audiobook version.This is not a slow burn, it is an excruciatingly slllllllllllllllllllloooooooooooooooooooooowwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww burn. I almost DNFed this a dozen times. But I persevered. Not only was this very slow to get interesting, but the beginning was kind of hard to follow. Again, I listened to the audiobook, so it is very possible this will not be the case in print. But the timeline jumps around a few times and I found it hard to figure out what was happening a few times.The characters are all assholes. Which, I typically do not mind. But Jake was the worst sort- incredibly arrogant and I found him difficult to read. I felt like I wanted to punch him at all times.Now- the "plot"- I had an inkling of where the book within a book was going fairly early on. And I was correct. I also figured out where the other plot was going, as well. I actually figured out the villain as soon as they entered the story. So adding that to the fact that it took forever to get going, this made the book very disappointing. I kept reading to know what this fantastic plot was, only to be completely underwhelmed.As I said, I listened to the audiobook. I did not enjoy the narration, but I really think it was more the book than the narrator. The narrator was paced well and enunciated well. However, as mentioned before, especially the beginning was difficult to follow at times. Also my extreme disdain for Jake made me annoyed by the narration. Basically, if you decide to read this, I would try the print version. This did not translate to an audiobook well. This is coming from someone who almost exclusively listens to audiobooks since I listen while at work. 75+ per year. I was given an audiobook in exchange for an honest review.

Devious, simmering, and ominous!The Plot is a twisty, character-driven thriller featuring the frustrated, disheartened writer Jacob Finch Bonner who, after having a respectable but not highly successful first novel and now unfortunately stuck in the disappointing role as teacher for a subpar MFA program, has no reservations when the opportunity presents itself to borrow a unique storyline from one of his previous, now deceased students, in order to become the world-class, successful writer he‚Äôs always known he can be.The prose is tight and intense. The characters are multilayered, consumed, and vulnerable. And the intricate, intriguing plot builds nicely to create just the right amount of tension and suspense, as it unravels all the manipulative personalities, questionable motivations, duplicitous actions, and complex relationships within it.Overall, The Plot is a compelling, cunning, tragic novel by Korelitz that started off a little slow for me but by a third of the way through, with its story within a story, the momentum started to ramp up, and it quickly became an addictive, enthralling read I couldn‚Äôt get enough of.Thank you to Celadon Books for providing me with a copy in exchange for an honest review.

A book within a book - like a play within a play - does not always work; in this case, both books being written piqued my interest. But our Jake Bonner - the writer of one of the tales - is no Hamlet. Jake is an entitled author of one somewhat notable first novel, and not very introspective regarding his failure to replicate his early success. Instead, we see Jake moping and feeling very very sorry for himself as he struggles to make a living as a once-touted young author. Until he writes his soon-to-be-Spielberg-produced-phenomenon.Korelitz does a fantastic job painting Jake's sins in the gray area - a real reader's book, a real writer's book - to whom does a story belong? And who has the right to write it?The twist in The Plot is evident as soon as the twist in Jake's fictional blockbuster, Crib, is revealed to us but the ride to the end is still thoroughly thrilling. Does the bad guy - the worst guy - ever win? The answer is, of course, sometimes.Thank you Netgalley for this preview!

I am so torn between my feelings about this book. I had been looking forward to reading it because it had so many great reviews. It started out with vivid descriptions of the creative writing and academic worlds, which I enjoyed. The style of writing at the beginning is sophisticated and detail oriented. I enjoyed the premise of the story and was curious to see where the author was going to take me in my reading. Yet somewhere along the line, the story began to lose me. Lack of suspense? Too much unnecessary detail? Too many "coincidences" of people just happening to fall into Jake's immediate presence at the exact times he needed them to? I cannot put my finger on it. However, I personally did not see the end coming in this one, so when it began to happen, I was naturally glued to my book until I finished it. I would rate it 3 1/2 to 4 stars. There are some very strong parts to the story, yet cliche driven parts in others. Yes, I am torn on this one.

This one started slow and went up and down for me throughout the book. As a reader, I was trying to figure things out with the main character, which I liked. A few of the details were getting mixed up for me so I really had to think throughout it. It was also very much a literary fiction, which is not my comfort zone so I had to get a bit used to that. There was one aspect I wish was included, I wish we could have seen Jacob actually writing the book and see his guilt struggle through the writing process. But overall it was good and the ending was fantastic, I really liked the way it ended.*Huge thanks to the publisher for sending a free review copy to read!

It took me a little while to get in to this, but once I did I really enjoyed it. I guess you'd call it a literary thriller, it's not heart pounding but it carries a quiet sense of building unease which I think I prefer, it reminded me a little of Peter Swanson and that's always a good thing. The "novel within a novel" thing was cleverly done and though I pretty much guessed the main character's anonymous tormentor, I was keen to read on to see if I was right, enjoying the little twists and turns on the way, a satisfying 4 stars.
This is one where I read the synopsis and could feel my eyes bulging and eyebrows rising. Sounds SO good!Hey Celadon wanna hook a girl up????
Every writer should read this, but then again everyone should read it. Such a fun ride. Sure to be one of my favorites of the year.

Based on a well-received (but not well-sold) first novel, Jacob Finch Bonner has managed to secure a gig teaching writing at a low-residential program at a decently respectable small college in Vermont. He expects it to go like every other class he‚Äôs taught ‚Äî that is, nothing will come of it for any of his students. But then, one student says he has a plot that‚Äôs never been seen before, guaranteed to be a bestseller because even people who don‚Äôt read will want to read it, that will make its author rich and famous, and that will be made into a blockbuster movie by an A-list director ‚Äî every single one of every writer‚Äôs dreams all come true. After being told The Plot, Jacob ruefully agrees that this is indeed a likely scenario. But then ‚Ä¶ the book never appears. And, seeing and seizing an opportunity, Jacob decides to write it himself.
I probably wouldn‚Äôt have read this book if it hadn‚Äôt been for the writing aspect of the plot. And I really did enjoy that part of the story. It made me both laugh and squirm in recognition of authorly behaviors and thought processes. The rest of it, though ‚Ä¶ eh, very much a mixed bag. I ended up finding quite a bit of this book to be tedious. I think my problem was mostly that we‚Äôre told about that awesome Plot very early on. Then we have to wait ‚Ä¶ and wait ‚Ä¶ and wait to find out what it is. For me, there was probably no way The Plot was going to live up to all that anticipation, and sadly it did not. (I was definitely straining my brain to figure out what it could possibly be.) The road to the reveal shows Jacob‚Äôs new life as a famous writer, traveling the country to appear on various talk shows and at bookstores and concert halls (rockstar writer for real!) At intersections along this road, so to speak, are excerpts from Jake‚Äôs bestselling book. And they mystified me. I found them a combination of depressing and dull, written in a way that I probably wouldn‚Äôt make it through 50 pages of in a real book. I couldn‚Äôt believe anyone would read that entire novel, no matter what kind of incredible twist it was supposed to promise. Most interesting to me was that a few pages of the original author‚Äôs novel are also included, and I found his writing far more engaging. Jake keeps congratulating himself throughout the story on how much better his version is, but I wonder if that‚Äôs a sort of joke on him by the author. Then Jake starts getting emails from someone who knows he stole the book. And then, for me, the pace of the book went off-track. Jake would get an email ‚Ä¶ and then there would be pages and pages about his domestic life. Another email, and more pages of utter mundanity. The Person Who Knows starts a Twitter feed, and Jake feeds the cat. Etc. This pattern went on for about 50 to 100 pages too long for me. It should have felt suspenseful, and apparently does to other readers going by their reviews, but I was about ready to flip to the end to see what the twists were and chuck the book back to the library. I only read the entire thing to be sure I can give it a fair review. The story picked up steam when Jake finally started trying to track down his mystery harasser. This section was fast-paced and intriguing, and I hung on every word. We (at long last) learn what the twist in The Plot was (but I didn‚Äôt care any more, and I found it more sad than shocking). And then there is a Big Twist in Jake‚Äôs story, which I should have seen coming, but didn‚Äôt because I hadn‚Äôt cared enough to pay attention (and semi-spoiler I never read  Housekeeping, either; I did see the movie but sure don‚Äôt remember the details). So at least that did surprise me. I have a few issues with the Big Twist for Jake:First, I question that anyone can fake being a loving wife and empathetic, caring person for nearly a full year. I know sociopaths are supposed to be able to be charming and all, but so consistently, to everyone, for such a long time? Maybe I question that because I have a hard time pretending to like people I don‚Äôt, even in small doses (luckily, I like most people). But it seems to me that a person with a generally bitter nature would find it challenging to come across as so sweet all the time, without ever dropping the facade. Second, why did Di/Anna feel she needed to murder her daughter? The kid was moving out, and Di/Anna could have just packed up and left Vermont and done whatever she wanted, wherever she wanted. She barely made use of that scholarship, although maybe she would have stuck it out the full 4 years if she hadn‚Äôt also murdered her brother and gotten the money from the house, which freed her up to be herself again (sort of). Last, why send those emails and start that Twitter account, etc.? Nobody thought Jacob‚Äôs book was based on a true story, but even anonymously asserting that it was a stolen story risked somebody tracing those accounts and finding out it was not just stolen, but also true. Sheesh, why take that risk?This was a decently entertaining read, and would have gotten 4 stars if I hadn‚Äôt been so bored in the middle of the book.

A lot of fun. Witty and amusing throughout. I was slow reading/listening at first, but by the middle I picked up the pace, and so did The Plot. Did I suspect what was to come? Yes, but it didn‚Äôt matter for me. I enjoyed the journey to the conclusion. Will recommend!

The Plot, it thickens as you read it! It starts out as a slow burn, but then it grabs you and pulls you in, at least it did for me. This was a suspenseful thriller based on an author, Jacob (Jake) Finch Bonner, who is trying to write books but just not quite making it at first, so he resorts to teaching a creative writing class at the local college. One day he reads just a couple pages of his student, Evan Parker's, manuscript and can tell he is on to something big. He tries to tell him, but the student is so arrogant and rude he gets nowhere with him. Years later, Jake is trying to come up with an idea for his next novel and he remembers Evan Parker's manuscript. He curiously looks him up to see if he ever did write the book, but finds out that not only did he not write it, but he died not too long after he last saw him. Jake decides to write the book based on the basic idea, since he had only seen a couple pages, and then made up the rest. His novel is a smashing success and he becomes famous and rich. Fast forward to later, Jake met a woman, Anna, at a book signing, they fell in love, got married, they are happy, life is good, they live in New York, and he is busy working on his next new novel. Then, bam! Just like that Jake starts getting messages from someone who calls themselves "Talented Tom" accusing him of book theft, plot theft and plagiarism. Jake is horrified, terrified and has no idea who it is, since he knows Evan Parker is dead! Jake also basically knows that he didn't steal the story, since he only saw a couple of pages and wrote the rest himself, but since he is getting threats he feels guilty. Eventually the threats ramp up and his publisher gets involved and brings in a lawyer. They assure him that this always happens to famous authors and that as long as he did not blatantly steal from a published book or story he has nothing to worry about. But STILL, Jake is worried, Jake feels guilt deep inside. Guilt will eat away at your rational thoughts and actions like ants, and make you do irrational things... This story has many more aspects to it, much more happens and it keeps you wanting to know what will happen next, and just who is Talented Tom? You will not want to put this one down until the thrilling ending. I gave this audiobook 4 suspenseful stars! Get yours today, you won't regret it! I would like to thank #NetGalley, the publisher Macmillan Audio, and the author Jean Hanff Korelitz for this audioARC in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Jacob Finch Bonner is struggling to write his second novel after his first book was a modest success, however, things aren‚Äôt going as well as he thought. His success and experience make him the perfect candidate to teach at Ripley‚Äôs a writer‚Äôs workshop/retreat. This is where he encounters Evan Parker, a loud, arrogant guy who claims he has the perfect plot. A plot no writer could mess up, a guaranteed success, and Even claims he doesn‚Äôt need any sort of teaching to help him along. When Jacob hears the plot he‚Äôs stunned, because Jacob thinks Evan is right. This plot will catapult this asshole into fame, giving Evan everything Jacob has ever dreamed of as a writer: Critical acclaim, book tours, a spot on Oprah‚Äôs Book Club Couch. Years later when Jacob‚Äôs prospects keep dwindling as his new books are rejected over and over he‚Äôs reduced to taking odd editing jobs and the random writer‚Äôs workshop. His situation is depressing but things are about to change when Jacob discovers that not long after Ripley‚Äôs Evan died without ever writing ‚ÄúThe Book‚Äù. Here is a once in a lifetime plot that begs to be told and who better than Jacob? Jacob writes the story and it‚Äôs exactly as predicted: fame, accolades, movie deal, and here‚Äôs when the other shoe drops. Jacob gets an email calling him a thief. Jacob was a bit self-absorbed and pretentious, but I couldn‚Äôt help but root for this guy! His life was going downhill, and I have a soft spot for the underdog! I didn‚Äôt even feel bad when he sort of lifted the idea (although, apparently you can‚Äôt copyright a plot) off of Evan, because who wants a jerk to win and come out ahead? Evan is dead and didn‚Äôt leave anyone who cared about him behind, so who‚Äôs sending the threatening emails? Jacob must go back and investigate Evan and his background to find out. The Plot was captivating even when things are pretty calm at the beginning! I had my suspicions, but even so when things started to come together I had that ‚Äúaha!‚Äù moment where I was shocked! Love being taken by surprise!I‚Äôm familiar with Kirby Heyborne as a narrator and have enjoyed his performances in the past. I loved him as the quiet, flawed Jacob Finch Bonner! I listened at my normal 1.5x normal speed.A copy was kindly provided by Macmillan Audio via Netgalley in exchange for an honest review.

Just who owns an idea?Accountability, accusations, ownership, creative license"The Plot‚Äù is both the title and the main character of the book by Jean Hanff Korelitz. ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù controls the action; it is present on every page. It has personality and power. If a writer does not do right by the magnificent idea that has chosen him or her, among all possible writers, ‚ÄùThe Plot‚Äù will just move on to someone else. A great story must be told. Such a story found Jacob Finch Bonner, but he was not the first author to whom ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù was given. Bonner was the renowned author of a best-selling book, but his subsequent books had not been commercially successful. As a result of this publication slump, he was teaching creative writing. ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù was first given to Evan Parker, a young man in one of Bonner‚Äôs classes. The young man did not publish ‚ÄúThe Plot,‚Äù and in fact, died. Bonner felt a responsibility, a duty even, to the story. He became obsessed with it. He had not seen Parker‚Äôs whole story, just a little of ‚ÄúThe Plot,‚Äù but he recognized the powerful and exciting theme; this was a story that would sell millions of copies. When Bonner published his book, he was careful to craft something new, not identical to Parker‚Äôs original work, but still ‚ÄúThe Plot.‚Äù After all, he thought, one cannot copyright a plot; the same ‚Äústories‚Äù have been told and retold for generations. Then something happens that changes everything for Jacob Finch Bonner. ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù is filled with unusual twists and turns. Readers immediately know that something is fundamentally wrong, wrong with the situation, wrong with the publication, wrong with Bonner. Too many things do not add up, and too many things are just too easy. Even Bonner himself wishes that he had not been so utterly and fatally wrong. In the end, ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù wins, and wins in a dramatic, traumatic, and inevitable way. There is also a nice shout-out to author Craig Johnson when a character spends a couple of productive weeks writing at the Ucross Center in Wyoming.

I‚Äôm predicting this book will be a great one for bookclub discussions. With a twisty plot, some unreliable characters and a lot of bookish banter, it has a lot to offer readers.Jake Bonner is a bit of a ‚Äúone-hit wonder.‚Äù His first book was published and popular in some areas, but after that he has published nothing notable and is in a writing slump. When he decides to teach a writing class, Jake has a student that stands out. Not because he‚Äôs a great writer, but because he is an awfully rude person and is so arrogant he believes he has a plot that is certain to become a novel that will be a huge bestseller. He tells Jake a summary of the plot before the course ends and then they go their separate ways.Fast forward a few months and Jake is still a struggling writer when one day he learns of the death of his former student with the bestselling plot line. Jake discovers the student never published anything so he decides to write his own story based on the plot that seems to be a sure hit.Jake soars to fame and at the height of it, he begins to get anonymous messages from someone that knows he stole the plot from his student. The meat of the story centers around Jake‚Äôs search for the source of his anonymous messages and his discovery of what really happened to his former student and the members of his family.I found the beginning incredibly dull and I had to make myself keep reading and then the next thing I knew I could not put it aside. It really gained steam the last half of the book and I ended up really liking the story. A great one to have a discussion about with other readers!Many thanks to NetGalley and Celadon Books for allowing me to read an advance copy and give my honest review.

3.75üíéi just finished the e-book of this & ok but whAT IS THIS ENDING HOLY SHIT. i didn't see certain plot twists coming at all lmaoo, it got me thinking about how can someone even do such a thing. also it's crazy how the name of this book has such a double meaning, it's just horrible istg. anyway, i did enjoy this story, it's unique and involves books/writing/publishing which is always something i absolutely love to read about. and it's a thriller, a huge bonus. the idea of it all is so well thought of, i hardly know any mystery/thriller books similar to this one.i also really felt for Jake, all he's been thru and how he felt about it all throughout the book.however... i didn't really vibe with the writing style. i don't even know how to explain it but it's just not something i personally like. the main character also kept repeating himself all the time about some things which i also found annoying. tbh, it was mainly the writing style and protagonist's inner thoughts what made me give such rating. it was good, but not my all time favorite!

I really wanted to like this book. Heck, the first 90% or so of it had be gripped and eager to devour the next page. The story was compelling and unique, the unraveling of the mystery was tense, the prose excellent, and the characters engaging. I was racing through it to the reveal and conclusion of the mystery. And then...And then...And then that "twist" happened and I was most discontented. Mostly because I thought it came out of left field and did not fit with the facts the reader was privy to. It almost felt like a twist for a twist's sake. I did not think it was earned and really diminished the rest of the book in my opinion.But hey, you might like it and think it was a brilliant change in direction. And I did enjoy about 90% of it, so don't let me naysaying discourage you from giving it a whirl. I just doubt I will invest any more time in works by this author, too many other books out there whose authors have not betrayed me.

4.5 rounded up because whoaaaaaa- This had one of the most original plots (ha) in a book I've ever read!! I loved the unique premise of this book, it def falls more into the suspense category (and very literary style writing) as opposed to a thriller so I think I went into it with false expectations but still really enjoyed it! it lost me a bit in the middle but the final third was brilliant with some truly unexpected twists.

Absolutely not what I expected. Like not at all. Good slow burn. I think readers will be surprised by this one. Watch your local little libraries on the 15th of April 2021. You may get lucky and find a copy.

This one was a miss for me. I had it figured out pretty quickly and it was too slow paced for me. By 60% into the book nothing had really even happened yet even though I was pretty sure I knew the ending. If you like slow burn, this may be the right kind of book for you.
Good sorbet to begin the new year.

The Plot*Review*Jacob Finch Bonner is teaching aspiring authors after enjoying only mild success with his own first novel. He‚Äôs frustrated and depressed. When the opportunity arises for him to steal a student‚Äôs idea for a novel, he takes it. When he finally achieves wild success and believes he has fully justified his theft, he starts receiving messages from someone who possibly knows what he has done. But as time goes by, who exactly stole from whom? Every once in awhile I totally miss out on a book. The Plot was one such book. I loved the story and also the story in a story. The author is clever and I truly appreciate the many layers of the story.

Actual rating: 3.5 stars For the first half of this book, I was glued to the page. The writing style was a little strange for a thriller- long, blocky paragraphs with little dialogue and lots of telling instead of showing, but I was captivated by the story. At around the halfway point, I knew what the ending would be and it stopped being as interesting. And the fact that the main character was so oblivious to what was going on felt a little too unreal to me. And the epilogue at the end seemed so unnecessary. So while I think this book will work great for lots of readers, especially if they don't see the ending coming early on in the story, it wasn't that great of a thriller for me.

A creative writing teacher has a student with a brilliant book idea. The student dies and the teacher thinks that maybe he can write the student‚Äôs story and no one would know.A bit of a slow burn that still kept me interested until the last 1/4 of the book grabbed me. Don‚Äôt read tell-all reviews to prevent ruining the fantastic ending.

The Plot is hard to review without you know . . .giving away the Plot. I didn't really know this was a mystery/thriller going into it. I really enjoyed the beginning where we meet a disenchanted writing instructor and his difficult, unpleasant student. The student has this terrific plot idea and a few pages of his novel. He reveals the plot to the instructor after being unwilling to share it with anyone, and that kicks off the heart and mystery of the story.For me, the best parts of the book were some of the ethical issues that were raised about novel ideas and to whom they actually belong. The mystery itself was fine, but by the latter third of the book, it was getting boring. I feel they could have cut a bunch of pages without losing much.The end got my adrenaline going, and I liked it. Others said they saw it coming, but I definitely didn't. All in all, solid and entertaining, but I don't think this is a genre that really excites me all that much. I felt almost identical about The Woman in the Window. I just don't find them that riveting for whatever reason. It's a bummer because I used to enjoy books like this a lot more. The fact that this book overlays an interesting ethical question definitely made it more engaging overall.

This book‚Ä¶ There's something unique about this book. I think it‚Äôs the writing style and voice of the main character but I honestly can‚Äôt put my finger on it specifically! I thought the premise for ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù was intriguing and it kept my interest the whole way following the mystery. The pacing took some getting used to since months/years would pass in a page or two, but it was always directly started so you don‚Äôt get lost and there was always a purpose for the time jump. This is a HUGE improvement from the author‚Äôs previous novel ‚ÄúYou Should Have Known‚Äù which I did not like. Like I would not be able to tell you this was the same author if I just read the pages! The writing flows nicely and the present day is interspersed with short excerpts from Jake‚Äôs novel, consistently building suspense and tension. A little slow in the beginning and repetitive at times, but I loved the ending and don‚Äôt want to spoil it so I won‚Äôt say anything more! ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù was a twisty, fun, addictive novel that I would recommend picking up upon release in May! Thank you so much to Celadon Books for my gifted copy! 4.5 stars

A very interesting premise. I don't even know what to say about this one. It's a great book, and it really gives you insight into human behavior. I honestly did not see the ending coming, I thought someone was the "bad guy" but then told myself I was wrong. And then I found out I was partially right. I will say though the reason why I am giving this 4 stars and not 5 is that the first part of the book starts off really slow (push through) and then we get the ending which I thought was cold (and I loved it by the way). But having the "bad guy" do a villain monologue took away from things a bit. I rather it had been short and to the point to make it more devastating.¬†"The Plot" follows Jacob Finch Bonner. Once seen as the next bright young thing in the literary world, Jacob after some failed releases is now teaching MFA at a low level college in Vermont. When Jacob meets a student named Evan Parker whose excerpt causes his imagination to start firing again, Jacob feels jealous of the young man. Jacob knows that Evan's story is going to be a blockbuster and waits to hear about it. And when the story never comes, and Jacob finds out Evan has died, well Jacob starts thinking.....and then we jump forward to Jacob's novel "Crib" taking the literary world by storm. But when some anonymous person gets on social media and calls him a "thief" Jacob gets worried that someone out there knows what he did. And from there we follow Jacob as he finds out more about Evan Parker's life and death.So at times I felt so much sympathy for Jacob. I can't imagine how it feels to have been on top (somewhat) of the world and to find your life not working out the way you want it to. And when you get to "read" Jacob's justifications for what he does, you can almost see and agree with his point of view. But as Jacob plays detective and finds out more about Evan Parker my sympathy for him left. He doesn't seem to care about Evan or the rest of his family. And heck he even uses a former student that was friends with Evan to find out what he could possibly know. Jacob is just focused on not being found out.¬†The secondary characters that come the most alive to me though or the characters we read about in the excerpts from "Crib". Jacob can write. He has a way with words. You feel for the characters and I kept wanting/wishing that we had that standalone novel somewhere where we could read it. I usually don't like a story within a story, but Korelitz did a great job with this and showcasing Jacob's writing along with his quest (yes we find out the major plots that all books follow in this one).¬†The writing was very good, I liked how developed everyone was in this. I felt things as I was reading this and shook my head a few times and even gasped here and there. The flow was a bit off to start with though. I think things don't pick up until after we see Jacob's success. The first few pages/chapters had me going good grief.The book setting moves around a lot, we have New York, Seattle, Vermont, and even down south.¬†The ending though was great. Except for the longish monologue. I loved the epilogue though.¬†

Meet Jake Finch Bonner ... he's an author of a couple of books and while neither were greatly received, it was enough to land him a position of teaching in a small program. He's written a couple of others , but he still carries them around in his briefcase .. unseen by anyone else.In his classroom of maybe a dozen wanna-be authors is Evan Parker. Parker brags that he doesn't really need to be taught anything at all .... he has the greatest plot ever. Jake is prepared to dismiss his bragging .. until he hears the plot.Bonner accepts that his writing career is over, and he waits patiently for Parker's book to be published. When he discovers that his former student has died, presumably without ever completing his book, Jake does what any self-respecting writer would do with a story like that‚Äîa story that absolutely needs to be told.It's called plagiarism.And once Bonner receives accolades for "his" newest book, he receives an anonymous email .. someone knows his secret. It escalates .. emails, twitter, threats sent to his home, his publisher....(BOOK BLURB) As Jake struggles to understand his antagonist and hide the truth from his readers and his publishers, he begins to learn more about his late student, and what he discovers both amazes and terrifies him. Who was Evan Parker, and how did he get the idea for his ‚Äúsure thing‚Äù of a novel? What is the real story behind the plot, and who stole it from whom?With an intricate plot and deftly drawn characters, it's quite a journey to get the answers to the questions Bonner should have asked before he decided to steal another's words. The suspense starts at the very first and steadily holds until the unexpected conclusion.Many thanks to the author / Macmillan Publishers / Macmillan Reading Insiders Club / Netgalley for the digital copy of this excellent psychological fiction. Read and reviewed voluntarily, opinions expressed here are unbiased and entirely my own.

The first time I started this I had to put it down. I was absolutely not in the mood for Jacob and spending a whole book with him. The second time was easier, I knew ahead of time that I hated the protagonist, and I did it on audio which often means I am less picky about such things. And I'm glad I did because I really enjoyed it.The way Korelitz had me really hating this man but made him just smart enough and just capable of change enough to not totally detest him was a tightrope walk but she pulled it off. It opens the door to a plot that is a lot of fun to turn around in your head, that echoes a lot of the current questions around what is ethical for writers to use in their fiction. At first, though, a lot of things about the titular plot annoyed me. I rolled my eyes at the idea of a "silver bullet plot." But after a while I let myself go with it. I let the book exist in a kind of surreal world where an idea can be a sure thing. (There is no idea that is a sure thing!) So when we got to the details of the actual plot it was an inevitable let down. This is a common problem in thrillers, keeping a secret for too long, hyping it too much, can create a disappointing third act. This one wasn't so terrible, but it definitely wasn't an actual silver bullet plot. And I often found myself missing the idea of the book as a work of surrealist satire rather than the more real world thriller it ended up being. But at least Korelitz knew how to up the ante and give a nice twisty ending. It was, in the end, satisfying. So I forgive the book for being what it is and not what I imagined. It is a fine line, though. Some thriller readers will find this takes much too long to get started. Some literary readers may find that it's too much of a thriller for their taste. But I think it's a nice sweet spot and we could use more like it. Just maybe with protagonists I don't hate quite so much. :)

This was a fun one! One of those books you race through, and think about when you're not reading it. I think Korelitz sets herself up at a bit of a disadvantage by describing the book-within-a-book in quite such gushing praise, describing it as having the most incredible twist in the entire world, and utterly unlike any other book that's ever been written ‚Äì¬†this could have been tongue-in-cheek self-consciousness, except that every character agrees that it's incredible, and it's a massive hit, instant bestseller, Spielberg making the movie etc. There are extracts of this incredible novel, and sure, it's fun, but it's just a good-quality thriller. It was quite easy to guess both the twist in the book (as in, who the culprit was) and also the twist in the book-within-a-book ‚Äì¬†it was so obvious that it grew frustrating to watch the protagonist bumble around not knowing what was happening. But I don't mind if I guess the end of a book as long as the journey to get there is still enjoyable, and in this case it definitely was. Other reviewers have said that the beginning is slow, and it is compared to the rest, but I still enjoyed it ‚Äì mostly because Korelitz is so scathingly accurate about the life of a midlist writer, and that stuff is catnip for me. If you've been looking for a fun, smart, absorbing thriller, this is certainly worth a read.

4 stars--I really liked it. Literary and twisty, this book engaged me on every page.
