This one left me scratching my head and feeling, once again, like I'm missing something everyone else was utterly thrilled by.A great deal of this review is going to have to go under spoiler tags because my "eh" reaction along with the reason for my new shelf "wait, what?" can really only be explained by getting into the meat of this story.I think that this book wants to be a great deal deeper than it actually is. As the story begins we meet the pretentiously named Jake Finch Bonner (the Finch is his own entirely unironic creation because he loves To Kill a Mockingbird) who is a washed up writer once considered "new and notable" by the Times but now relegated to teaching in a backwater, equally washed up writing school. Jake has lots to say about writing and how much he loves it. Lots and lots and lots. None of it is terribly interesting. Which I think is the point but is, nonetheless, not super fun to read about.As the latest semester of the writing program begins he meets one of his new students, a giant, flaming asshole who swears, loudly and frequently, that he is about to become the greatest novelist in the history of novel writing because he has the greatest story ever that no one has ever told before and it is so amazing that it will immediately be published, adored by millions, optioned into a film and propel him to fame and fortune forever. Jake scoffs at this. The few pages he's permitted to read of this supposedly brilliant book are fine, but nothing to write home about. But then in a private meeting with giant, flaming asshole he's told just what this story is and he realizes...giant, flaming asshole is right! This is the single greatest story in the history of novels! It will immediately be published, adored by millions, optioned into a film and propel giant, flaming asshole to fame and fortune forever! The seminar ends and giant, flaming asshole leaves to write the greatest novel ever written. But as the years pass and the greatest novel ever written never appears Jake begins to wonder what on earth has happened to giant flaming asshole? Why did he never pull the trigger on his masterpiece?A quick internet search reveals that Jake now has a choice. And when he makes it he will decide the course of the rest of his life and attract the ire of a dangerous enemy.So, on to my issues of which there are four. The first three absolutely contain spoilers so if you have any desire to read this go no further. Number 1: The question of morals and ethics...is kind of a non-starter Jake discovers that giant, flaming asshole died before getting the chance to write his book. So he takes the basic plot he learned at the writers conference and uses it to write the book himself. And I mean I get it, we're supposed to get into a deep debate over whether or not Jake is a plagiarist. We're supposed to think that the person who starts threatening him with exposure for his "theft" is at least sort of justified. But he's not a thief. He's just not. Should he maybe have revealed that he heard this story from someone and decided to use it? Yeah I guess but he didn't steal someone's manuscript and then write his name on it. Its just nowhere even close to the same thing. There's just no debate here.Number 2: The greatest novel ever written...is very much not the greatest novel ever written Not only has the story absolutely been told approximately a million times, (I can think of like three novels with the same plot just off the top of my head) it was lame all those times too! Here it is! A disaffected, overachieving teen is forced by her shitty parents to have a baby she doesn't want. She raises the baby until she too is a disaffected, overachieving teen but they kind of hate each other and then one day accidentally (?) mom kills her and kinda sorta assumes her identity to live the life she never got to have. The end.The book reveals this plot slowly because clearly the point is that the reader is meant to be totally shocked by the reveal that the mother kills her own daughter. Much is made over this "crazy twist" that no one sees coming and how very shocking it all is and I was waiting for, I don't know, aliens? ghosts? they're the same person? (that actually would have been cool) only to arrive at a very mundane story that I've seen every where from Law and Order to V.C. Andrews novels.Number 3: The big bad is...just silly After Jake writes his book its not long before he begins receiving increasingly terrifying messages from someone who knows he didn't come up with this story on his own. In all fairness why this person is tormenting him is pretty cool. I definitely got invested enough it what was happening to Jake and his fears of someone revealing that he'd "stolen" his story that I forgot to even wonder what the motivation would be for someone to try to out him. The reveal that giant, flaming assholes story was never his but was in fact stolen from someone else isn't enough to detract from the utter ridiculousness of whose it in fact is. Its doubly annoying because, if you know how these things work at all, its very, very simple to pick out the villain the second they're introduced and then everything unfolds exactly as you assumed it would. The character was introduced, I went "oh they're the one" and several hundred pages later I was right. This does NOT make me a genius, it makes the story lame and predictable.Number 4: The writingSo this one is all personal preference and should be taken as such. Jean Hanff Korelitz is a perfectly fine writer but I found the "voice" of this book especially grating. This is the first book of hers I've read so I don't know if its her style or a conscience choice but there are just so many italicized phrases and parentheticals and asides that I could never decide whether they were intended to be ironic and meant to paint Jake Banner as a pretentious nitwit or were actually supposed to be witty bon mots and winks to the reader. The "quipping" just became too much after a point. Like by page three.Then we come to the insertion of excerpts from the greatest novel ever written. There's virtually no change from the story of Jake's travails and the chapters devoted to his novel. Again, this is a personal preference but since this is not a first person narration completely in Jake's voice I'd expect at least some stylistic choices to indicate I'm reading two very different things. Something that tells me the difference between the fact and the fiction. Magpie Murders is a great example of an author who does this brilliantly. Instead we get the same dry if acceptable prose and the same dry if acceptable voice and I'm left, once again, wondering what in the world everyone thinks is so amazing about either of these books.I don't know if this was a simple case of too much hype spoiling the broth or if I just read too many mysteries or if there really is nothing new under the sun.I can't help but feel that had we never learned what the greatest story every told was this would have been a very different kind of book. Until it began to be unveiled in all its lackluster glory I was genuinely on the edge of my seat wondering about how amazing it must be. Of course given how the rest of the plot unfolds it wouldn't make any sense to have done this but if this was really going to be a book about the ownership of an idea and what stories writers have the right to tell it would have been super neat to leave readers having to tell it themselves.

The premise of the story is a compelling one. An author of a moderately successful novel has been trying to write another to establish his writing credentials. Although he has written several additional books, none has been remotely successful or even attracted much attention. Jake Bonner makes his living teaching writing seminars to graduate students. He spends his spare time agonizing over his writing attempts and at the prospects of ever reclaiming his career.Jake teaches one particularly irritating student. Evan Parker is obnoxious, arrogant, and overly confident, but he also happens to be a gifted writer. Parker reveals his plot for a book he is starting to write. Bonner is stunned and envious. Parker‚Äôs plot is so ingenious that it would be a crowning achievement for a seasoned writer, let alone a debut author. After the seminar concludes, Bonner loses touch with his former student. In the back of his mind, Bonner always expects to hear about the release of Parker‚Äôs book. Meanwhile, his career continues to decline. One fateful day, Bonner learns that Parker is deceased, never having written his book. The temptation is too great for him. Using the story‚Äôs plot, he writes his own book. It becomes an overnight sensation and bestseller.Suddenly, Bonner is in the spotlight again. His calendar fills with book tours and speaking engagements. He starts a relationship with a woman, Anna Williams, and they move in together. Not all of the attention, however, is welcome. Bonner starts to get emails from an anonymous person who claims he is a thief. The emails become more frequent and threatening. They promise exposure through social media. Bonner‚Äôs life which had been looking so bright with possibility becomes one of paranoia. Now he has someone and something to lose, Anna, and his newfound reputation. Bonner takes dangerous risks to avoid being exposed.Jean Hanff Korelitz has written a novel I raced through because of its plot, intensity, and unbeatable story. The work is well-written and has an incredible ending. This was a terrific read anyone with a curiosity about a writer‚Äôs inner life needs to get. It‚Äôs also a smartly crafted mystery.

It‚Äôs not an exaggeration to say that The Plot is an unputdownable page-turner. I finished it within 24 hours ‚Äî I just couldn‚Äôt stand waiting to see how it all turned out!In The Plot, our focus is on Jacob Finch Bonner, a has-been writer who burst onto the literary scene years earlier with a well-reviewed first book, then flamed out on his second book and couldn‚Äôt even find a publisher for his third or fourth. He can‚Äôt bring himself to write, and supports himself through teaching at a mediocre MFA program that‚Äôs open to anyone who wants to write, no competitive admissions process required.When the super obnoxious Evan Parker shows up for Jake‚Äôs class, Evan is dismissive and rude, and asserts that he‚Äôs just there to get the initials MFA into his credentials. He insists his plot is amazing, can‚Äôt fail, and will make what he writes a huge bestseller and get him a major movie deal. Jake can‚Äôt believe Evan‚Äôs arrogance, but when he finally coaxes the plot out of Evan, he has to reluctantly agree that Evan has something unique and possibly quite valuable. Of course, it‚Äôs insulting that Evan insists that it doesn‚Äôt take writing talent to make a great book ‚Äî all that‚Äôs needed is a great plot, and he has one.Years go by, and Jake supports himself through online teaching and an editing business. But when he hears that Evan has died, he‚Äôs curious about the plot of his book. Surely, if someone had published such a story, he would have known. After googling and poking around, Jake becomes certain that Evan never did write his book‚Ä¶ and since the plot was never used and never truly left Jake‚Äôs mind, well, why not?Jake‚Äôs book is everything that Evan knew his plot would lead to. Crib is a huge bestseller, an Oprah book, and is about to be optioned by Stephen Spielberg. But Jake‚Äôs success is disturbed when he receives an email calling him a thief. His anxiety leads him into a deeper look into Evan‚Äôs life, and the more he digs, the more he understands about how someone like Evan could have come up with this amazing plot in the first place.I can‚Äôt go into more detail than that, because spoiling this book would be unforgivable! Suffice it to say that Jake‚Äôs investigation reveals plenty of weirdness and unexpected twists, and I found it fascinating.The Plot gives us a lot to think about, both in terms of the book‚Äôs storyline and the suspenseful elements, but also in terms of the world and inner life of a writer. As one character points out, ideas can‚Äôt be copyrighted. So if someone has a story idea but never uses it, and someone else knows about the idea and does use it, is it stealing? On the surface, yes‚Ä¶ maybe? Was it ethical for Jake to write a book based on a plot concept that, as far he knows, was never used and was never even written beyond the draft of a first chapter? If Jake took the story outline he heard from Evan and turned into a compelling novel, was that Jake‚Äôs work in reality? How much credit, if any, does he owe to Evan? The questions are fascinating to think about, and my feelings and opinions on these issues continued to change throughout the novel.I did pretty much nail the biggest plot twist early on, but that doesn‚Äôt mean that I truly figured it all out. I may have had a good idea of the ‚Äúwhat‚Äù, but the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and the ‚Äúhow‚Äù were surprising and really well put-together, and I loved all the little ups and downs of Jake‚Äôs search for the truth.I will say that the very end was not what I expected, and I‚Äôm still struggling with it! Not because it doesn‚Äôt work ‚Äî it absolutely does! But I will say that my sense of fairness feels upset. This is not the ending I wanted for the characters‚Ä¶ but it totally works in a very creepy sort of way.The Plot has lots of disturbing developments, but it‚Äôs not graphically violent. As I said, beyond the actual intrigue and action, I also appreciated the thoughts on a writer‚Äôs life, the highs and lows of success as an author, and the various questions brought up about who gets to tell whose stories and whether it‚Äôs true to say that each person has a story that‚Äôs uniquely theirs to tell.I think one sign that The Plot is really well done is that even though I felt disappointed by some of Jake‚Äôs actions and decisions and what these say about his morality or lack thereof, I still rooted for him and cared enough about him to want him to find a way out of the increasingly perilous place he finds himself.The Plot is one of the buzziest books this summer, and with good reason. It‚Äôs a fast, engrossing story that kept me hooked until the very end. Check it out!

The tone of The Plot is like a snarkier version of Less ‚Äì meets Crime And Punishment, meets I Know What You Did Last Summer. It‚Äôs a delightful take-down of the publishing industrial complex and the Writer As Martyr archetype, as well as a complex psychological portrait. As Elisabeth Egan wrote for the New York Times review: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre a reader who likes stories where a terrible decision snowballs out of control, this book is just what the librarian ordered. Welcome to a spectacular avalanche.‚ÄùYou can read my full review of The Plot on Keeping Up With The Penguins.

The Plot is about a failed author, Jacob Finch Bonner, who is stuck with a job teaching writing. When a student comes to him with the plot for a novel that he claims will be a bestseller, Jacob is disbelieving. After hearing it though Jacob agrees. Some time passes and Jacob realizes the book has not been published because the student died. Hesitating only briefly, Jacob writes his own novel using the student's plot. Soon he has the fame and money he always wanted. But someone out there knows what Jacob did.I liked the idea of this book. Books about books or writer characters are enjoyable. So the first 40 pages, although slow, were very interesting to me. After a while though I began to notice the wordy sentences and long paragraphs. Something would be explained and then an extra 5 words were tacked on, repeating for emphasis the original statement. As I read I realized that I didn't like Jake. He was arrogant and thought poorly of people without reason. He also frustrated me with his lack of effort put into writing when forced to come up with his own plot. And speaking of "plot" the novel Jake writes is supposed to have an amazing plot twist. The plot of The Plot centers on this. It is supposed to be so amazing, never seen before that we can believe that readers everywhere would become obsessed with it. We get to read chapters from Jake's book, called crib. It isn't an action packed story so everything, from what we are given anyway, comes down to the end. I don't see the twist in Crib as anything special. In fact it's not a book I would enjoy reading. After Jacob's success he gets an email. Someone knows the plot wasn't his own. The communications become more frequent and nasty. All Jacob can think about is losing everything. I didn't feel any tension from this. The stakes seemed to be mostly in his head and he spends most of the book worrying. His editor and agent aren't that concerned and it's hard to see anything too bad potentially happening. He finally does a little investigating but I don't think Jacob reads mystery novels because he doesn't know how to ask questions. And when he actually has something to go on he does not put any of the pieces together. He is a little stupid actually. I was able to guess the villain as soon as they were introduced. It was obvious mostly because of the writing. It's hard to explain without spoilers but if the author had handled their introduction and inclusion in the storyline better, maybe there would have been some suspense. Probably not much though because it was also obvious there were limited options for the solution. This book took forever to get through. I think it was a bad idea to have the reveal from the villain's point of view. Their identity and motive wasn't a surprise. Their actions and plan were unbelievable. So the end was a depressing end to the letdown of a story. Due to Jacob's unlikable personality, lack of work ethic, and lack of intelligence I wondered if the author wanted us to be happy with the ending.

Thank you NetGalley and Macmillan Audio for the audiobook for review!This is my first audiobook. Ever. I wish I had a ebook so I could look back on it while I write this review, but since I don't, I apologize for any vague references or misrememberings.First, the audiobook itself. I'll be frank: It was awful. It sounds like it was put together from a library of recorded syllables rather than an actual person reading, and the reader was so slow that I had to listen to it in 1.5x speed just to get through it. After that, though, I flew through this. The story was compelling, the mystery was enchanting, and the writing was as lyrical as Korelitz has Jake describe Evan's writing in the beginning. I do wish the voices had been a little more distinct, however, from the story of Jake and The Plot, to the story within the story, of Jake's novel, Crib, to even the first few pages we get to read of Evan's version of the novel in the beginning. The style was incredibly similar, and if it hadn't been for the chapter titles where readers are literally TOLD these are pages from Jake's novel within the book, I wouldn't have been able to tell the difference.The story is as unique as any mystery/thriller I've ever read. The meta-factor definitely helped with the originality, and it was a refreshing take on the genre. Do I think the plot (the actual story that starts all the drama, not this book, The Plot) is the best thing since sliced bread; as remarkable as Jake seems to think when Evan describes it to him in his office, guaranteed bestseller and sure to be picked up by Hollywood? No. Did I see the big bad coming from about 50% in? Yes. Was the ending pretty expositional and slightly eye-roll worthy? Yes. Can I think of better way to have ended the book instead? Well, no. So.All in all, a quick thriller that, while it didn't really keep me guessing, definitely kept me engaged, if for no other reason than I enjoyed Korelitz writing and Jake's character. I will definitely be checking out some of Jean Hanff Korelitz other books, and am grateful to have received this eARC!

UPDATE: read this again. I am sure it will get a third helping too. ‚Äî‚Äî‚ÄîThat was great! I was able to guess the plot/reveals ahead, but attribute that to good foreshadowing by the author.The book is also markedly similar to The Words (starring Bradley Cooper and Zoe Saldana) for the first 60% which I oddly didn‚Äôt mind since it worked to emphasize the ‚Äúmessage‚Äù in the book. I also had an unusual personal connection to one of the characters, which increased my interest and enjoyment. If you're thinking it's Jacob because I'm a published author, you're wrong! ;) I once attended a writers meetup and there was a guy there exactly like Evan Parker / Parker Evan (He wouldn‚Äôt share even a snip of his story because he believed it would be the next Star Wars). At the time, I was feeling very üôÑ& judgmental about his ego and inability/unwillingness to share or participate with all of us and now I don‚Äôt blame the guy!SUMMARY: a washed up novelist (Jacob) is teaching a writers course in Vermont. One of his students has a terrific story/plot, but he never publishes it... years later when the student (Evan Parker/Parker Evan) dies, the washed up novelist takes the plot and writes it. (It‚Äôs not plagiarism since he didn‚Äôt copy even a single word.)The book is mega successful and while riding high on his success/book tour, he gets a message ‚ÄúI know you stole it‚Äù and so begins the long journey/investigation into who is this person that knows and what do they want and was the plot truth or fiction!?! Periodically pages from "the novel" are chapters. It's brilliantly and beautifully woven together. I LOVE a book inside a book, 2-for-1 when executed correctly.OVERALL, This is definitely something that will keep your interest and turning pages! This was a psychological thriller that initially took its time setting itself up but then became a fast paced, gripping read. As the tension built, I found myself increasingly eager to know what was going to happen. Jacob is a one hit novel wonder. He wrote a book at the start of his career that somewhat took off. Since then, he has been teaching writing at a mid to lower end university program, trying to replicate his success without any luck. He‚Äôs stuck in a rut and his self esteem is suffering. Then comes Even Parker, a narcissistic student who claims to have the perfect plot idea for a best selling novel. Evan is protective over his idea. He scoffs at Jacob and the university saying his idea is so good, he really doesn‚Äôt need any help in crafting his book. But in a rare moment of Even letting down his guard, he shares the plot idea of his book with Jacob. And so the story continues from there....This is a book that delves into the writing profession and publishing industry. It is both plot and character driven in that the reader is given an intimate glimpse into Jacob‚Äôs psyche and his transformation as things start going horribly wrong. I was taken with this audiobook but will be honest and say that I guessed the ending. I had a hunch early on and sadly for me, I was correct. However, the ending is fantastic and it appears that I‚Äôm in the minority of guessing the reveal as I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs super obvious. Regardless, this was a book full of tension and edge-of-your-seat moments as the mystery grew. The audio performance was well performed. Absolutely recommend this audiobook. Would be a fantastic summer read.A gracious thank you to MacMillan Audio and Netgalley for an advanced audio copy in exchange for an honest review.

Jacob 'Finch' Bonner is a has been author who is struggling to write. He teaches writing at a third rate MFA program. But one particular year he meets a student named Evan Parker an obnoxious asshole who thinks he is better than everyone else and doesn't need anyone's help. He claims to have a plot for a novel that's surely going to be a worldwide success. Jake is very skeptical but when he hears the plot he grudgingly has to agree with his student.Years go by and Jake doesn't hear anything about Evan Parker and his book. He learns that Evan passed away shortly after he narrated the plot to Jake. Jake can't let a good story go to the grave . So he takes Evans plot and writes a novel and gets it published. It is a worldwide success and with it comes recognition for Jake. He is going through each day fearing one day all of it might explode.One day Jake receives an email. Four simple words. 'You are a Liar'. His whole world comes crashing down and here the game of cat and mouse begins.This was thrilling ride!!!. I had heard a lot of good things about this book. I was very apprehensive about reading this as it seemed like a "literary" novel. And I'll be honest the language in the beginning was very flowery and self indulgent for my liking. But once it got to the story it was pretty fast paced. I had guessed the big reveal a few chapters ahead. But I still enjoyed it. I only have one gripe. The way the plot of Jake's book was described with the "twist", my expectations were very high. When the "twist" was revealed I was very underwhelmed. It wasn't that ingenuous. But all in all its a pretty good thriller.

I love books about writing and the book world. But I couldn't buy the plot of The Plot. When the main character who is a teacher hears the plot of a book his odious student is writing, they both think the plot is so fantastic that it will be an international bestseller, an Oprah pick, and become a movie. And so it does, after the teacher learns of the student's death and writes the book himself. My problem is that there is NO plot that is a guaranteed bestseller. None. And plots can't be copyrighted, and many similar books have come into the world after having been inspired by the same source material. Yet the author character is living in fear that his secret will be found out, even though he wrote every word of it. The twist was pretty clear early on. And the main character spends most of the book moping and being gripped with anxiety. He only starts doing things in the last quarter of the book.

I have a feeling this will be a best seller! Despite figuring out what was going on very early, I couldn‚Äôt put down this well written novel. The book within a book was an effective technique. The only thing that bothered me while reading was the question (which the book answered), can you own a plot? Although he felt guilty about what he did, and certainly wouldn‚Äôt look forward to all the attention he would get when his anonymous accuser‚Äôs allegations were made public, I couldn‚Äôt quite understand why Jake was so upset about it. He just took a story that someone else had told him and wrote a similar one in his own words. There was no plagiarism. This would make a good discussion for a book group.

'The Plot' by Jean Hanff Korelitz has so many wonderful tongue-in-cheek moments about the ecosystem of being a writer of novels I knew this mystery was a crafty satire immediately! I started chuckling when I recognized a certain autobiography that supposedly a character in 'The Plot' had lived. The book is a slow-burner mystery, but for certain, imho, the mystery is not really where the fun in reading this book is. I guessed almost everything about the identity of a character when I got about 2/3rds into the book. Despite this premature identification of a murderer for me, I enjoyed reading 'The Plot'. Below I have copied the cover blurb:"Jacob Finch Bonner was once a promising young novelist with a respectably published first book. Today, he's teaching in a third-rate MFA program and struggling to maintain what's left of his self-respect; he hasn't written--let alone published--anything decent in years. When Evan Parker, his most arrogant student, announces he doesn't need Jake's help because the plot of his book in progress is a sure thing, Jake is prepared to dismiss the boast as typical amateur narcissism. But then... he hears the plot.Jake returns to the downward trajectory of his own career and braces himself for the supernova publication of Evan Parker's first novel: but it never comes. When he discovers that his former student has died, presumably without ever completing his book, Jake does what any self-respecting writer would do with a story like that--a story that absolutely needs to be told.In a few short years, all of Evan Parker's predictions have come true, but Jake is the author enjoying the wave. He is wealthy, famous, praised and read all over the world. But at the height of his glorious new life, an e-mail arrives, the first salvo in a terrifying, anonymous campaign: You are a thief, it says.As Jake struggles to understand his antagonist and hide the truth from his readers and his publishers, he begins to learn more about his late student, and what he discovers both amazes and terrifies him. Who was Evan Parker, and how did he get the idea for his "sure thing" of a novel? What is the real story behind the plot, and who stole it from whom?Hailed as breathtakingly suspenseful, Jean Hanff Korelitz's The Plot is a propulsive read about a story too good not to steal, and the writer who steals it. I did not think the book propulsive, but it was suspenseful as a light dramedy for me. Jacob isn't particularly likeable - he's too narcissistic. But he represents a type of person which I thought spot on and very funny! Did I see a bit of myself in the character of Jacob, perhaps? Not telling. *ahem*The novel is full of ironic sotto voce information about writers, writing and becoming a famous author! The plot is more about the variety (a sad and inadvertent comedy) of people who want to break into the New York City literary world, and what happens when they do. It's also about the anxiety of creating an "original" story without having echoes and restatements of other book plots and characters, which after two thousand years of storytellers writing stories is truly an impractical idea, basically. The chapters alternate between the fictional book Jake has written and Jake's 'real' (fictional) life, as well as the fact Jake's book is based on the life of another 'real' (fictional) character in the book cribbed from another writer/character, while we readers are reading about all of this in the fictional novel 'The Plot' - well, you see the fun the author was having, gentle reader! The writing is very good too.

The Plot is a slow-burning book that captured my attention right from the start because I was fascinated by the premise of the book, especially the idea of whether a writer can plagiarize an idea or a plot that's never been written by another person. The idea that stealing an idea or recycling ideas for writing is crazy since writers have been doing it for centuries-but so have artists, architects, and composers as they take ideas from the past and build and expand on them. Yet, in The Plot by Jean Hanff Korelitz, someone doesn't share this sentiment and feels that the taking of their story, their "plot" is stealing, and they're more than a little angry.Jacob Finch Bonner is a has-been writer. His first book hit the bestseller charts and proclaimed him a New and Noteworthy author; now he's teaching aspiring writers at an MFA program. When he meets Evan Parker, a know it all, who wants no help with his book because he says it's so good that it's going to be on every bestseller list and be made into a blockbuster movie, he's taken aback by his arrogance and confidence. Then Jake hears the plot of Evan's book and knows it's true.Three years later, Jake happens to wonder what happened to Parker's book since its never been published. After searching the internet, he finds out that Parker died a few months after leaving his course, never writing the book. This leaves Jake, now struggling more than ever with money and still no new book, with the idea that he should take the plot of Parker's book and rewrite the story into his own. After all, if Parker never told anyone (he shared nothing about it while at the college with anyone but Jake) and didn't write it, then no one will ever know where the idea came from. That's exactly what Jake does.Suddenly, he's a huge success. Everything Parker said would happen comes true-NYT #1 bestseller, a movie deal, Oprah, book tours, and more. Jake is famous beyond his wildest belief. There's just one problem: he gets an email that says "you're a thief", just one of many emails, texts, tweets, and letters from the person who knows what he did and is threatening to expose him. As Jake begins research into Evan Parker's life in the hopes that he can find who is threatening him, his career, and stop them, the pace and tension in the storyline amps up. Things start to get much more interesting from this point on, and the second half of the book is definitely the part that will keep you turning pages.Now, I did figure out who the person was that was sending him the messages almost immediately and guessed how the book would end, but that didn't really take anything away from the book because I while reading, I couldn't see who else it could possibly be. This really is more literary suspense than anything, and Korelitz has a mastery of words. The characterization was remarkably well-done although the characters were unlikeable, which was not a big deal, of course. The Plot is thought-provoking: who really owns a plot? Can you even appropriate an idea? Thank you Celadon Books and Jean Hanff Korelitz for the ARC. All opinions are my own.

These weighty questions mingle with a love story, a mystery, and a writer's journey to strive‚Äîthree of the most satisfying flavors of fiction out there.---A book about a book. A plot about a...plotOh my God. This was so good. If you know me, you know I'm picky when it comes to mysteries and thrillers, and this one...this one didn't disappoint. I finally finished it a day before its publication date, and I couldn't be happier. The Plot was a bit slow in the beginning, but once we started rolling, I couldn't stop reading.We follow Jacob Finch Bonner, who recently became a literary God due to his novel Crib, the plot of which he stole from a former student of his. Jake is riding the wave of success when he gets a message that reads: You are a theif. Jacob struggles to the very end with what he once believe to be the truth: Anyone can be a writer, as well as: No one can tell your story but you. And guess what? I was SO there for it.Go read this book if you want a thriller that truly thrills! Not gonna lie, I got major Gone Girl vibes with that ending!

Thank you Celadon Books for the gifted copy.It's not often that I read a book so far ahead of it's publication date but I just had to with this one. This is going to be a book everyone will be talking about...it's that good! So mark your calendars for May 11th when this one hits the shelves...you will definitely want to pick up a copy or pre-order this book.I will say, this is a slow-burning psychological thriller but I found myself completely captivated right from the start. I absolutely loved all the commentary about the writer's world - some I was quite familiar with being a book blogger. I also loved the way the story was structured, alternating between what is going on in Jake's life and then the chapters from "the book." I found each equally compelling and both added to the overall enjoyment of the book, propelling it forward.This premise of this book definitely piqued my interest and then once I started reading it, I found I could not put the book down, but again, it's a rather slower read until that last third of the book when things really take off. This is when Jake is really in the midst of figuring out who is behind the messages and boy do things take on a life of their own. While I did figure out some of the twists, this in no way detracted from my overall enjoyment of this book because I still did not figure out everything. And the ending...just brilliant! I loved it! There are quite a few subtle twists and turns this book takes and it really kept me engaged and flipping the pages. I definitely recommend picking this one up when it comes out in May!You can see all my reviews at: https://alwayswithabook.blogspot.com

I caved and purchased this book, because my library loan list was groaningly long. Partway into the novel, I wondered why I‚Äôd thrown down my hard-earned coin because my attention wandered. What was the charm? Such a SMART storyline- that‚Äôs the charm- since protagonist Jake Finch Bonner is underwhelming and almost unlikeable at first. Gradually, the frustrated and flailing author becomes an object of sympathy, as we join his efforts in publishing the book, the story he has had dropped into his lap and which might never otherwise have been written if not for him. ‚ÄúStories, of course, are common as dirt. Everyone has one, if not an infinity of them, and they surround us all at times whether we acknowledge them or not. Stories are the wells we dip into to be reminded of who we are, and the ways we reassure ourselves that, however obscure we may appear to others, we are actually important, even crucial to the ongoing drama of survival: personal, societal, and even as a species.‚ÄùHumour barbs this inventive ‚Äúplot‚Äù, as cat and mouse problems beset Jake. At times a psychological thriller and others, a philosophical look on the ethos in the world of writing and publishing, the structure of the novel reminded me of a Russian nesting doll - a matryoshka- as revealed by each layer. I always knew ‚Äúwho‚Äù - but couldn‚Äôt guess how it all would end. Kudos to author Jean Hanff Korelitz for her layered and zigzagging tale. Strong 4.5 stars and a ‚Äúplot‚Äù which I‚Äôll remember for a while. It was worth dropping my own coin. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

What an intriguing story! The Plot is a fast-paced novel, very difficult to put down once started. I've read quite a few books about writers (including many from Stephen King), But fewer that delve so deeply into the fascinating world of publishing. I would recommend it for a quick and entertaining escape from the real world.

Do you like books about books? I LOVE them and am always drawn to anything with a book within a book, an author as a character or anything publishing related. This follows Jake, a struggling author trying to write his second novel. He‚Äôs teaching at a third rate school and meets, Evan a cocky aspiring writer. When Evan tells Jake the plot of his novel he‚Äôs intrigued. Fast forward a few years and Evan is dead so Jake takes his idea and writes the book. It takes off in a huge way, think Oprah‚Äôs Book Club, it‚Äôs been optioned as a movie and been reprinted several times. Life is good for Jake until he receives a note calling him a thief....Many people warned me that this one was a slow burn but that once it takes off, it‚Äôs pretty gripping. I can see that, but for me the audio was so well done that I honestly never found it all that slow. If a steadier paced book is an issue for you then consider the audio because the narrator was fantastic. I thought this was a really smart thriller and recommend going in as blind as possible. What I said above is pretty much all you need to know without giving too much away. The characterization was strong as was the ending, definitely a super solid thriller with a fresh spin

I enjoyed this story but I think I had been expecting more. For a book about a plot with such a crazy twist I didn‚Äôt find this book to be very twisty at all. Despite figuring out what was going to happen I did enjoy reading it and especially liked the chapters from the narrator‚Äôs novel intertwined int he main story. The writing was good and the characters were well-developed (even if they weren‚Äôt particularly likeable). The narrator is Jacob who started out his career as writer with a lot of promise and was highlighted by the New York Times. His follow up book was significantly less successful and led him down a path to teaching creative writing at a third rate program. He hates his job and his students. At one point he comes across a particularly cocky student, Evan Parker, who has an ingenious idea for a novel that will make him famous and to Jacob‚Äôs frustration he agrees about the brilliance of the idea. Years later when he is reminded of that student he looks him up and finds out he died not long after the program. Jacob can‚Äôt help himself and writes a novel using the plot Evan had told him. He instantly rockets to success but someone starts to send him anonymous notes calling him a thief and a liar.

This book is not nice. Don't read it in bed before going to sleep, because you won't have nice dreams if you manage to put it down. There's a very unpleasant novel (to say the least) inside a very intriguing one. In the beginning, everything goes slowly and I thought that it may not live up to the high expectations I had, but I was wrong.I didn't really like the main character. A writer who seemed to have lost all hope and whose life was boring until he found "the plot". Then he changes for the better and his life becomes more exciting. He also musters the courage to protect what he has achieved and the second part of the book is much more fast-paced and definitely undownputable.The final twist didn't come as a surprise to me. However, that fact didn't make it less appealing. The writer disappointed me again for his lack of foresight, inability to connect the dots and helplessness. The novel didn't disappoint me though. Jean Hanff Korelitz wrote it with the skill of an author who truly knows human nature.I recommend this novel to readers who are not easily appalled by how terrible people can be.www.theleisurediaries.blogspot.com

Finished 06/14/20213.75 stars. Womp womp. Not quite a 4 star read for me, which is sad because I was particularly excited about this one, & for the first 1/3 I was actually really enjoying it! Was having 4 star feelings, aaaand was even thinking I could imagine giving it 5 stars if the ending really blew me away, which apparently people were saying things like ‚Äúread this for the ending!‚Äù So I had high hopes. But alas, it wound up being the ending that killed it for me. A few things‚Ä¶First of all, I saw the ending coming from a mile away. The moment the character was introduced, I knew it would be said character that was f‚Äôing with him. And as the story progressed and we were clued in on more details about how ‚ÄúCrib‚Äù, was similar/the same as real life happenings, I only became more and more positive that this character was in fact the one. Silver hair? I mean come on. It became blatantly obvious for me & as soon as the word soup was uttered I knew what was coming. All this made for a sorta spoiled reveal, usually I‚Äôm annoyed at the fact that I can never guess what‚Äôs going to happen the way so many other people seem to be able to, but having done so this time around, and so early on, I realize how thoroughly the fun is spoiled when there‚Äôs nothing left to guess. So definitely anticlimactic for me. Secondly, the premise of the entire story is that the mostly defunct writer Jacob Bonner is on his last legs as a writer, forced to sink to new lows in order to continue to support himself as a ‚Äúwriter‚Äù with writer gigs. Teaching writing at a school that‚Äôs basically available to anyone willing to pay, the kids coming thru the program are not exactly the rising stars of the writing world. But having already had his 15 minutes of fame with his first book that was somewhat successful, Jacob‚Äôs now stuck in writer purgatory having not been able to produce another success, & is forced to take this job that consists of humoring writer hopefuls. When Evan comes along, he is obnoxious in every way. Boisterous, rude, cocky (and not in a good way) and full of unsubstantiated confidence in his skill as a writer. Jacob reads some of his pages & attempts to give advice, & Evan rebuffs his attempts at helping him, so sure is he that he already has a golden ticket. He sets it up to Jacob like he already has a plot that is so luscious, so juicy and enthralling and unique that he is 100% positive that his book could not possibly fail. He‚Äôs thoroughly sure that he is the world‚Äôs next John Steinbeck & John Grisham all in one. It‚Äôs the infallible plot. Jacob of course accompanies this with the appropriate internal eye roll, that is until Evan takes him into his confidence and reveals this perfect plot. We don‚Äôt hear it right away, we only know that Jacob agrees with Evan‚Äôs assessment. It‚Äôs supposedly so amazing of a plot, that it inspires immediate jealousy in Jacob because now he too is positive of the book‚Äôs future success. It‚Äôs just that good. They are both certain without so much as an iota of doubt that it is a plot/book that will be turned into movies with top notch directors, it will be talked about on Oprah, it‚Äôll be on every best seller list. Comparisons to Steinbeck & Dan Brown & John Grisham, he is all of those authors in one, it will be both the great American novel AND a best seller with mass appeal. The hype is REAL. Of course we all want to know what this gift from god of a plot consists of, but I assumed the author would find some way to skirt around ever having to reveal the actual plot and just continuously reference it, cuz otherwise the author is going to have to actually produce some magical plot that sends shockwaves through readers at barely the mention of an outline. But this isn‚Äôt what happens at all. The overall outline/plot is revealed to be basically mom kills the daughter that she‚Äôs bitter towards cuz of all her own unfulfilled dreams & potential, then takes her place at college & la dee fucking dah. That‚Äôs a fine plot, and I‚Äôm sure in the hands of a proper author it could be titillating, shocking, all the things a proper plot twist generates. It has the makings of being a perfectly adequate thriller. But the infallible, perfect, ultimate, so-damn-good-i-know-it‚Äôll-be-on-Oprah-plot that they made it out to be?! Yeeaaahh‚Ä¶No. 100% No. To pass it off as such just felt phony, fake, & like the author thought we the readers were stupid. Like didn‚Äôt he expect that we were going to get curious about this magical plot? I guess it‚Äôs called suspending your disbelief, it‚Äôs something we have to do often as fiction readers, but still. For a book called the plot, all the hype surrounding the plot, only to have the plot be some mediocre second rate, dime a dozen thing? He‚Äôd have been better off going my route and trying to find a way from never revealing the full scope of said plot.And, last but not least‚Ä¶the ending of this book came with my absolute BIGGEST bookish pet peeve: the villainous monologue. I absolutely despise this tool that lazy authors use to give the reader info. Rather than finding a way in which to properly relay info to the reader, the author does THIS. They have the villain/bad guy/whatever in some way come face to face with the MC, then for some strange reason that makes no logical sense proceed to lay out a play by play of their every villainous move & motive. The ‚ÄúMUAHAHA, I got a knife from the kitchen drawer & then i waited in the hall way & hid in the cabinet and then jumped out when they got here and then stabbed him to death. I‚Äôve been waiting to do this since he stole my girlfriend 10 years ago! Then i wrapped up all the evidence and threw it in the trash‚Ä¶then I stole your mom‚Äôs car and waited for your dad so i could stab him too!‚Äù Okay so maybe it‚Äôs not quite so bad as that but it‚Äôs pretty damn close. There is never any situation ever in which a murderer chooses to give their victim a literal play by play of all the actions they engaged in, at any time for any reason. Murderers don‚Äôt sit there and explain things. They don‚Äôt find it necessary for you to understand things before they kill you. Authors everywhere need to stop considering this as a tool in their tool box, because once i come across a villainous monologue all bets are off. They‚Äôd be lucky to come out of it with more than a single star. It‚Äôs quite ridiculous, and bottom line it‚Äôs absolutely LAZY WRITING. Figure out a way for us to learn these things on our own!!!Sigh.I still chose to round this up in the end because I did think that the book‚Äôs first half was better than decent. I was fully absorbed in the story and in Jacob‚Äôs internal struggles. Jacob was not exactly the hero of our story, he was both unlikable and relatable. He was weak & insecure, which are of course very easy to understand. Who of us is not those things, at least some of the time? His superiority is a bit irritating, the fact that he seems to feel success is owed to him, & that he gets to be the judge and jury of writers and who‚Äôs deserving of success. Jealousy & envy are traits that are also easy to wrap our brains around, & of course Evan is portrayed to us as obnoxious enough that we don‚Äôt exactly sympathize with him either. I was torn as to how to feel about what Jacob did. Was it plagiarism? Not quite. But was there dishonesty in his actions? Absolutely. That‚Äôs another thing I thought about a lot. Based on how things went down, the chances of anyone being able to prove that Jacob ‚Äúplagiarized‚Äù anything are impossible considering that his writing was 100% his own! It was the idea that was stolen, Jacob took the raw idea and ran with it and turned it into something real. Proving the way this went down would‚Äôve been pretty much impossible so Jacob‚Äôs major stress out over this was pretty unfounded. If it were a crisis/attack of conscience that would be one thing, but spend your life dreading being outed? Eh. No doubt authors deal with stuff reminiscent of this all the time, without some sort of record of this idea somewhere that could be time stamped in some way, it would be no more than the word of some random crazy person against a famous published author. Just unsubstantiated claims. After writing this review I am seriously considering dropping my rating to 3 stars. There were so many stupid things wrong with it. I‚Äôm already starting to forget the feelings I had when I was enjoying the first half! Still, I think I‚Äôm going to stick with the 4 stars. Plot holes and eye rolls and all, it was still a good time.

2.5 stars
Do I need to give up on thrillers?
Jacob Finch Bonner ‚Äî an author whose first book was a critical success, but who has been less successful with his follow-up publications ‚Äî has been compelled for financial reasons to take a teaching job at Ripley College. There he meets a student, Evan Parker, who, from the get-go, is so obviously smug about the incredible, so good, fantastic, brand new plot for his yet-to-be-written novel that Bonner finds it hard to imagine the plot to live up to its high expectations. But Parker relays the plot to Bonner after having submitted a measly handful of pages for review for the class. That's when Bonner realizes that Parker is correct. This novel with its unbelievable plot twist is going to make the biggest splash in the book world this side of the century mark.But a few years later he runs a rudimentary check on a search engine and sees that this arrogant guy (with the hair perpetually flopping over his forehead) has never published this phenomenal new book. In fact, after another search, he sees that Parker has died ‚Äî just a few months actually after leaving the class at Ripley College. So, Bonner does what he thinks any writer would do ‚Äî¬†he writes it himself. For how could he deprive the world of this amazing plot?Jacob continues along a nice path ‚Äî with this guilt and constant awareness poking at the back of his mind the whole while ‚Äî enjoying the success of his book, Crib (which is offered up within The Plot through a handful of excerpts). It has been chosen for Oprah's Book Club, optioned for a movie, and made all the best seller lists. He's traveling with book tours, scheduled appearances, and book signings. When suddenly, he receives an email that the sender knows what he's done. The threats to out his supposed theft increase and eventually become public. The legal team with his publishing house gets involved along with his agent and his editor. Meanwhile, Bonner decides to get in front of the anonymous instigator and try to discover who could be behind the increasingly threatening messages.Another book where I really liked some of the ideas put forth and the potential there, but felt the execution lacked in its delivery. It truly may be that thrillers just don't thrill me. At no point was I holding on in suspense. At almost no point did I wonder what was going to happen. The structure and play with words were especially interesting, but could not carry the weight of the entire book ‚Äî much less all three interwoven stories. I do admit to liking both the way Korelitz writes and the voice of Bonner as the narrator. But I never felt connected enough to his tale to truly care, especially once I'd figured out the forthcoming details early on. Also, the actual plot in Crib ‚Äî the book-within-the book ‚Äî felt incredibly obvious to me, which I understand would be the danger in hyping it up within the novel's interior to begin with. But it really made it a hard sell as I continued through the whole of the book. Crib was just not that amazing of a story for me to warrant all that effusion of brilliance.I wanted a little more by way of understanding and exploring the idea of who owns a story. What Bonner has done isn't plagiarism. But where is the line for theft of intellectual property? Who is allowed to tell the story? And when does borrowing or being inspired by something cross the line into outright thievery? But I didn't get that here. Bonner only seemed to briefly and occasionally wonder the same thing, but by reassuring himself in a way that allowed him to power through a moment of despair.All in all, not enough meat on the bone for my particular tastes. It was a middling sort of story and for once I never looked forward to the book within when those chapters popped up.

TW: Suicide, parent abuse, abortion, family drama, murder, 
  *****SPOILERS*****
About the book: Jacob Finch Bonner was once a promising young novelist with a respectably published first book. Today, he's teaching in a third-rate MFA program and struggling to maintain what's left of his self-respect; he hasn't written--let alone published--anything decent in years. When Evan Parker, his most arrogant student, announces he doesn't need Jake's help because the plot of his book in progress is a sure thing, Jake is prepared to dismiss the boast as typical amateur narcissism. But then . . . he hears the plotRelease Date: May 11th, 2021Genre: Thriller Pages: 336Rating: 3.5‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠êWhat I Liked:	‚Ä¢ The plot seemed so promising.	‚Ä¢ The writing	‚Ä¢ The two stories intertwined in the bookWhat I Didn't Like:	‚Ä¢ The ending..... Overall Thoughts: This started off so so so good. I wanted/needed to know what was happening. I loved that we had two stories going on at the same time and we would pop in between the two stories. It started to go down hill for me when Jacob went searching for the person that was sending the notes. If you stole someone's story would you try to find out the truth or just listen to the people around you and forget it? This book starts off very slow but I promise you if you stick with it you will be rewarded with an amazing story! It centers on Jake, an author who had trouble maintaining success after his first book and is relegated to teaching writers courses at various schools. He talks to a very unlikable student who has an amazing idea, and when he sees later that the book hasn't yet been published, he takes the idea and writes it himself, to huge success. As time passes, he starts getting indications that someone knows what he did and tries desperately to protect himself.This book is uniquely told by alternating between chapters from the actual novel Jake wrote with the chapters of what is happening right now and told from Jake's POV. I was equally interested in both storylines. As I said earlier, it does start slow- the first 3rd of the book felt like a slog but I read the rest of it late into the night once it got going. The author expertly weaves a complex story in a way that is easy to understand and ties what seemed like disparate pieces together, with multiple twists throughout. Though I did figure out who the villain was, I enjoyed reading up to the point where it was revealed to see if I was right, and didn't feel let down that I had guessed it. I didn't like Jacob Finch Bonner much as The Plot opened. He was teaching creative writing at a summer program on a college campus. The symposium attracted adult writers trying to learn the craft and make connections with agents and other writers. Jacob, a washed-up, one trick wonder, was clinging to the literary success of his first novel, and trying to ignore the losers he had written since. He was bitter, sarcastic, and had no respect for the earnest wannabes who hoped to get a little help, or at least inspiration from a "real" writer. Jacob went through the motions, doing the bare minimum he had to in order to get paid. Then a cocky, insolent student, Evan Parker, tells Jacob he has sure fire best selling novel and explains the plot. Astonished, Jacob agrees it is the plot of a sure bestseller. He leaves the encounter feeling even more sorry for himself, reflecting bitterly that it wasn't fair that Evan Parker was able to come up with a great story idea, when his own writer's imagination had deserted him. That's the set up for a complicated and twisty mystery. The story was slow at first, and although I never learned to like Jake Bonner, as I got to know him I understood his frustrations and motivations, and began to root for him a little. If you've ever attempted to write a novel, or attended a writer's event, you'll appreciate the background and insight into the world of writing and publishing. The Plot is deftly written with subtle humor and unexpected turns. Highly recommended!

Jacob Finch Bonner, author of a novel that achieved success many years ago, is teaching at an MFA program. One of his students, Evan Parker, discloses a sure-fire plot behind an as-yet-unpublished book. Jacob later finds out Evan has died. He usurps the idea and turns it into a blockbuster. When Jacob starts receiving anonymous threats, accusing him of theft, he begins an investigation to see if he can figure out the person‚Äôs identity. This book starts out as a mystery and turns into a thriller. Excerpts from Jacob‚Äôs book are included, so the reader will need to keep track of several layers of characters. I particularly enjoyed the parts about literature and the writing process. It is perhaps no surprise in a book entitled The Plot that the characters are thinly drawn. It might have been better to keep this ‚Äúperfect plot‚Äù a secret since it does not seem all that extraordinary once it is revealed. This book explores the ethics of appropriating an idea for a story. I am not sure I buy into the idea of a ‚Äúsure thing‚Äù in terms of an idea for a book, since so much depends on execution, but it was certainly entertaining. QUICK TAKE: I love a good TALENTED MR. RIPLEY story, and while I didn't love love love THE PLOT, I ultimately really enjoyed it. The premise of this book is that a once famous but now down-on-his-luck writer steals (borrows?) a totally original plot from a former student when he learns the student has died. ‚ÄòIt will be read by everybody. It will make a fortune. This is a book that verrrry much had me in its grasp, and which I really wanted to give five stars. But right from the beginning I told myself I was only allowed to do that if the hook of this book delivered on its central promise. And I don't think it did, not as much as the author wanted it to, anyway. The premise here is that a writing teacher (a once promising author himself) takes the plot of a novel from a deceased student‚Äîa plot which the student told him would be a guaranteed bestseller and make him tons of money, a "sure thing"‚Äîbecause hey, he's not using it (being dead), and that premise *needs* to be written. Sure enough, two years later, our main character is a bestselling author, rich, with a movie adaptation on the way to be directed by Steven Spielberg. But he starts getting messages calling him a thief. Who is writing the messages if the student is dead? plot /pl√§t/a plan made in secret by a group of people to do something illegal or harmfulthe main events of a play, novel, movie, or similar work, devised and presented by the writer as an interrelated sequencea small piece of land that has been marked or measured for a particular purposeAnd we get to play with all of those by the time the story is done. In addition to the main plot of our main character Jake writing the book and then hoping not to get caught out, we also get excerpts from Jake's novel, which he calls Crib (a clever play on the double and/or triple meaning of the this book's title, as "crib" has multiple means as well). It is in this area that I felt the story didn't fully deliver, although to be clear what was there was great. But this guy (his name is Evan) makes the bold claim that no one has a plot like his, that it's a guaranteed hit, no one could mess it up, that it will make its author a millionaire, win him fame and critical acclaim. And he's right. So by the time we finally get around to seeing the "twist" that everyone is pooping their pants over, it has to live up to all that expectation. And I just don't think it does! For one thing, there are several interconnected twists in this book, but I called one of them almost right away, which had me primed to try and figure out what else was going on. So by the time I had that suspicion confirmed, the "big twist" at that point felt inevitable. I just don't think this is a plot that is as good as Korelitz thinks it is (or, at the very least, almost every single character thinks it is, in the world she's created). All that said, though, this was still great. I love the way that Korelitz writes about writing. I thought she navigated several complicated characters and fraught situations in a way that left me appreciative of their nuance, instead of being beaten over the head with a stick. The ending of the book is almost perfect, a hard enough thing to accomplish, but especially in a suspense novel. This book made me want to pick up writing again. I'm not sure whether I will pick up anything else from this author. None of her other plots sound as interesting as this one (heh). Although I did have Admission on my TBR for a long time, I finally took it off a couple of years ago because it had been there for over a decade without my having read it. The Latecomer sounds interesting, but I'm rarely in the mood for family drama. I guess we'll see what she comes out with next.[4.5 stars rounded down, coz of that plot, yo]

In and of themselves, ideas cannot be copyrighted. So if you write a story or book with a plot that someone else simply claims to have thought of first, you're likely on pretty solid ground. But what if that someone shared his or her idea with you - even jotted down several pages of notes - and then unexpectedly died? You're positive it will be a best-seller if it's fleshed out, and in your heart of hearts, you know it's a story that begs to be told. If you do the telling, though, are you stealing? Such is the overarching question behind this mesmerizing book. It actually happened to Jacob Finch Bonner, who's had a couple of relatively nondescript books published but is hoping one day to hit the New York Times best-seller list. A student in one of his college writing seminars, a total jerk named Evan Parker, describes the book he's sure will be a winner, and Jake (secretly) agrees. Later, when Evan dies, Jake is faced with a decision: Publish, or let the story perish?Rationalizing that, as previously mentioned, ideas cannot be copyrighted and this is a story that must be told, Jake chooses the first option. And by golly, he was right; in short order, he becomes a writing sensation, landing on that coveted list and and Oprah's book club choices. Although he now must deal with his publisher's expectations for a follow-up book - one he knows can't possibly live up to the wild success of this one - for now, he's relatively content to enjoy the fruits of his (and Evan's) labors. That is, until he gets an email that tells a different story: You are a thief.Needless to say, he sees his now-stellar career in shreds, but on the other hand, he doesn't want to admit that he got the idea (and maybe more) from someone else. Now, he sets out to find who wrote that message - which in short order turns into many more, some even posted on social media. In the middle of it all, he marries Anna, his love from across the country (he's in New York, she's got a successful job directing podcasts in Seattle). Not wanting to worry her, he rationalizes, he keeps his so-far secret between himself and his publisher.The rest of the book details his search to identify his accuser and learn more about Evan as well as his struggles to write another book and keep his new marriage on solid ground. Interspersed are chapters taken from the book he wrote - the one he "stole" from Evan - and reading these builds awareness of what the story behind the story really is. I must say the first third or so of the book is a little slow, but trust me, once it gets going you won't want to put it down. Although I did guess early on who might be behind the whole mess, I had absolutely no idea the hows or whys, making the ending one that quite literally made me gasp.In short, if any book deserves to be on that NYT best-seller list, this is it. Many, many thanks to the publisher for sending me an advance copy to read and review. Wow!

Jacob Finch Bonner was a well respected novelist after just one book. However, for his sophomore title, he is hit with a hard case of writer's block. To make ends meet, he is teaching a program for aspiring writers, although it has been years since he has published. When someone taking the class, Evan Parker, tells Jacob of a plot for a book, Jacob is intrigued. Then, Jacob discovers that Evan has died, so Jacob takes on Evan's plot as his own and writes a bestselling book. The book has done so good that Jacob rises immediately to the top - including an offer from Stephen Spielberg for a feature film. He is a book thief, but who's to know?Now, wealthy beyond belief, traveling far and wide, Jacob's success almost comes to a screeching halt - and it starts with a single email - You are a thief. That is all it says. Jacob perhaps should have given the idea of Evan's plot some serious thought. Actually, Evan felt it was a sure thing. If Evan had not died, would he have achieved the very success that Jacob is experiencing? Who knows of Jacob's actions? Jacob now starts to dig deeper into Evan's life. Now he needs to know how Evan came up with the plot, and whether or not it had anything to do with his death. What was the plot based on, who was really behind it and who is sure to expose Jacob?That one email becomes many. Then there are the texts. But, it doesn't stop there. Threats are coming fast and hard, giving Jacob pause. However, the train has left the station and Jacob can do no less than to try and sort things out so that he never becomes exposed.Although I loved this thrilling story, there was a point I pretty much figured it out. Even though that part of the mystery fell flat, I was eager to see the journey ahead of Jacob so that the many questions and fears facing him would be resolved. The book definitely was intriguing, enough that I pretty much read it from cover to cover in one sitting. Having an idea who was threatening Jacob did not take away my enjoyment of the story. In fact, what it did was to keep me even more riveted to the events as they unfolded. I ended up loving this book and have already recommended it countless times. Although I received a print ARC of 
The Plot, 
I also got an audiobook review copy. I did have to speed up the book in order to feel a bit more engaged with the story. This is not the first time I have listened to this narrator. In fact, two of the books I have listened to were 
Gone Girl
 and 
The Wife Upstairs.
 Once I got deeper into the story, I was able to relax into the narration, and thus also have been recommending the audiobook to fellow readers. Many thanks to Celadon Books and NetGalley for this ARC for review. This is my honest opinion.

Thank you Celadon Books for an ARC in exchange for an honest review.The Plot was such an interesting and unique book. I would classify it as a mystery thriller, but I also learned so much from reading this book about publishing, writers, and reviewers. While the beginning was a bit slow and kind of a lot to take in, after a couple of chapters I was super intrigued. Once I got hooked into this book I did not stop until I was flipping the last page. It kept me on the edge of my seat and the way it was written had a big sense of thrill throughout the book.This follow Jacob Finch Bonner who is struggling with his career. He wrote a somewhat good book that became a best seller and now has no motivation to write. He is currently a professor teaching at a university to aspiring young writers on how to write successfully, only he has no motivation to teach these kids anything as he is facing that he will never be a big-time writer. One of his students perked Jake‚Äôs interest when he said the plot of his story is mind blowing and once he finishes the book it will be the best book ever written. Jake is very intrigued and sits down with Evan Parker and gets him to spill the plot of this soon to be famous book. Jake agreed it would become a best seller and everyone would be talking about it. Two years later, Jake is now doing random side jobs and remembers Evan Parker, but can‚Äôt recall ever hearing about his book being published. He googles Evan and realizes he died a couple of months after they met, and he never did publish his book. It looks like no one even knew that he was writing a book besides Jake. Jake ends up stealing the plot of Evan‚Äôs book and becomes an international best seller. Only is it too good to be true? Someone seems to know what really happened and starts accusing Jake of being a thief.I am so glad I picked up this book because it was so amazing. We get a story within a story because we get chapters from Crib, the book that Jake wrote that was based off on Evan‚Äôs plot. It was very chilling to read the chapters from Crib because it was a seriously messed up book. It is definitely a superb psychological thriller that has you glued to the pages wanting to find out more. While I did kind of figure out who was blackmailing Evan early on, I think the author wanted readers to find out. It made it kind of eerie to read this and know who the bad person was. I was still very shocked by the ending and had chills reading the epilogue. I honestly just really enjoyed the entirety of this book and it was kind of crazy knowing Jake stole someone‚Äôs entire idea for a book, but yet I was rooting for him. He wrote the book himself, he just used someone‚Äôs idea. If you‚Äôre looking for an exceptional thriller, pick up The Plot it will not disappoint.

Thank you so much to Celadon Books for the ARC of¬†The Plot¬†in exchange for an honest review! My full review, plus a little meet the author blurb, and a little Real Talk blurb that I wrote on industry bullying can all by found in the full review on my blog at https://onereadingnurse.com/2021/04/3...This is a slow burning story that starts out detailing Jacob Finch Bonner‚Äôs sad writing career, and his cynicism towards it. I think his ranting about student writers was hilarious and probably pretty accurate, I can‚Äôt even imagine.¬† Jake is a great character, a bit of a troll himself but he felt so real to me.One cool thing I will say first is that as a Plattsburgh native who spent some time in the Cooperstown/Oneonta/Cobleskill area, I freaking love the setting in these towns üòÇAs we start learning about ‚ÄúThe Plot‚Äù, the mystery develops when Jacob loosely steals an idea from a now deceased former student. The book then took on a bit of a tribute aspect to the greatest plot ever written (cue Tenacious D music) *THIS IS JUST A TRIBUTE* heh heh.But‚Ä¶then‚Ä¶ An internet troll attacks Jacob. It seems pretty benign at first then gets more serious. Thus begins my favorite aspect of The¬†Plot¬†which is a mocking but also kind of true conversation about the publishing industry, reviewer culture, and people trolling authors. The damage it can do (even though it really shouldn‚Äôt), and how Jacob and the legal team handle the issue. I dropped the book and clapped when his publicist was ranting about GoodReads trolls and author morale, because someone finally said it.¬† What is the industry coming to??Seriously though, who could possibly be this upset about the book? Thanks to the publisher for providing an early copy of the audiobook for The Plot in exchange for an honest review.While I get that books can have unlikable protagonists (especially in mystery/thrillers), those protagonists need to be supported by a really strong or compelling narrative to make sure you end up hating them and not the actual book and Jacob Finch Bonner is such an unlikable protagonist that it made this book feel really, really, long.I think a lot of the problem comes from having the narcissistic, judgmental protagonist be a writer because inevitably, it becomes very difficult to draw a mental line between what's the character showing those traits and what's the author. For example, after spending the books opening hearing Jacob judge everyone around him and think about how he's destined for greatness he is finally humbled through reading the work of a student that he describes in narrative as one of the best written things he's ever read. I assumed that was going to work as a summary for what the student wrote but then the next chapter, we read the perfect piece ourselves which (unintentionally) moves Jacob's narcissism to the author since we just read paragraphs of them praising their own work through Jacob's judgmental lens. This book is a whole lot of Jacob feeling awful with the real mystery not really kicking in until the 60% mark and at that point, I was so frustrated with the narrative that Korelitz could have told the best mystery of all time and I still wouldn't have been able to get invested.

"The Plot" is about a failed writer named Jake who's watching his career descend. He can't write anymore, and his last book tanked. He has nothing in the tank. He is reduced to teaching in a lousy MFA program where they take anyone who signs up. He gets a horrendous student who waltzes into class and says, "I don't need to be here because the book I'm writing is foolproof with a foolproof plot." When Jake hears the plot, he knows the jerk is going to have massive success. Years later, Jake wonders why the book never came out. He discovers his former student died, and there is no book. Jake writes his own book and becomes massively successful. But he can't enjoy it because he's terrified that somebody's going to find out. Then somebody does. The rest of the book is a puzzle to figure out who it is and what they know. Jake has to ask himself: who was his student? Where did he get the idea? Did he take it from someone else. This was a very suspenseful plot, and it does involve a book within a book, so we to see some of the novel that's in question because everybody who reads this will want to know, what is the foolproof idea? Jake is complicated, and he has been so twisted by his perceived failure and the loss of what he thinks he deserved to have because he worked hard. I felt bad for Jake. I couldn't tell if I was rooting for him or not, but I wanted him to shout the truth from the rooftops.To listen to the interview with the author, go to my podcast at:https://zibbyowens.com/transcript/jea...

Jacob Finch Bonner is a writer whose glory days are behind him. Now resigned to teach at a third-rate MFA program in nowhere Vermont, he encounters an asshole student who says he has a great idea for a novel. One that is certain to make him rich and famous. Except the student dies. And Jake steals the dead student's idea. Wich makes Jake rich and famous. Well, what could go wrong? Apparently, everything. Great premise, right? But here's the rub: while I adore the premise, I didn't adore the book. I didn't hate it or dislike it, mind you. I just "liked" it, thanks to the author's foundational idea that's as original as the book is readable. The pages flew.On the flip side, my reservations became twofold. First, it was far too easy to deduce who the "anonymous" person was; the one threatening to expose Jake. So once that big "reveal" was revealed, I felt a bit deflated (though I have to say the dialogue portion of that part was written very well). Second, everyone in the book is either a dick or a bag of dicks. Which makes it really hard to root for anyone. Granted, we're supposed to dislike the protagonist, since he stole the idea for his novel from his dead Bag O' Dicks student. How warm and fuzzy are we supposed to feel about any of it? Not much, and I get it. But still. Almost everyone in the book is unlikable in some way, and some far more than others, even though the overall pacing of the novel was good and the tension pretty high throughout. A decent summer read. As long as your expectations aren't too high .

A unique and clever book about books, what's not to love?"All he had ever wanted was to tell‚Äîin the best possible words, arranged in the best possible order‚Äîthe stories inside him."‚ÄúYou‚Äôre only as successful as the last book you published, and you‚Äôre only as good as the next book you‚Äôre writing. So shut up and write.‚Äù‚ÄúOnce you were in possession of an actual idea, you owed it a debt for having chosen you, and not some other writer, and you paid that debt by getting down to work, not just as a journeyman fabricator of sentences but as an unshrinking artist ready to make painful, time-consuming, even self-flagellating mistakes.‚Äù‚Äú...I've always thought there was a kind of beauty to it, the way narratives get told and retold. It's how stories survive through the ages. You can follow an idea from one author's work to another, and to me that's something I find powerful and exciting.‚Äù‚ÄúStories, of course, are common as dirt. Everyone has one, if not an infinity of them, and they surround us all at times whether we acknowledge them or not. Stories are the wells we dip into to be reminded of who we are, and the ways we reassure ourselves that, however obscure we may appear to others, we are actually important, even crucial to the ongoing drama of survival: personal, societal, and even as a species.‚Äù

We first hear from Jacob in his earlier years, and then after he publishes this career-changing novel. As you can imagine, this book was nothing like what I expected. I was so pleasantly surprised by this unique premise.I recommend going in without much information as well.
