I was especially glad I had the book to follow along with!

Thank you Celadon Books & Netgalley for the arc. I actually listened to this book on audio copy provided by Macmillan Audio.3.25/5 Plagiarism is a serious issue no matter the situation. One should never ever steal other person‚Äôs work. This is the core message of The Plot. Though the story started slow, I was able to connect with Jake and understand him as a struggling author / writing coach. Not justifying what he did, but Jake sounded like a sensible person who should have guessed the *someone* since he knew the story of *something turned* why did it occur to him only at the end rather than sooner? When I got ahold of the plot, I guessed the ‚Äúvirtue‚Äù of a certain character long before Jake did. This made me loose my grip with the story, but since it was an audiobook I continued to listen just to know how Jake comes to ‚Äúknow‚Äù. It was an okay revelation - guess this is what happens when one reads too many thrillers!! But I should say, the book with the book format was pretty cool. The writing was very good and the narration was decent, I felt the voice modulations could have been better. If you don‚Äôt read much suspense novels, this might impress you.

James Finch Bonner has become forgettable. His one published novel has faded from memory and he has no idea how to get an agent or publishing house to give him another try. He stumbles along in his sad little life, bringing his black cloud of desperation with him. He takes a job as an instructor at a writers' retreat, pretending to care about his students' submissions. But then he meets Evan Parker, an arrogant young man who has written a few chapters of his guaranteed best-seller. When Bonner hears the snippet that Parker submits, he recognizes great writing and needs to know more. Soon enough, Bonner takes the opportunity presented to him and ... intrigue and mystery ensue.From cover to cover, I thoroughly enjoyed this novel. Korelitz is a master at doling out little bits along the way, making you endlessly try to piece it all together. From the first little snippet of the novel that Evan Parker/Parker Evan submitted to his instructor, I was desperate to know more of that novel within the novel. Slowly, Korelitz reveals it all in such a clever manner and her multiple red herrings had me convinced each time. Totally enjoyable, thrilling and worthy of its hype.

I had to give up on this book at about the one-third mark. It was dreadfully slow and lacked any real tension. The narrator was especially hard to listen to. It seemed like they were concentrating so hard on enunciating every word that it sounded computer-generated and was filled with unnatural pauses. Speeding up the playback helped but did not improve the experience enough. I've seen some reviews suggesting the pace picks up in the latter half of the book, but glacial pacing through the first third is just too much. Unfortunately, I could not enjoy or finish this book.

I had hopes based on the synopsis, but it fell flat fast. The writing was wordy, in fact, too wordy. For an example - the first main was given paragraphs to explain his three part name. I don't feel like I needed that in depth explanation for the middle name Finch that he gave to himself. The last name derived from a Jewish name. Who cares that much ? It held nothing in regards to the plot. Sadly, about 25% I gave up. The style and length was just overboard, in my opinion. DNF

That was a wild ride. This was on several "best book" lists so I thought I would check it out and I am glad that I did. That ending!I thought I was reading a mundane book about an author that does something morally questionable, but then it took a turn. Man. Highly recommend.

You have to wade through the entire book to understand how he steals ‚Äúthis plot‚Äù and this stolen idea has grave repercussions on his own life, albeit the main story. As the story was predictable for me, it did not give me any thrill or cliff hangers feeling to at-last know why ‚Äúthe plot‚Äù had such grave consequences for him and who was actually behind this idea. The author of this book, herself brings up this point that in the world we live in today, no body has a copyright to a great idea and unluckily, the entire premise of the book is predicated on stealing ‚Äúthe plot‚Äù. It‚Äôs tough to digest that a great idea, even if stolen would make the author jump through so many hoops and give so much heartburn given that the author herself points out that a great idea cannot be copyrighted. Another issue I have with the writing is that if a thought can be communicated in a crisp and concise manner then there is no need to regurgitate the same thought in twenty different ways as musings of the writer. To my mind that is just lazing writing since you‚Äôre trying to fill up the pages in the book without much thought to the story moving forward or actually helping the narrative of your book. Another issue I have with the book is the main character of the book, namely Jacob Bonner, always seems to be lucky to get hold of the right people at the right time - this again I feel is laziness on the part of the author as the author should try and put some more context and colour on the people. Some books are so easy to read. This was definitely not one of them. I felt like giving up so many times cause either the author kept saying the same thing over and over again or was whining a ton but I stayed with it. Pick it up if you have nothing else to read!!! Because of all the above reasons, my rating for the book is 2 stars.

This book had one of the most unique and original plots I‚Äôve ever read, and that‚Äôs saying a lot. Also, a book about books, authors, bookstores, or publishing is just going to resonate even more with me because I (obviously) love books and my job. Both of those things made it so fun to read, especially the interludes with the chapters of the book written inside of this one. I will say that the reveal at the end was entirely surprising, but the twist to lead up to that point absolutely was. And even so, the way that the ending was done was perfect, even guessing what happens it was still entertaining and jaw dropping. If I had more time I probably would‚Äôve finished it in one sitting.

Plot (noun)) = A sequence of events in a narrative, as in a novel. This novel's suspense quotient is thru the roof! A page-turner that grabs you from the first chapter and won't let you go until the breathtaking conclusion, one that you won't see coming. A story within a story where a jaded writer, Jake Bonner, finds a second shot at success in a whirlwind thriller that probes the nature of creative provenance and asks the question: Whose stories are we allowed to tell?When a student shares a story he is writing that he believes will be a best seller Jake can't get it out of his head. When years go by and he still has not seen it published he gets curious and starts hunting for his former student. Finding out that the student died ten years ago he decides to write the book himself. What could go wrong? It's the perfect plot!! *Reviewed by Janet from Camden Point*
A disappointing book within a book. Saw both twists coming a mile away. Do not recommend it.
